documents.commentText:
I am a 61 year old woman who has degenerative disc disease,spinal stenosis,arthritis of the spine,hips,hands and knees,and fibromyalgia. Have had these ailments since 1990. I also suffer from depression and PTSD from my teen years due to extensive physical and sexual abuse from childhood on.
For almost 25 years my physical ailments limited my life tremendously. I spent most of my time either in bed or on my couch because of the terrible pain. My emotional issues during that time kept me from being able to socialize or be among groups of people because I would have panic attacks and terrible anxiety.
I learned of kratom in several pain groups I was involved with on social media.
I had avoided all pharmaceutical medications because of the numerous side effects and the fact that they were all addictive.So,I was wary of kratom also,but was so tired of living as I was. I had no quality of life. 
I decided to try it in January 2015. 
I was extremely surprised to notice the almost immediate difference in my pain levels. They had been at a steady 8-10 all those years and were now at an appreciated level of 3-4. I was able to move around better with less pain. I could do simple everyday things others did,such as stand long enough to actually cook a meal,go to the supermarket myself to shop,do small loads of wash instead of the laundromat doing it for me. The biggest joy was being able to do things with my grandchildren! 
As all of this was happening I also noticed I wasn't having panic attacks and could be amongst people again. I was able to go to church again!
I once again feel like a productive member of society instead of being isolated. The thought of losing this simple plant from the coffee family and going back to that heartache frightens me. I never want to be there again.
Please don't condemn me to that life again. 
There are so many thousands of us that have been helped by this plant.
It is not addictive,you cannot overdose on it,and there have been no deaths attributed to just kratom alone. The drugs that are FDA approved cannot make those claims,yet they are permitted to be prescribed to people who have become terribly addicted to them and there are thousands of deaths attributed to prescription pain medicine every year.
Please allow me to continue to help myself with this harmless plant. Do not sentence me to a life of isolation and agonizing pain.
Thank you for your time and your consideration of my plight,along with many thousands of others.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to you to reach out to in order to prevent the scheduling of the natural, herbal supplement Kratom. Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) is a plant indigenous to Southeast Asia. Traditionally, in certain regions of Southeast Asia, the chopped fresh or dried leaves of the tree are chewed or made into tea by local manual laborers to combat fatigue and improve work productivity. Its leaves contain the alkaloids mitragynine, and 7-hydroxymitragynine.  Kratom is used to treat pain, depression, anxiety, and opiate addiction. I use Kratom for several different reasons. It has improved my life and health.  It is not physically addictive, no more than caffeine (Its actually related to the coffee plant.) The DEA has recently expressed their intent to place Kratom on schedule 1, meaning it has no medical value and it also is extremely harmful to human health. The overwhelming evidence and my personal experience is that Kratom is extremely safe and definitely far safer than certain pharmaceutical, narcotic medicines. I ask for your help in this matter and request that you help allow this beautiful plant medicine to continue to improve peoples lives.
Maximum King

documents.commentText:
Hello, my name is Brandey and I am a 27 year old mother, and chronically ill person. My illness started in 2011 when I came down with viral meningitis. I spent 3 days in the hospital and 6 months trying to recover, but I have never been the same. My central nervous system is severely out of whack, and I feel touch and pain much differently. Meningitis also kick started an autoimmune disease, and I am currently undergoing tests for Multiple Sclerosis, Lupus, and Myasthenia Gravis. I also have Fibromyalgia. My brain has also been affected. I now have a small tumor growing in my brain, among other lesions that my doctor has found. I (had) an IQ of 125, perfect vision, excellent memory and fantastic health. Now there are days when I can barely remember my own name, I now wear glasses, have chronic migraines and have been in the hospital 7 out of the last 30 days. I now suffer from major depression and an anxiety disorder, and I have frequent panic attacks. I feel useless. My organs keep going bad, and my appendix  (out this month) was my last expendable one. The pressure in my head is UNBEARABLE. The smallest infection (they couldnt find the source) made me go septic, and I spent 4 days in yhe TCU. The reason I am telling you this is because I want you to get an idea of how a truly sick person like myself has benefitted from kratom. Mytragina Speciosa is a safe, beneficial tea leaf. It is the safest alternative to opioid pain killers available. I was able to stay out of pain management for the last year because of this plant, even though I do qualify for pain management treatment. I don't want to become a junkie. I want to function and have a normal life, which I am able to do with kratom. I am the type of person that does extensive research before putting anything into my body. There have been no documented overdoses of kratom alone--all persons had other harmful substances in their system that ultimately caused death. I WANT to be around for my son. I want to live as long as my body will let me, without the risk of accidental overdose. Please consider doing research on the benefits of this plant, instead of banning it. There is valuable research that can be done to help other people like me. To make pain management as safe as scientifically possible. To treat and cure addiction. Please consider our testimonies, and don't ban Mytragina Speciosa and it's derivative alkaloid compounds. This will hurt so many people, and cause so many deaths. 
Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText: I am an NIH (National Institutes of Health)-funded neuroscientist specializing in addiction research, and I do not think the DEA should schedule Mitragynine or 7-Hydroxymitragynine. Scheduling these compounds will dramatically decrease their availability for research at a time when we should be expanding it. The country is currently facing an epidemic of opioid abuse, and these compounds represent one of the most promising treatment options for opioid addiction. Millions of people in the United States have safely used these compounds, particularly as a replacement for more dangerous opioids. Scheduling them now will only exacerbate the growing opioid epidemic by removing one of the few safe alternatives for people experiencing opioid addiction.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,
Kratom has become an important part of my health care.  I have a slow growing tumor in my spine, and a disc in my lower back that the MRI tech could only describe as obliterated.  As such, I live in constant pain.  Kratom manages that pain, far better and longer acting than the opioids my doctor prescribed.  I also feel more clear headed than on the pain pills. If you take this safe alternative away, I will have to go back to the opioids, and I don't want the pain clinic to turn me into a junkie.  As an agency supposedly there to help protect the public (and not just be an extension of "Big Pharma"), how, in the midst of this opioid crisis (which makes the crack explosion in the 80's look like childsplay), can you even consider banning this alternative which has been used through human history with little to no adverse consequences?  Most of the poor countries where it's grown made it illegal domestically because it's one of their only exportable cash crops, and the rest of the world pays better, NOT because they were concerned with their countrymen's well-being.  Please, regulate this industry for product consistency and set a minimum age (no one wants kids messing with any potential intoxicant).  But if you are truly interested in serving the public's best interest, you will leave this safer alternative available for responsible adults.  If not, then we will all know where you truly stand.

documents.commentText: Hello,thank you to everyone who approved this comment period. I am 20 years old and I live in Louisiana,I work everyday in air conditioning ductwork for industrial applications like college campuses,businesses,hospitals,ect. It is a very hot job and it's extremely hard work. When I was younger I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia. Around the age of 11 I was in a dirtbike accident and broke ribs. I was in bed for about a week or two and then i got up and wanted to race again, but everytime I rode after the wreck I noticed a slight pain in my back. I always pushed it off as fibro and took my lortab or tramadol and It helped a little. Well to get to the point when I turned 18,at this time my back has gotten so bad I have lost jobs because I can not work or even get out of bed. My life went downhill fast. In  about a year and a halfs time I had been addicted to every pain pill you could think of ( mostly Oxycontin, that did not work) so I started heroin. I weigh 123 lbs and was doing about $300 of it a day. Until I almost Overdosed. It made me want to stop. So I did it (with the help of family and friends) I withdrawed and hurt for days and nights. Seemed like forever. I had what I think was seizures, extreme vomiting, bowel movements uncontrollably, cold sweats, hot flashes, uncontrollable muscle movement and so on and so on. I WISH I WOULD HAVE KNOWN ABOUT KRATOM THEN. But I got threw it. I used suboxone for about 5 months to help. But my back still hurt. I found kratom from a 79 year old lady that uses it for arthritis and has been for a long time. I was skeptical at first because I wanted to stay away for drugs that could possibly become addictive. I tried it one time and that day was the best day I have ever had. Pain was low and no WD symptoms. I felt human again. I have been enjoying this amazing plant for ever since. I have never had any bad side effects at all. I went from not being able to get up out of bed to having an amazing job that I love,married my bestfriend of years,and now have a babygirl comming in December. Kratom does not fix the problem. It's makes it liveable. I have not done any type of drug, alcohol,or pain killer since I found kratom. Please reconsider the ban on kratom and it's ingredients. I finally have my life back. Please don't take it away.. let my little girl have a happy actively great daddy. Please. Thank you for reading.

documents.commentText:
My name Patrick Bunch. I am 27 years old. I currently work for Citigroup as an Operations Analyst.
I was introduced to Kratom through a local business that sells various types of unique teas. I have consumed Kratom both as a capsule form and as a brewed beverage on several occasions. I have never felt any sort of urge to continue consuming Kratom after each use. I have never felt a loss of coordination, felt a lapse in normal judgement or loss of control. 
With regards to overdosing or abuse, I don't see Kratom as being dangerous, from my experience, taking too much Kratom (a very large amount) at once  will make one feel nauseous and with possibly vomit. 
Now, my girlfriend was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis and began to lose coordination, lose sensation in her hands and feet, experience depression, experience difficulty using the bathroom, loss of cognitive function and on occasion experiences slight tremors in her arms.
We sought alternatives to help manage her symptoms and discovered many testimonials about how Kratom has helped people manage symptoms. 
My girlfriend has found relief of her symptoms when consuming Kratom. 
She says that many of the symptoms subside and even disappear for short periods of time after consuming Kratom.
Her relapses do not occur as frequently when she uses Kratom and it is much safer than the prescription medications that she may have to take in the future if her symptoms get worse.
If her condition worsens, she will begin to take medicines that will make her susceptible to progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is a fatal virus in the brain.
We believe that Kratom may be one of the tools to manage her disease and bring her relief.

Please consider before making this plant illegal, funding and pushing for more unbiased professional research.
Thank you for listening

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,
 
Please remove Mitragynine & 7-hydroxymitragynine which is in Kratom from becoming a Schedule I substance.
 
I am 29 and suffer from a herniated disc, chronic neck pain, TMJ, arthritis in my neck. I support a family of four on a single income as Help Desk Technician. I have been to many doctors with little success for treatment. I have found that Kratom improves my quality of life after a hard days work. It isnt comparable to any drugs, marijuana, alcohol or other stimulants.  Kratom helps to improve my quality of life that I suffer with chronic pain. Please dont make this herb illegal. Cervical injections, botox injections, chiropractic care, physical therapy, acupuncture, massage therapy, yoga exercises have not helped with my pain.
 
Kratom is a well-known, well-researched herbal substance drawn from the leaves of trees within the coffee family. The number of cases of documented harm from kratom use is remarkably low, both as an absolute matter and when considered against the extensive history of use of kratom, both inside and outside the United States
 
Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine are two of the primary alkaloids of this plant. These two compounds are not synthetic and should not be lumped together with  "bath salts" or "spice".
 
Kratom has been used as a medicine by many people for thousands of years. It is a potent remedy for physical pain, anxiety and depression, and could be used to aid with opiate withdrawal by those who would like to quit using illicit drugs such as heroin. Kratom is NOT a hallucinogen and should not be classified as such. Adding mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as a Schedule I substance is rash and unjustified prohibition, resulting in a foreseeable increase in street drug-related crime, as well as a punishment to those who are currently using it responsibly to treat various ailments.

The reason that there are no deaths solely attributed to Kratom is because Kratom does not affect your respiratory capacity. It does not slow down your central nervous system. It's potential to do harm is virtually impossible.

Kratom has very limited recreational capacity.  The White House petition has over 100,000 signatures for the "Please do not make Kratom a Schedule I Substance." 

The federal government has invested significant resources to develop alternative pain management strategies. This includes a study funded by the National Institutes of Health in partnership with the University of Massachusetts and the University of Mississippi to investigate the use of Kratom as a remedy for opioid withdrawal. This study led the researchers to apply for a patent identifying the Kratom extract, mitragyinine, as a useful treatment for other addictive drugs besides opiate derivatives. The DEAs decision to place Kratom as a Schedule I substance will put a halt on federally funded research and innovation surrounding the treatment of individuals suffering from opioid and other addictionsa significant public health threat. Remember the DDear Colleague Letters of Senator Hatch and Congressman Mark Pocan.
 
We hope you realize the threat this scheduling causes the people seeking legitimate use of this special plant to improve our quality of life. Attached are testimonies and facts about Kratom along with other facts listed below. 

Sincerely,
 
Anonymous

United States. Kratom does not qualify as an imminent hazard to public safety and is outside of
the DEAs emergency scheduling power (Controlled Substances Act, CSA).

documents.commentText:
My name is John Michael. I am 45 years old, and live in Los Angeles, California.

I was distressed when I first heard that kratom was going to be placed on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances. I believe this action would harm countless people who have found kratom to be an invaluable tool in getting off opioids. It would also deprive this helpful and inexpensive resource to people who find themselves battling opioid addiction in the future.

I'd been prescribed hydrocodone for my back in 2004. I used it on and off over the years, but found it was getting to be a serious problem for me in 2013. My intake had escalated to 8 pills a day. I was worried about stopping taking them for fear of withdrawal.

I read online about kratom. I tried it, and found that it eased my withdrawal symptoms to the point where I could comfortably function, and even go to work. I was no longer in that "opiate fog" I had been in every day for months on end. A dose in the morning, and a dose before bed did the trick.

After a few weeks, I stopped the kratom intake and have been able to keep off hydrocodone since. In all my times taking kratom, I have always found its effects to be subtle and mild. Akin to the effect caffeine has. In my experience, alcohol is way more potent a drug than kratom. Without kratom, I'm not sure what I would have done.

Thank you for taking the time to read and consider my comment, and thank you for delaying the schedule 1 order for kratom to hear from the people who have benefited from it.

documents.commentText:
To Whom This May Concern,
I was encouraged to tell my story on this forum to increase awareness of the benefits of Kratom.  14 years ago I was diagnosed with a sever case of Crohns Disease.  I was 21 at the time and in college.  This disease placed me in the hospital on many occasions, and threatened my life several times.  My team of doctors were great but all plans of action failed; forcing them to strongly suggest the removal of my large intestine as well as a portion of my small.  I was an athlete my whole life and they were clear that this procedure would limit my ability participate in sporting activities, assuming I would successfully recover.  I refused the operation and trusted in God to see me through.  I figured, I was born with them and I will die with them.  They accepted my choice and placed me on a morphine drip for the pain.  Months later I slowly recovered to a place of health that was nothing short of a miracle.  During my recovery, the pain was excruciating but I always turned away the prescriptions of pain killers the doctors wrote.  I never wanted to become dependent on them and made the choice to avoid them.  Throughout the years, flare ups have been a regular occurrence.  Each flare up has been met without the aid of prescription pain killers.  My family hated to see me in such terrible pain and often looked for homeopathic ways to help me.  All efforts fell short until my brother researched and recommended Kratom.  When I looked into it and found enough evidence of its non-addicting attributes I decided to try it.  It has been a God send.  Not only did it help me manage my pain, it helped me in many other ways dealing with such a debilitating disease.  
I am now 36 years old.  I am the Business Operations Officer for River Pediatric Therapies in which I oversee and navigate all business decisions for future growth.  I have also opened a successful gym in my spare time.  There are many factors that have helped me be successful from such a sick and debilitating start.  There is no question that Kratom was one of these factors.  As for the debate on Kratoms addictive qualities; I have never experienced any dependency on it at any time.  I went from taking it daily during a bad flare up to only taking it when pain arises, which currently is about once every two weeks or so.  I ask that you take my story to heart and keep the one supplement that has truly helped me legal.

Thank you,

Justin

documents.commentText:
To whomever it may be of concern, 

I write this letter in order to just further add to the rhetoric that Kratom should not be classified as schedule-1 drug. It has been shown to help people who are currently struggling with an addiction to painkillers. If this drug could be regulated and used as treatment for these people then I believe it could truly help those struggling with addiction, and more importantly, it would be beneficial to their families. 

I'm originally from Boston MA. And growing up in Boston I saw many things, and one of those things being heroin addiction. In 2015 my uncle charlie died after he overdosed on heroin. He had broken his knee two years prior and started taking pain killers for his injury. The only problem was that he became hooked on those fucking pills. He'd be popping them like they were tick tacks, and after a while it became pretty evident that he had started to develop a problem. After his insurance couldn't cover the medication anymore he moved on to shooting heroin, and other substances. I slowly watched a man who was in many ways like a big brother too me become a completely different human being. He would constantly lie about why he needed money, when in reality he just needed a quick buck so he could go shoot up. I honest to god believe that if this drug was made available then circumstances like these would be avoided. For me and for many people whom have had relatives that struggle with an addiction to painkillers, and then see those addictions become much worse. 

So I please ask you to reconsider what the effects of criminalizing this drug could have. If not with yourself, then the consequences it could have for others and their families. Thank you for your consideration and I hope you have a pleasant day.

documents.commentText:
There is overwhelming social support to END the war on drugs, as it has been proven to been a failure over the decades. Banning Kratom would continue this failing war that costs the country far too much money, ruins lives of convicted drug offenders, and is ultimately ineffective and unfairly prosecutes minority groups. According to the Law Enforcement Against Prohibition, "kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement." This should not be placed in the 5 drug schedules as it has proven medicinal benefits. They also pose the following points: 
-Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down
-Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
-Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

The War on Drugs has been detrimental to the relationship between law enforcement and the communities in which they serve. Trust has been shattered and social support to end the war on drugs is higher than ever before. It is crucial that we as a country choose to make the decisions that restore trust, create fairness, remove prejudice, and allow freedom to the citizens of this nation.

Please do not ban Kratom. This would be a step in the wrong direction for our country.

documents.commentText:
I have been prescribed hydrocodone for years to treat chronic back pain. As regulation has tightened on opioids in response to the addiction epidemic, it has been increasingly difficult for me to get access to this medication. Although I have never had an addiction problem, I have had physicians refuse to prescribe it because of their own feelings about the drug. When my physician does prescribe it, I am often subjected to burdensome and even humiliating conditions, including drug tests, before I can get a prescription refilled.

Until very recently, I was forced to accept these conditions as the price I paid for access to the only drug that has has been fully effective in treating my pain. But in the last six months I discovered Kratom and it has changed my life. The plant is just as effective for treating my chronic pain, and I have been able to get access to it without stigma or embarrassment. As a result, I have been able to significantly curtail my use of opioids for pain management. So naturally I was distressed and upset when I heard the DEA had moved to cut off my access to Kratom and force me back into the regular use of prescription opioids. This struck me as incredibly irresponsible, and even cruel, based more on perception than science. The outcry from the public, the scientific community, and even Congress, and the DEA's relatively unprecedented decision to back down from the rescheduling, tells me my suspicions were correct.

Please do not take away the access that I and many many others depend on to a natural substance that serves to lessen our dependence on synthetic opioids, while treating very real, very painful conditions. Kratom is safe, has few if any of the addictive characteristics of opiods, and is highly effective. To remove access to it makes absolutely no sense under the DEA's previous reasoning.

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
I am 63 years old and retired (disabled). I worked for The Electrical Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT) as Sr. Compliance Engineer. In 2011, I was forced to take disability due to five (5) unsuccessful back surgeries. I have been under the care of a Pain Management (PM) doctor since 2007 for chronic pain (CP), and I am in good standing with my all of my doctors.

I strongly oppose the DEA's choice to move Kratom to a Schedule 1 drug or to restrict it in any form. Many CP patients exchange psychological pain in return for limited physical relief - I am one of them. In addition to the dismal side effects of opiates, we are treated like drug addicts on parole. For those of us who have access to treatment, the presumption of guilt overshadows and influences all aspects of said treatment. We must sign a one sided contract, which robs us of our rights as patients. If we refuse, we suffer. Our privacy is invaded with drug testing and pill counting. Many doctors viewed us as a liability and marginalized us as human beings. No other class of patients endures this kind of treatment! Can you find equality and the due process promised to us by the Constitution in the setting described above? What about our rights!

This experience lead me to discovered Kratom earlier this year (2016), I have found this plant to be safe and effective in reducing pain without the side effects of opiates. It is also less expensive than doctor's visits and medication. It has been good for my mental well being, too. My blood pressure has dropped. My cognitive ability has returned to normal and did so proportionally as I reduced the intake of pain medication. I am able to do more chores around the house. I can make plans without worrying about the restrictions of being tied to one pharmacy or obtaining a written script every 30 days (PM contract), which includes a 2.5-hour drive. I don't have to worry about the pharmacy being out of the medication, or endure being viewed as a "drug seeker" by the pharmacy technicians. CP is bad enough on its own, but when combined with the treatment that comes with it, it can make life unbearable. Imagine what this would be like for you. Would you want this kind of treatment for yourself, or a parent, spouse, or child? Think long and hard about it!

Again, I oppose any restrictions on Kratom. In closing, I would like to say that I will never be free from pain, but thanks to this plant, I am free of pain medication and free from the draconian environment that accompanies CP treatment. And equality important, I have regained my personal dignity and a modest measure of independence. There are many who testify to this fact. This is real progress: Do not rob us of this small victory!

documents.commentText:
I am not sure if this comment is going to retain my formatting or not. I have attached another copy as a .txt file to make it easier to read if the formatting is not retained.

I was an opioid addict for nearly a decade, most of that time spent struggling and failing to get clean. Kratom was the only way I was able to beat this, and I have been using it for almost three years with no ill effects. I don't think it's hyperbolic to say that Kratom saved my life. I'm also afraid of what will happen if it gets banned again and remains illegal. I know many people who are in the same situation as I am. I have tried Suboxone in the past, but it was impossible for me to bear the cost of the expensive prescription and monthly doctor appointments. Additionally, it caused many harmful side effects such as chronic severe constipation and left me with an addiction just as bad, if not worse, than I originally had.

From my own experiments I believe that it is physically impossible to suffer a fatal (or even dangerous) overdose from Kratom alone. The plant contains alkaloids other than mitragynine and 7-hydroxy mitragynine. At least one of them has been found to be an opioid receptor antagonist. When an individual consumes an exceptionally large dose of Kratom, these other alkaloids present themselves in sufficient amounts that they start to block the opioid action of mitragynine and 7-hydroxy mitragynine in addition to causing a number of unpleasant (but not dangerous) side effects which resemble a hangover from alcohol (headache and nausea being the most notable) and fade within a few hours.

Normal Kratom doses range from 3-5 grams up to 15-20 grams. In order to show the relative safety of Kratom compared to other substances, I have consumed as much as 30 grams or more on multiple occasions. While I did experience headache, nausea, and mild dizziness at such large doses, there was not a single instance in which I experienced any respiratory depression whatsoever  or felt the need to seek medical attention. Based on my observations, I do not believe that Kratom poses any significant threat to public health and safety whatsoever.

I think it is worth noting that the letter of intent published by the DEA cited 15 deaths and 660 calls to Poison Control Centers associated with Kratom use in the entire USA in two years' time. While myself and many others clearly find this number to be dubious and suspect the true number to be zero, for a moment let's assume that it is accurate. That would mean that in two years, 15 people have been harmed while thousands have used it to free themselves from addictions to much more dangerous substances. For comparison:

- From 2013-2014 there were about 22,000 calls to Poison Control Centers due to ingestion of laundry detergent pods. 

- In 2014 Poison Control reported 112,412 calls for antidepressants, 66,058 for vitamins, and 31,903
for exposure to hydrocarbons such as gasoline (source: https://aapcc.s3.amazonaws.com/pdfs/annual_reports/2014_AAPCC_NPDS_Annual_Report.pdf)

- Data obtained from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that more than 300    people die annually as a result of acetaminophen poisoning. Acetaminophen is also responsible for roughly 100,000 calls to poison control and 60,000 emergency room visits annually in the USA alone.

- The CDC reported 29,001 deaths due to alcohol in 2013.(http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvsr/nvsr64/nvsr64_02.pdf)

- In the USA in 2013, 1,182 individuals were treated at a medical facility for overdose of caffeine with 12 of them experiencing major negative health symptoms.

- Cows kill 20 people per year in the USA (40 per 2 years = 2.67 times as deadly as Kratom)
- Dogs kill 28 people per year in the USA (56 per 2 years = 3.73 times as deadly as Kratom)
- Bees, Wasps, and Hornets kill 58 people per year in the USA (116 per 2 years = 7.73 times as deadly as Kratom) [all three of these sourced from CDC]

I could go on but I think I've made my point. A good friend of mine just died from an opioid overdose a few days ago. It's time for us to start doing things a different way. The people being helped by Kratom are friends, neighbors, sons, daughters, brothers, sisters, mothers, and fathers. It is inhumane to cut them off from the treatment that allowed them to regain a normal life, especially when doing so leaves them with no other options.

If Kratom is banned permanently, I guarantee that deaths from both illicit and prescription opioids will increase considerably. This isn't even speculation; it has already happened in the states that have banned Kratom on their own.

documents.commentText:
My name is Francisco Soler. I am a father of 6 and happily married since to a wonderful  since 2004. 
In 2008 after suffering a lower back injury in a martial arts competition I was forced to visit a specialist to help me get back to teaching and competing as a top martial artist instructor
For 6 straight months I attended Physical Therapy, massage therapy and even tried acupuncture, but no matter what we tried the pain was getting worst, day in, day out.

It was so bad that my entire left side of the body was almost useless.
So my Dr. prescribed hydrocodone for the pain. Boom! after 2 hours of drinking my new little white pills, the pain was gone. Not only was the pain gone but I felt amazing. So the next month I told the Dr to please increase my dosage since 1 pill wasn't doing the job any longer.

To make a long story short 30 pills went to 60, 60 went to 120 and 120 went to over 300 a month. I was addicted for the first time in my life. One day after having gone to the Dr to get my pills he told me that he could not do that for me any longer, I was shocked and destroyed. My body started going into the worst withdrawal symptoms in history. I wanted to kill myself! Desperate to find something to take the edge off I went to the street for help. I had no choice. my wife went from having an all-star athlete to now having to put up with a junkie. I lost my job and was quickly losing my home and family. 

 As I searched and searched for an answer I finally gave in and started using heroin. I was shocked at how quickly my withdrawals symptoms went away. 2 weeks of mental health hell, relieved by a 10 dollar bag of heroin. the catch? The heroin addiction was even worst because my heroin habit went from 2 bags a day to 2 bundles a day! I was officially screwed. After 2 months of using heroin, I decided enough is enough I went back to my Dr. and begged him to please prescribe to me a pill called suboxone used to treat heroin addicts.

 The Suboxone was another trap. Yes, I only needed a pill a day, but if 3 days passed without my dose, the ugly monster would come back and there I was again chasing a high I just could not control. Scared out of my mind that the suicide thoughts would eventually turn into action. For 7 straight years, I depended on Suboxone to live a half way decent life until again my Dr surprised me with the news that he could no longer prescribe them anymore. And there I was again with 6 pills enough to last me for a week and tired of chasing Dr's. this time though I was determined not to go back to heroin but to find a Natural remedy to my disease.

 That is when I found Kratom my life saver. I ordered some from a reputable online vendor, tried it and voila, my symptoms went away, except this time was different I wasn't feeling the high that opioids provide, but rather a natural sense of well-being and an increase in energy. it took me about 2 months to finally accept that with Kratom I wasn't going to get high. I don't use Kratom as much anymore but I will forever be grateful to that plant for helping me take back my life and be a father to my kids, Someone they can be proud of. for the first time in my life I have my own business and my family is closer than ever, we are even making plans to buy a house. I ask you to please do not take Kratom away from  us, it is not a drug to get high, it is an alternative a natural one for many diseases like drug addiction, pain, and depression. I thank you for letting me comment on this issue and hope that you will help the millions of people benefiting from this amazing Plant called Kratom

documents.commentText:
Hello,
My name is Jolie. I am a 46 year old woman, wife and mother. I have a Masters Degree in Clinical Social Work. I have suffered with mental illness since my late teens. I have been hospitalized many times for suicidal ideation, severe depression and psychosis. I have participated in talk therapy since my teens and started taking anti-depressants in my early 20s. However, I med resistant and none of the medications I have  taken have ever worked. Many of the medications have given me horrible side effects (i.e. psychotic episode). Last year, I had a course of Electroconvulsive Therapy. The treatments were not successful and until this day I suffer from memory loss and impaired cognition. As a result I am unable to work at this time.
I have never abused drugs or alcohol. Currently, I am taking 4 medications to help combat Major Depressive Disorder, General Anxiety Disorder, and Bipolar Type 2. The medications help stabilize me, but I still have trouble functioning on a daily basis due to the depression and the severe anxiety. I am no longer looking for a cure, but a way to "manage" my life in healthy ways.
My mother believed in homeopathic treatment, however, I resisted. And then I started to research the benefits of Kratom for individuals like myself. I read similar things in response to other medications and even ECT and I was skeptical. However, I decided if I was going to voluntarily shock my brain 5 days a week trying Kratom surely could not make things any worse.
I continued to read and research. I finally ordered multiple strains to see if I could get the relief I needed. After several tries I started to notice a significant change in my mood, anxiety and behavior. It did not happen overnight. I noticed I was feeling good. I felt something I had never felt before. I had clarity and patience. A sense of happiness took over the continued feelings of hopelessness. I can't remember that last time I had any thoughts of suicide or violent outbursts. I discussed the changes I was experiencing with my therapist and she said this is what it feels like to have hope. This is what it feels like to want to be alive. This is what if feels like to enjoy your children. For the first time ever she said I was living a healthy lifestyle.
To this day, I am shocked at the remarkable changes in my life due to Kratom. I am certainly not cured and I never will be. I still feel depressed at times and I still have anxiety attacks. However, they are manageable and not debilitating. They don't last all day and they don't last for months at a time. Instead of sleeping all day and asking a friend to pick up my children from school, I get up with them in the morning, prepare breakfast and pick them up after school. I still may feel depressed but I am able to function. And then there are days, multiple days in a row where I feel good. And I can't believe it. Nothing has ever helped me the way Kratom has. Nothing has even come close. I am a better mom, wife, sister and daughter. I have control over my illness. My illness does not control me. I am happy. I see my future. Medication has never afforded me this wonderful opportunity for healing and recovery. If there is a ban on Kratom I do not know what I am going to do. I am terrified of going back to those dark, ugly places. I am afraid that I will not be able to leave my house for days due to crippling anxiety. I am afraid my children will see me sleeping all day. I dread the thoughts and planning for suicide. My one and only regret is that my mother is now deceased and has not been able to see me well after so many years of struggling and being unwell. 
Please do not take this away from me. Please. It has changed my life in ways I never imagined.

I am pleased to have an opportunity to offer my comments on how kratom has positively affected my life. My name is Valorie Mall and I am a retired teacher with 30 years of memories of the best career anyone could imagine.  I am 65 years old.

I am disabled resulting from chronic auto immune conditions, neuropathy, and stenosis. My emotional health is affected by PTSD.  DURIng my adult years I have used prescriptions for a variety of pain medications, anti depressants, and anti anxiety drugs. Some were very helpful, others were accompanied by life altering side effects such as memory issues, poor thinking skills, balance problems and unrelenting exhaustion.  At the end of December 2015 I fell and broke my leg in three places.  The hospital stay was a nightmare. Since I was a chronic pain patient it was nearly impossible to control the pain from the injury. After all the therapy to literally get back on my feet, I was done with the amount and types of medications I was on.  They did not help enough to justify how they were destroying my life. I could not speak or think clearly and I was constantly afraid of falling.  

After he misery of getting myself off all my prescriptions without assistance, I had to find alternatives.  My pain and anxiety were still there and I had to find ways to deal with them.  I began searching the Internet for pain relief alternatives. I found kratom.  

My trial of kratom did not begin immediately, first I did research.  After reading many articles and communicating with people that were successfully using kratom for pain and anxiety relief, I was ready to try. I ordered a small amount from a well regarded online vendor.  The result was amazing. After I learned how to adjust amounts and strains, my pain was significantly diminished and my anxiety was under control.  But the best part was there were no side effects.  Friends and family began to comment on the change in me. I could speak and think clearly. I was able to progress at improving my stamina and physical strength.  My sleep had fewer PTSD interruptions. 

There is no cure for the issues I deal with physically and emotionally. But kratom has helped me manage symptoms and improve my quality of life. There are not enough words to explain the difference in my life. I do not believe this wonderful plant should be a schedule 1 substance.  It will negatively impact so many lives. We deserve our chance to lead productive and satisfying lives.

documents.commentText: Our nation already has a problem with mass incarceration.  Ramping up the drug war will only exacerbate this problem.  There is absolutely no reason to invent a crime by adding anything to the schedule of controlled substances.  Locking more people up for using kratom does not solve any problem and increases harms to people who choose to use this plant.  Kratom has been used safely for many years and has been shown to ease symptoms of opioid withdrawal.  Criminalizing this plant (and its users!) will only worsen the nation's problem with opioid addiction and overdose.  Turning law-abiding citizens into criminals by bureaucratic fiat is never a good idea.  Also, substances in Schedule I are notoriously difficult to study due to regulatory roadblocks.  Placing kratom in Schedule I will only impede the research that may help us understand this plant.

documents.commentText:
I am a Clinical Substance Abuse Counselor, and I am reaching out in regards to the DEA's efforts to push a ban on two active alkaloids that are present in the plant known as Kratom. I understand there is a lot of concern recently over this plant, however, there is also a lot of misinformation regarding this plant too. I specialize in opiate misuse treatment. I graduated with a masters degree in mental health counseling from Viterbo University. I have been working in the Medically-Assisted Treatment field for almost three years and have significant experience helping people end their opiate addiction and heal the extensive damage that occurs cognitively from extended opiate misuse. I am also very adept at working with methamphetamine addiction which this specialized area is still very much in its infancy yet.  

Many people I have spoken to over the last couple years report that Kratom has been very helpful in alleviating symptoms of withdrawal from their opioid medications when they stop wanting to take these narcotics and retain their former quality of life. Of course this plant became something of interest to me and over the last two years I began doing some research and spoke with hundreds of people about how this plant works for them and what their experiences are regarding Kratom.  I have learned that if you take too much you will feel very sick and ultimately you may even throw up. I believe the knowledge that this plant can help with opiate treatment has caused many, many people to seek it out and use it as a home remedy. I also think that not everyone does their research about this plant and if used improperly there could be fear enough to call 911 and ask for help- hence the increase in CDC poison control calls in the last few years regarding Kratom. This is where regulation is needed and can help protect and inform the public on proper kratom consumption.

Kratom was banned in Wisconsin, when misinformation was at its highest, so I have had no contact with the substance. I suspect many people in the DEA have as much personal experience with this plant as I, but why is it that an addiction expert and a government entity have such opposing views on this topic? Deep down I just dont see how banning more plants is going to help in the opioid epidemic. Also, if this leaf works as many people say that it does, I believe banning Kratom would actually increase the likelihood of people using heroin when the DEA cuts off the opioid supply in 2017 due to changing regulation. I truly believe that banning Kratom will have a direct impact on increasing overdose death rates if this plant is able to ease people from resorting to opiates and/or heroin use. 

As a clinician, I also encourage you to look at this issue from a clinical perspective, and if you are not sure what that means I can explain. First, It is important to understand what defines substance abuse and how it impacts a person's life. If you can't control your use, and begin to spend more time participating in drug seeking activities, and lose touch with what is important to you (job, family, self-care) then you have a substance misuse issue. An avid opioid user cares for nothing other than their drug, and the thought of getting and using their drug is what fills their thoughts every waking minute of their day. People who use heroin or other opioids are likely to spend a great deal of money to fuel their habit. They are likely to commit crimes and ultimately put their lives at risk of death. Heroin and other opioid pills are what killed nearly 40,000 people in 2014 due to overdose. 

The Kratom community appears to be a very different population of people. We see a lot of people talking about wanting a quality life back, and seeking to be active in their communities, families, and their personal pursuits. We see people who have taken the reigns of health back in order to deal with a great many symptoms that may have prohibited their former quality of life. They are unwilling to accept that powerful narcotics are the only answer, and that difference in thinking is incredibly important. People who use a plant to engage and participate in life in a functional and positive way are not the people taking great risks with their health. This is a dramatic difference in lifestyle choices and overall outlook towards life and life's possibilities.

I want to close by reiterating that the typical person who uses Kratom is someone with a family, job, education, a desire for quality of life, and goals for their future. Someone trapped in addiction is typically silent in their struggle, disconnected, hopeless, and even suicidal. The question that must be asked is what does the Kratom community appear to be like to you? When you see the efforts being made by hundreds of thousands of people fighting for Kratom, does it resemble strung out behavior? The answer is "No" it doesn't, because they are two very separate populations and only one of them needs any help.

documents.commentText:
My name is Brian Baumgardner, I'm a 47-year old graphic designer and photographer from Dayton, Ohio. The following statements represent my opinions on kratom prohibition. 
I first learned about kratom 8 years ago through an online pain management support group as I was dealing with severe pain from a growth in my sinus cavity. Kratom helped me deal with the pain both pre- and post-operative without the need for dangerous prescription narcotics.
Since then, I have occasionally used kratom to help with pain and seasonal depression. This herb makes it possible for me to avoid pharmaceuticals and their negative side effects.
Aside from pain and depression, kratom has other proven beneficial uses not the least of which is reducing withdrawal symptoms for those trying to quit using opiates and other addictive drugs. With the current opiate issues affecting this country, this might be one of the most important benefits of this plant.
With decades of prohibition as our countrys main weapon in the drug war, I think its safe to say it has failed. Drug problems are only getting worse. In May 2016 Alabama banned kratom without public comment. Since then, in Jefferson County alone, deaths from accidental overdose on prescription opiates and heroin have doubled. By April 2016 they saw 47 deaths, as of June 2016 there were 103 deaths attributed to opiates and heroin. http://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2016/07/jeffco_sees_25_heroin_fentanyl.html
Kratom remained legal in every state that allowed public comment. After careful research in Florida, kratom remains completely unrestricted. The Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) released a December 2015 report titled Kratom - Mitragyna Speciosa, The Impact to Florida and found, Kratom does not currently constitute a significant risk to the safety and welfare of Florida residents. Additionally the report sites that the Florida Department of Health found there are no pervasive health issues which can be attributed to the ingestion of Kratom products in Florida. http://speciosa.org/official-statewide-intelligence-drug-report-kratom-and-the-impact-to-florida/ 
Unlike prescription opiates and heroin, kratom does not cause respiratory suppression. This is why I am so confident that not I, nor anyone else will die from drinking kratom by itself.
The DEA reasons that the 660 calls regarding kratom to US Poison Control justifies prohibiting the herb. In the same 6 years, there were 23,203 calls regarding caffeine, 66,300 calls about essential oils and 1,499 reports about Valerian root. By DEA reasoning these substances pose a far greater risk than kratom, yet I think it is safe to assume nearly everyone in the DEA and our government uses at least one of those. 
While kratom may have some opiate-like effects, it is not an opiate, nor is it a synthetic substance like bath salts as some states have classified it. Kratom has limited, if any recreational value. I never considered my cup of kratom tea a drug any more than I consider a cup of coffee a drug simply because I dont get high off of either one. If kratom had any recreational merit it would be much more popular than it is, after all it has been available here for over 20 years. If it didnt have medicinal properties, I wouldnt use it. 
Aside from causing many Americans to suffer and even die, kratom prohibition would also put thousands of hardworking small business owners and their employees out of work. As a mature, educated adult I feel this would be careless and irresponsible. Kratom should remain unrestricted in the same way as Caffeine, essential oils and Valerian root.
Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
Kratom has incredible medical potential, and classifying it as schedule 1 would restrict much-needed research on this plant.

Kratom contains an assortment of alkaloids, some of which act upon the opiate receptors. It therefore does have a potential for abuse and addiction. However the side effects of the opiates contained in kratom are much less than those from poppy based synthetic opiates, and there is substantial scientific research supporting this claim. 

Kratom also has other alkaloids that counteract the addictive and opiate agonistic properties of it's psychoactive opiates. This is known but poorly understood, more research is needed here. Because of this potential self-limiting property, this could be used for long term pain relief with more success than poppy based opiates. 

Poppy based opiates are also not useful for depression because of the addictive nature of them, and that tolerance builds quickly and it can "dull" the user and prevent them from driving / working. Kratom does not have such an intoxicating effect and something about it makes it much easier to focus and respond to ones' environment vs. poppy-based opiates. There is a huge need for opiate based antidepressants for some who have combined symptoms of ADHD, anxiety, and depression, and a drug based on Kratom could be wildly successful. 

Personally I believe that adults should have the freedom to make their own choice on what they put in their body, unless it is a substance that threatens their life or the lives of others (heroin, amphetamines). However, kratom is pouring in and we don't know where these leaves have been, if there is bacteria on them (kratom can and does cause digestive issues and I know from personal experience) - we don't know if the vendors are spiking it with synthetic opiates or what. It needs to be regulated the same as any other herbal supplement. If I go to my local supermarket I can be assured that at least some health code standards and regulations went to ensure that I'm not going to get some weird stuff in whatever supplement I buy - kratom should be no different.

It should also not be promoted in smoke shops as a "legal high" because that's silly - it should be used for a medical purpose only - not by high school kids wanting to get a buzz. I'm 100% in agreement with a minimum age of 18 or even 21 for kratom purchase. 

Kratom is a serious substance, it has the potential to so much good if we can research it and decode it. I can only think that a process to extract it's alkaloids and create a drug out of it could be hugely successful and beneficial to society in that they have a far lower side effect to benefit ratio than other opiates on the market. I don't think there is a "big pharma" conspiracy - in fact I'd rather the regulatory agencies stepped in and made sure this plant is tightly regulated and not distributed to minors but available to adults who prefer this to antidepressants and traditional pain medication. 

I don't think prescription should be required to purchase kratom or any drugs based on it - but that would be better than banning it outright. SOME cost effective solution needs to be in place for the millions (yes millions) of people who are currently using this plant and benefit from it. It saves people from far more dangerous opiates, and helps people with chronic pain live their lives better. 

I personally would definitely pay more for a drug where a company did the research on which alkaloids are good and which are bad, isolated the alkaloids that are beneficial and limit the side effects (some alkaloids I believe create some of the side effects), and provided me a drug based on kratom where I didn't have to digest as much plant matter (digestive issues are the #1 side effect by far despite all the misinformation). A little bit of research and pharmaceutical technology has the chance to harness the power of this plant to create a solution for so many people.

However - the plant itself should be legal to purchase because it's very cheap and some people probably can't afford the derivative drugs, and it honestly poses very little safety threat when used responsibly (15 deaths but none from Kratom alone). So ramp up the research, ramp up the regulation, but by God don't ban something with so much potential.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern,

    I'd like to add my voice to the many opposing the classification of kratom as a Schedule One drug. 
    My name is Sadie Gardner, and I am a 22 year old nursing student living in Vancouver, WA. I work full time as as caretaker for an 83 year old woman who has severe dementia and needs 24 hour care. 
    I first heard about kratom through several friends who were enrolled in a massage therapy course with me. Two of my fellow classmates had been on vicodin for several years and both had been able to replace that habit with the use of kratom. They recommended I try it one day when i was having some menstrual cramps, and I went out to a local store and purchased some. 

    I found a very small amount of kratom (I don't have amount scale but about 1tsp, so maybe 1/2 gram?) an effective painkiller that didn't prevent me from doing homework or other daily activities. I still use kratom about once every other month, in equally small amounts, when I'm having similar issues- it worked well for me as a mood stabilizer once when I was switching from hormonal birth control, and I used it a few days in a row once when my caregivering client wasn't sleeping and I needed to stay awake. I've found it helpful where ibuprofen fails, I've never gotten any kind of high whatsoever, and I've never had any feeling of addiction to the substance. 

    I do not think kratom should be a Class One drug, as I've experienced it's medical value for myself. HOWEVER, I have read about people using "extracts," or concentrated forms of kratom, and becoming addicted. I have never tried this form of kratom, but from what I've read online of people's personal experiences, it is when people start using concentrated extracts that they tend to become addicted. I don't think it necessary to use kratom in such large amounts to reap its benefits, and perhaps it would be less controversial to prevent kratom addiction and kratom use recreationally by outlawing only this larger scale use of the drug. My understanding is that it would not be practical to consume the amount of kratom contained in an extract through any other method. 

    In conclusion, I have experienced the indisputable medical value of kratom. While the amount consumed should perhaps be limited, and while there needs to be some larger scale research conducted, I do not believe making kratom a Schedule 1 drug is the answer.  

Thank you for your consideration,

Sadie Gardner

After increasing to 15mg oxycontin every 6 hours, my spouse noticed I would stop breathing at night. Sleep study confirmed apnea. After research, I discovered kratom. Within 6 months, under my rheumatologist supervision, I was off pain meds. My liver function is normal, kidney function is better, pain is manageable, and the apnea is gone. Please, don't schedule kratom, I don't want to die. It has saved my life!

documents.commentText:
Salutations

I want you to know, before you schedule it into an unavailable obscurity, how Kratom saved my life.

I am currently preoccupied primarily with the decriminalization of cannabis. That being said, I have been prescribed, and take regularly, high doses of a neuroleptic (Zyprexa) for nearly the past decade, as well as a heavy dose of amphetamines. Over that same time I have been on several classes of antidepressants and virtually every benzodiazepin available, occasionally at alarming doses (including alprazolam, diazepam, clonazepam and lorazopam which, combined, I contribute to about a year of my life being completely unrecallable). My medications have messed me up in ways I would never have thought possible. I've experienced a short but severe bout of dyskinesia several years ago, and currently am suffering from intolerable akathisia which I can only describe as torture from within.

At some point in my life about eight or nine years ago, I could no longer cope with my life in the most proverbial sense, nor accept the hurt I've caused those I love, and started using virtually any legal (in some cases, grey-area) psychoactives I could find. The bulk of my discoveries were online; mostly information, knowledge and products. 

I'd been aware of my susceptibility to opiates/opioids for a while by this point in my life, notably due to prescriptions for kidney stones. I came across Kratom for the first time sometime during the summer of 2005, thanks to Daniel Siebert, and my first experiences with this plant occurred not long thereafter. However my attention was eventually concentrated on dried opium poppy pods which I obtained from eBay. My use of the poppy pods quickly led to a life addicted to opiates, and within a year I was injecting or insufflating heroin and OxyContin. I place the majority of the blame for this addiction happening to me on myself, but I am not entirely at fault. I was already messed up psychologically and if anyone had even mentioned what these medications could eventually do to me and my mind, I would have told my doctors at the time to shove these pills right up their ass. Nevertheless, there I was: an already messed up, vulnerable personality on some crazy medications, now adjunct with an addiction to opiates.

For nearly five years that was he extent of my existence. Finally, around 2010, I was fired from my job and was watched very closely by my parents during this time (my parents also kept a close eye on my bank accounts). I had no desire nor plans to stop using opiates, but due to circumstances I had no choice.

The next months were excruciating. I couldn't fall asleep for more than a couple hours at a time yet I never got out of bed. I do not think I need to elaborate further on the specifics of heroin withdrawal. By this time, opium poppies had become difficult to obtain online; eBay pulled all pods off their site and I was not aware of any other reliable sources to acquire them. Desperate for relief, I turned to Kratom. I had only experimented with Kratom a few times and was not optimistic about it curbing my withdrawal symptoms. I could not have further understatement the medicinal power of this plant.

I used Kratom about four or five times a day, roughly 5-10 g of powdered dry leaf per dose (more or less, depending upon the source). Kratom not only made it possible to tolerate opiate withdrawals, Kratom made it easy. I have honestly never even considered using opiates since the first day I started using Kratom medicinally. After roughly five months of using Kratom, I decided on a whim to stop using it and noticed yet another amazing aspect of this plant: it has virtually no withdrawal effects of its own.

Kratom took someone who had no desire, at all, to stop using opiates and allowed me to quit heroin cold turkey, and remain opiate-free for over six years (and counting). I know heroin is a national problem - nearly an epidemic at this point. You need to look into this plant more closely before you ban it forever. You need to do what you can to stop kitchen chemists from cooking up analogies of mitragynine and 7-HMG then selling them as research chemicals. This plant can save lives.

I understand that it is nearly certain Kratom will be criminalized. The DEA has a well documented history of having no tolerance for any psychoactive substance whatsoever, which are all eventually scheduled according to popularity and availability. I have learned to be OK with Kratom being illegal because my need for Kratom lies directly behind me, and I seriously doubt anyone could say anything to stop Kratom from being criminalized at this point. I just wish you would realize you cannot win this war on "drugs," which is really a war on drug users; meanwhile smugglers, traffickers and dealers make huge profits from sick people like me because of your fear and ignorance of a plant you can't fully understand.

I have so much more to say, but I've reached the 5000 character limit.

documents.commentText:
I suffered a catastrophic back injury in 2010. After multiple surgeries, I ended up physically dependent on hydrocodone. I decided to quit taking the drug, despite the fact that my pain levels would justify its use. I don't want to take anything that I can't stop taking without severely adverse consequences. I am now almost a year from my last dose. The crushing anxiety coupled with the pain had made returning to using hydrocodone a daily temptation.

Kratom came to my attention via a pain management support group. I take 1.5 teaspoons of it per day and it takes away the anxiety, reduces the pain significantly, and caused me to stop thinking about the pills. It does not provide me with feelings of euphoria, so my head is clear and I can function normally. I don't have to increase the dose every six months. I don't have to go to the doctor every month. I don't have to carry the stigma of being physically dependent on opiate pain medications.

When I saw the DEA was classifying Kratom as schedule 1, I decided to stop taking it. The following day, I felt no ill effects from discontinuing use. Thus, I know it is going to make physically dependent, and the lack of euphoria doesn't make it a good candidate for addiction. 

Taking this action because people have died abusing the product is well intentioned, but misguided. People die from taking too much tylenol. People die from alcohol consumption. People who are prone to abuse and bad decisions are going to find a way to hurt themselves with any product, so taking this line really means you should also consider pulling tylenol off the shelves.

The perception in the community is that the DEA is only protecting the rights of big pharma with this action. I am not a conspiracy minded person, so I don't think there is a dark room with unaccountable powers making rules to benefit a few wealthy individuals, but I can see where this line of thinking originates when actions like this one are proposed.

In summary, I ask the DEA to avoid any classification stricter than Ginseng or St John's Wort. This is an effective treatment for pain and anxiety and the vast majority of consumers cause no harm to themselves or others while using it. If you give it a legitimate standing, then supplement companies can package it in reasonable doses and ensure quality. The current approach leads to product tampering, which has been a contributor to several of the reported deaths. 

Thank you for listening.

documents.commentText:
I understand that Kratom use is controversial. Many people think of Kratom users as "just another drug addict." I strongly disagree with this view. I was only 19 years old when I was diagnosed with spinal cord cancer. 
After surgery I recovered quickly and felt back to normal. About 18 months after the surgery I began experiencing chronic pain. This pain worsened as time progressed. 
I was unable to sit in a classroom for more than 30 minutes at a time, unable to play any sports, and I eventually was in so much pain that I could not walk over a mile at a time
without experiencing agony. I sought treatment and was sent to a pain clinic. It is an understatement to say that the American medical system failed me in my time of need.
Most of the pain doctors offered me pills, they tried me on six different muscle relaxers (one at a time), none of which helped even the slightest. They tried me on all sorts of anti-depressants and 
anti-convulsants. Nothing helped. I was sent to physical therapy and pain psychology. Physical therapy helped me get my range of motion back and helped me in the long run, But I needed something to help me live through
the next day. I quickly saw my pain medication triple in quantity, at the age of 22 I was up to 30mg of oxycodone a day. I refused to go any higher with it, because it was only making the pain worse. 
I had no social life, I began experiencing trouble in school, I could not work longer than 3-4 hours at a time, and I was depressed and suffered from extreme anxiety. I finally found a great physician who helped
me find what the underlying problem was. I was treated for ADHD and central pain syndrome. My symptoms drastically improved and my pain medication was cut down to 15mg of oxycodone per day.
I was not completely satisfied. At the age of 22 I want to be off of pain meds and living a normal life. I found out about kratom after I experienced the worst pain of my life for a week straight,
I was unable to sleep more than 2 hours each night of the week and pain meds were not doing anything. I have been taking kratom for 5 months now and my pain medication dose has gone from 15mg of oxycodone per day
down to no pain meds needed each day. That's right, I have weaned off of my dose and only need to take a pain med once a week or maybe less than that! 
I have a social life, I play softball, I am married, and I am about to pass my last CPA exam. I also work 30 hours per week while attending 3 graduate level accounting classes per week. I graduated at the top of my 
class for my undergraduate degree and I owe a lot of this to kratom. I have become a productive member of society and I do not want this to change. I am finally happy with
my health and my overall well-being. There is no longer the thought in my mind of "how much pain will I be in tomorrow?" 
I support the use and research of kratom and believe that the DEA would be acting too hastily if it were to be banned. Research is needed! Please
do not let the actions of a few irresponsible kratom users make your impression of kratom to be negative.

documents.commentText:
To Whom This May Concern,

My name is Michelle Thomas and I am 40 years old. I have 4 amazing children ages 10, 11, 20, and 22.  When I was three years old I was diagnosed with Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis. This disease destroyed every joint in my body. I struggled with this through my entire life, the pain I was in, the treatments they tried, but in the end, the damage continued to get worse.

I grew up taking NSAIDs, muscle relaxers, valium, Vicodin (it was called that then), and a huge variety of arthritis medication that didnt seem to help or the side effects were so severe that I had no choice but to stop taking them.

As the years went on, the pain finally started to reduce. However, within a couple of years, I was in a bad vehicle accident and was rear ended at a dead stop with the man behind me travelling at about 60mph. He didnt even touch his brakes.  It was then, that April day in 2001 that has changed my adulthood to what it is today.

Within a few days of the accident, I was in the hospital with bad joint pain in my hips, neck pain, shoulder pain and more. Over time, the symptoms became more severe and I was diagnosed with Thoracic Outlet Syndrome, I have pinched nerves in my lower back, left elbow, and neck, I have facets disease of my spine, arthritis, depression and more.

Obviously going from a somewhat healthy woman in her 20s I became a woman that relied on pain medication to make it through the day just to have some kind of quality of life. I went through months of physical therapy, but ultimately in the end, it got to the point where pain medication wasnt working like it had previously, my body and joints had more damage that wouldnt reverse, and when I was 22 years old, I had to have my left hip replaced. 1  years later, I had the right one done. I have had to have my right shoulder replaced already. I had to have surgery on my left shoulder so I could get movement back in it. 

I have lived the last 18 years on pain medicine, mainly Vicodin/Norco, muscle relaxers, etc. I have also struggled with depression for as long as I can remember because of my quality of life or lack thereof, as well as the constant struggle of dealing with pain from the moment I woke up until I fell asleep at night.

I just recently discovered Kratom from a friend who takes it and has for a while.  I cannot believe the difference that Kratom has made in my life.  I have lived in a drug induced fog for almost 18 years, never really even knowing I was in that fog, until I began taking Kratom.  I was able to replace Kratom entirely and instead of being and living in a pain filled foggy state of mind, I was shocked to see how clear headed this made me.  I have my Marijuana Medical card, but dont care for taking/smoking it because I dont care for the High that you  receive from this legal drug, but Kratom gives me that release from pain, from depression, that I never thought was possible in my life.  I just recently went through a divorce and I cried for weeks and the first time I tried Kratom, the tears were gone. Its like it took away my pain, it lessened my depression, and made me think clearly to the point of where I could begin the healing process after this life changing event.  I was taking 5-8 Norcos a day, 3 muscle relaxers every day, Valium, antidepressants and more. While I still take the antidepressants, I feel pretty confident that I could wean myself off of them as I continue to take Kratom.  Kratom actually reduces my pain to a manageable level now so that if I have to go to the store, I dont get panic attacks because those trips always wound up with me being in pain, crying by the time I got home. My life has changed dramatically in the past 5 weeks since discovering Kratom and can honestly say that even my children see the difference. I feel I owe them a clear headed mom, one that isnt afraid to go grocery shopping, or to the mall.  I just want to enjoy my life because the first 40 years was nothing but pain and sadness with a life hooked completely reliant on pain medicine to get through my days. 
 
I feel like I am a completely different person. I am happy.  I am close to pain free and I dont have the bad thoughts I did have before Kratom.  I am finally the clear headed mom, my children deserve and I am so thankful to have this as an option.
Please dont make Kratom illegal.  I dont want to be the useless, foggy headed mom to my kids, or have no quality of life due to the pain I experience every day without this. I feel that my kids deserve this life!! Without Kratom today, I have no doubts, that I would still be crying, still wishing I wasnt around, still in horrifying pain, and in a fog stateso foggy I didnt even know I was in it until I took Kratom for the first time.

documents.commentText:
I am a 65-year-old woman who has never abused drugs or alcohol.
 
I have RSD, Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy, also called CRPS, Complex Regional Pain Syndrome. This means I have chronic, severe pain. This syndrome is not fully understood, but it is thought that excessive, abnormal neurological responses to trauma cause RSD/CRPS. In my case, it began after I broke a bone in my left leg and then developed a complication that required surgery.
 
This occurred in October 2013. Since leaving the hospital in December 2013, I've taken a high dose of Lyrica daily for pain. I also took a high dose of Norco (acetaminophen/hydrocodone) daily for pain until April 2016.
 
During this time, I knew my brain was dulled. I knew I dragged around. I knew I could fall asleep anywhere, anytime. When I heard of kratom, by accident on a completely unrelated online board, I researched it. Finally I bought some. And finally, although I feared it at first, I tried some, after weaning myself off Norco.
 
I want to emphasize that neither Norco nor kratom has made me high or altered my mood in any way.
 
Kratom has been nothing less than a miracle. With every day on kratom, I realized just how messed up my brain had been on Norco. I also got my energy back (well, what energy I have at 65, with a permanent injury and wearing a leg brace ... ). I no longer slept through most of the day. I began to feel like myself again.
 
But the best part is how kratom helps with the pain. Every day I take 12.5 grams of kratom in capsule form. This lasts 24 hours and provides good, steady pain relief. By no means does it make my pain go away. But it significantly diminishes it.
 
Norco, on the other hand, provided roller-coaster pain relief. I would take a pill and feel better for a couple of hours, until the pain gradually increased in intensity. Then it was, take another pill, feel better, have the pain increase, take a pill, feel better, have the pain increase, and so on....
 
I cannot tell you how very important it is to me to keep kratom legal. It has been used for centuries in other parts of the world. I understand it has not been through our Western system of double-blind testing followed by federal approval. But it works.
 
I dread having to go back on any type of opioid for my pain. Please, keep kratom legal.
