documents.commentText:
I am a fifty-one year old American male living in downtown Dayton, Ohio. I have not been able to work since 2001, due to a partial colon resection and the ensuing medical problems. Essentially I was in and out of the hospital or on my father's couch from 2001-2004. In 1983 I was admitted to Miami Valley Hospital for depression. Since then I have been on psychiatric medication, remained melancholy, and the depression deepened with all of my intestinal issues at the beginning of this century.

In 2013 I realized the pain medication was problematic, specifically when I did not have it; it also didn't have the same impact when I took it, having built up a tolerance. An old friend introduced me to Kratom as we drank tea in my section eight apartment, and we discussed my prospects, or lack of prospects. 

I thoroughly researched Kratom and the active ingredients in the plant, and decided I'd purchase some and it afforded me the opportunity to ween myself off painkillers, and it also imroved my frame of mind, my mental health. I noticed my complexion improved, my eyes weren't as bleary, and I began concentrating again: reading, walking when possible, making contact with old friends again.

Unfortunately, in August of this year (2016) my back and hip and right buttock began hurting, and I eventually could not get out of a chair. After several emergency rooms and catscans and an MRI and doctor's appointments and epidural injections and physical therapy I was diagnosed with Neuro farimal stenosis, sciatica, a pinched nerve, and constricted L5 spine. Several medications were provided to help with the pain and numbness and inability to move or be mobile, and I am now scheduled to see a neurologist and pain management specialist, this action precluding more visits to the hospital and my family doctor, hopefully. 

Kratom allowed me to greatly reduce my intake of Flexeril, Oxycodone, Roboxin, Lyrica, Neurontin, Ibuprofen, Ondansetron, Metamucil, and stool softener. I am in a better physical mental and physical state now, my head is clearer, and the pain is manageable, and I finally feel distance from the weeks where I couldn't lay down on a bed, or walk more than a few feet without debilitating pain, or was compelled to call an ambulance twice in twelve hours and be transported to the Miami Valley hospital emergency room.

Structure is crucial to my well-being, and Kratom is part of my daily regimen. In essence, I have benefitted from the Kratom tea in different ways, and the benefits have manifested themselves in stable and hopeful thinking, and a gradual diminuition of pain. It's part of my lifestyle, like Metamucil, walking whenever possible, continuing to see my array of doctors and specialists. 

I don't understand why Kratom is in the process of being scheduled as a drug, and in such a way that I won't have access to it. It's critical to my physical and mental health. There is no intoxication, it doesn't affect my driving (rare), it doesn't have side effects--it seems as natural as caffeinated tea or coffee to me. It is very important for my well being that I have access to Kratom, which I would rather utilize than a vast array of medications that muddy my brain and discombobulate my body as a whole.

Thank you for your time and I hope you consider my words, or my situation, or plight. 

Sincerely,

Timothy Fox

documents.commentText:
My name is Milo Bennett. I am currently a kratom user and oppose placement of kratom on the Schedule 1 list or any legislation that would prevent kratom being sold as a dietary supplement.

I first used kratom in 2014 when looking at different supplements for back pain stemming from a lingering injury. I found information on kratom and the additional effects of relieving anxiety and having a calming effect also sounded appealing. I conducted research on online vendors to find the most reputable ones. I also researched responsible use of kratom as a dietary supplement and made my first purchase in the Spring of 2014.

My research paid off as I consider the dietary supplement quality to be very good as well as the instructions on how to take kratom. My goal was simply to see the effect on back pain and my mood that kratom would have.

I work in mental healthcare which can be mentally draining and results in social burnout. I interact with patients with persistent mental illness on a daily basis for my job. Kratom not only helped my quality of life and job performance by reducing back pain as my injury healed but it also improved my general mood as well, resulting in better time away from work to rejuvenate myself mentally. Kratom is valuable to those struggling with social anxiety.

I have used kratom off and on in the last couple years, finding no adverse side effects from use or quitting use of kratom. I have gone from once a day use to quitting completely with no issues.

Please consider this testimonial during your evaluation of kratom as a valuable dietary supplement. It is not merely a recreational substance but a dietary supplement that improves the quality of life for the average citizen.

documents.commentText:
After a gallbladder removal surgery in 2007, I was left very sick for over 5 years. Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea daily. I fell into a deep depression, having lost contact with most of my friends and family. I was having suicidal thoughts daily.  My public anxiety was through the roof, and my depression was rock bottom. These were dark times.

My girlfriend, now wife, at the time forced me to go see a doctor, despite not having insurance or the funds to afford it. I was prescribed the anti-depressant, Prozac. I lasted 2 weeks on that horrific drug, as it caused me to shake violently and literally go crazy. A horrible experience.

I was then prescribed amitriptyline, which in low doses can also help with calming gut issues. It didn't do anything for me at all, it was like a failed placebo that I wasted 6 months of my life on.

Next up, Alprazolam or Xanax. Xanax took away the anxiety, but made me so tired that I couldn't function in day to day life. We own our own business and not being able to converse with my customers wasn't practical or helping me at all. I stopped taking it as it was worthless.

Fast forward to 2013 and I come across the word "Kratom" on a depression forum I would frequent often. Some people claimed how it really helped them, how it was nothing more than a dried and powdered plant that you can make a tea with. I figured I had nothing left to do, and being now thousands of dollars in medical tests from numerous tests, I had no funds left to really continue that route. 

So I ordered some kratom. I made a tea. Didn't really 'feel' much from it, maybe a bit more relaxed, but nothing else. Next day, had another tea. Same thing. The next day, same thing. After about a week or so, I suddenly realized: "I haven't thought about killing myself all week for the first time in YEARS!" I still had stomach issues, but I felt like I could actually deal with them without the weight of my mind holding me back.

That's when I knew what a miracle kratom can be. All of the emphasis that is put on drug addicts and people trying to get high is nothing but a slander tactic. You want to get high on kratom? Good luck. You will get the worst stomach ache of your life. 

This plant helps thousands. And without it, the DEA would be forcing us back into a life of failed pharmaceuticals and doctors who would rather run tests than see their patients back on their feet.

Please, do the right thing. Keep kratom legal. If you want to regulate and help ensure that the products offered are safe and grown appropriately, I support that. Kratom is NOT a party drug and shouldn't be sold as such. It is a supplement in the purest form of the word.

Thank you for reading.

documents.commentText:
he DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works... 
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies. 
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes... 
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.

documents.commentText:
Kratom has significantly changed my life. I've struggled with chronic pain since my early 20's, after a car accident in 2005 resulted in a titanium plate being installed in my leg. While prescribed oxycontin, I was unable to function, and almost failed out of college. Long term over-the-counter painkillers like IB profen lead to a deterioration in my stomach lining, something I found out after a colonoscopy at the relatively young age of 31 to find a solution to crippling stomach aches.

Kratom not only with helped my pain, but lessens my anxiety. An unexpected side benefit: I lost weight, as I felt well enough to exercise, and drank far less alcohol than before starting kratom. Before kratom I dreaded the future, wondering how I could manage pain that will only increase with time. I accept I'll always have a certain amount of pain, but with kratom, I'm able to be functional, hold a job (my profession requires me to be on my feet in the kitchen), plus more meaningful relationships with my friends & family, as I'm not on edge from pain and anxiety & can go out socially more. My husband has commented on my general mood & demeanor improving.

I appreciate this comment period being allowed. I don't understand why kratom, a solution to the opiate epidemic, is in consideration to join the same category as heroin. It's not a respiratory depressant, unlike opiates & any alleged kratom overdoses have always been found to have other chemicals present. There's been 4x more calls regarding dishwasher soap pods than kratom, yet those are unrestricted; what's the real threat?  Regulation isn't unreasonable, but to regulate it into inaccessibility is unnecessary, & doesn't make sense for a non-medical entity to decide.

There's currently much research going on in regard to myriad different medical uses, moving kratom to a schedule 1 substance would not only shut down this valuable research, but would make further, new studies difficult to begin. It's impossible to substantiate the claims that are being made by the DEA, especially since they recently refused to turn over any evidence in a Freedom of Information Act. Perhaps they did not want to be shamed at lack of legitimate reason to make this herbal supplement, a simple plant leaf, into a felony. America already has the highest rate of incarceration, making kratom schedule 1 would add to that, as anyone who's experienced the pain relief of kratom is unlikely to accept going back to a life of constant pain. Kratom is a harm reduction method that could save lives in the form of overdoses, the medical complications that result from long term alcohol/drug abuse, and aid in the recovery for those who are looking to better their lives. That's at least what Florida found out when they launched a special investigation into kratom recently.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir or Madam:

I am writing you regarding an issue very close to my heart.  This is in regards to the DEAs Notice of Intent to Schedules of Controlled Substances: Temporary Placement of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine Into Schedule I, essentially banning a harmless herb, which has helped many individuals to alleviate their own personal physical pain, including our men and women in service and that have served who cannot find relief for their daily physical pain (or choose not to) through conventional narcotic pain medication, would only increase the prison population greater or lead to these people to choose a path they dont want: that of using prescription painkillers. 

It can also help with withdrawal symptoms from prescription opioid drugs and street narcotics, which we are seeing an epidemic of in our country. It is my opinion that the DEA is exceeding its authority to place a plant used by hundreds of thousands of law abiding citizens on the list of Schedule I drugs, which would turn them into immediate criminals - risking extensive jail time due to mandatory minimums, removing their right to vote, and severely impairing the ability to get a job once they are freed, amongst all the other negative consequences.  As Im sure you are well aware, the US has the highest prison population in the world, with over 50% of the inmates in federal prison being non-violent drug offenders.  It is absolutely absurd for the DEA to add a plant, which has been used as a tea for thousands of years by East Asia to their scheduling list.  According to medical literature, not a single death has been caused by kratom (without the individual being a polydrug cocktail that included kratom). [1]  

The DEA says that kratom has resulted in a total of 30 deaths in the US, and although that is a tragedy, prescription opioid medications alone have resulted in a whopping 28,000 deaths from heroin and prescription painkillers in 2014.  Right now, there is a huge crisis of deaths from opioid abuse in this country that could be helped greatly by leaving kratom available and in the hands of consumers.  Kratom, being a natural plant, should be regulated by the FDA under the DSHEA as a dietary supplement, as it meets that exact criteria.  If there is concern about its misuse, it should be restricted to adults age 18 or 21 to purchase.  Unfortunately, because of all the yellow journalism and smears in the mainstream media, kratom has been lumped together with drugs that should have and have been properly banned.

Recently, the state of Florida had proposed to ban kratom earlier this year, but after testimony and an examination of common sense medical information, Florida came to the conclusion:

a review of information currently available through identified law enforcement and laboratory sources in Florida indicates that Kratom does not constitute a significant risk to the safety or welfare of Florida residents. The Florida Department of Health (DOH) reports no pervasive health issues attributed to the ingestion of Kratom products in Florida. [2]

I myself am a daily kratom user, drinking it in the form of a tea to help alleviate the excruciating pain brought upon by my irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD).  Banning this substance would negatively affect my quality of life to intolerable degree, of which I have found no prescription medication or treatment to be as effective as kratom.

I believe God gave us this miracle pain relieving plant, to use for the benefit of all mankind, as he said in Genesis 1:29-30

Then God said, "Behold, I have given you every plant yielding seed that is on the surface of all the earth, and every tree which has fruit yielding seed; it shall be food for you; and to every beast of the earth and to every bird of the sky and to everything that moves on the earth which has life, I have given every green plant for food"; and it was so.

I view the fact that this plant was just recently brought to the west from across the great oceans as a sign from God that it is intended to help the people of this nation, to help our opioid epidemic, which is taking the lives of so many of our young people today.

I am not the only one who will be impacted by this insane ban.  Just search the hashtag #IamKratom on Youtube, Twitter or Facebook and listen to the stories of people who have been helped tremendously -- many have had their lives saved -- by this simple plant, a tea, that the DEA wants to take away from us for no just cause.

I appreciate the DEA listening to us, the kratom users, and giving us the opportunity to have a public comment period for kratom. These are my thoughts, facts and opinion on the matter.  I hope you will make the right decision and leave kratom as a dietary supplement.

Sincerely,
Jonathan Grose

documents.commentText:
My name is Angela Carnazzo and I'm 53 years old. I'm mother to an 18 year old son. And  I beseech you not you put Kratom on the list of schedule 1 substances for both of our sakes.

 I'm on disability mainly because I have been diagnosed with Bipolar 1 disorder with ultra rapid cycling. I can cycle two to three times a day or just remain hypomanic for weeks. With the hypomania I can be depressed enough to want to die and at the same time be manic enough to act on it.  I take medication now but it's never been very effective.  For decades before i was diagnosed I would just self medicate for whatever way I was feeling. They say people with Bipolar have a high risk for substance abuse. I'm certainly testament to that.

I also inherited osteoarthritis from my mother's side of the family.  I've had both of my hips replaced and one of them is ready to be replaced again.  All five sections of my spine are effected so I can look forward to deformities as I age.  The pain can be unbearable. 

I used to live on the strongest opiates available. Antipsychotics, antidepressants, Librium. I just floated through life and I don't remember most of the important milestones in my son's life.

Two years ago a friend told me about kratom. She said it might help my pain and she gave me enough for a few doses. It sat on my kitchen counter for at least a month. Then one day as I was about to take a handful of oxycodone I looked at myself in the mirror and was appalled at what looked back at me. I was mortified and disgusted and filled with self hatred. How had I become this recepticle for pills. Pills that didn't even really help the pain and the depression anymore. I became completely manic and went through all cabinets and collected every pill in the house and threw them down the garbage disposal. I couldn't go on like that. It wasn't living. I don't know what you'd call it but I didn't want to do it anymore.  Well I pretty much changed that tune as the withdrawal started to set in. Where was all of that righteousness then? I was terrified, I was sick it was horrible. And the pain. I had never felt pain that bad. I honestly thought I was going to die.

That's when I remembered the kratom on the counter. I was desperate. I thought I remembered she said to make it into a tea. So I made some. It didn't take long at all. The withdrawal symptoms eased tremendously and my pain diminished. I honestly couldn't believe this terrible tasting tea did all of this. I called my girlfriend and laughed and said how long have you wanted to give this to me. A few years she said. I always thought no one knew how high I was. Yeah. My depression minimized greatly as well.

So that's my story. It's not over. There isn't a cure for bipolar and ostioarthritis is a degenerative disease. But kratom has given me my life back.

I don't ever want to be that shell of a person again. Never, but that is what will happen to me if Kratom is put on the list of schedule 1 drugs.

So again, I beseech you. Please let me have a life that's worth living. Don't deny kratom to the people who need it.


Angela Carnazzo

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing to submit my thoughts with regards to Kratom; specifically, placing, the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, two constituents of the kratom plant, on the schedule 1 controlled substances list.

I am in my mid 50s and until a few years ago, was a professional in the world of the non-profit sector.  Due to chronic pain, I began and still continue, to research alternative treatments and lifestyle choices, in hopes of maintaining a quality of life. This research, led me to Kratom and I spent hours learning about the leaf, its properties, strains, and testimonials of many people, who shared their stories with regards to the better lives they had, with the help of Kratom. 

I can attest to the fact, I found Kratom to be a very complimentery tea, to my lifestyle regiment. I never experienced any "high" or "withdrawal" from Kratom. My budget does not allow for a constant purchase of Kratom; however, a few months ago, I had decided to start making room for it on a permanent basis, in the budget, in order, to hopefully, no longer use or lessen the use of opioid medication. I do have concerns of what long term use of ANY pharmaceutical medication has on an individual's body. However, with the DEA's intentions of Schedule I placing, I could no longer take the route, I had intended because if I had replaced a medication with Kratom and then, no longer, been able to obtain it, with the current climate regarding prescription opioids, I was concerned I would not be able to obtain the medication.

I have read so many, testimonials of not only, chronic pain patients, who have been helped by Kratom, but the stories of those, who have been able to leave the world of "addiction" behind them and once again, be productive tax paying, law abiding, family involved persons! It is astonishing and to know, Kratom does not repress the respitory system, making death via overdose non exsisitent! Please, do not make Kratom unavailable to the many people and families that, it has been such a valuable asset in, regardless of whether chronic pain or addiction, given them a Quality of LIfe!

Sincerely,

Kathy Hastings

Kratom was introduced to me by a good friend of mine who has suffered from chronic pain for 15+ years. She has neuropathy in her left leg. I myself struggle with back pain and Kratom is an excellent remedy for me on days where the painful sensations are so distracting and exhausting that I have trouble completing the tasks that are required of me.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

As a medical and pharmacology-student, I have often recommended Kratom to patients (outside of the workplace) as it relieves their pain in a way many Schedule II and III drugs are unable to do so. Due to its availability over the counter, I recommend that they try this perfectly legal herbal supplement. 

I have had many patients comment that the pain relief they receive from taking various Kratom leaf and tinctures is superior to that of high dose morphine or 75mcg/hr Fentanyl patches. I have had many reports of considerably less drowsiness and fatigue. I have also been told that nausea, a common side-effect of chemotherapy, is not a contributing factor.

This legal and over the counter substance has many, many great uses. Whether an individual takes small doses to assist with their GAD (Generalized Anxiety Disorder) or severe pain (due to cancer treatment) all I have heard is positive reviews. Truly the only negative review I have heard is that the taste is foul.

I believe that many patients will be harmed by scheduling this substance. This is not the same type of substance as "bath salts" that cause hallucinations and strange behavior. Kratom binds to similar sites in the brain that block pain and increase dopamine production; additionally, this herb is used by many native tribes across the glove and has been used for hundreds of years. Certain tribes of Native Americans/United States (First Nations/Canada) are permitted the used of Peyote and other hallucinogenic drugs.

Thus far, no evidence has been shown that Kratom has any carcinogenic effect nor does it harm the body. At the first worst, taking too much Kratom may induce nausea. 

Please head my warning that Kratom is a very useful substance that will not lead to some form of pandemic of addiction. The users and researches of Kratom that I know quite well and follow have not show nor found any of the typical behavior of a drug addict.

Finally, many individuals have used this substance in order to desist the use of harder and more dangerous drugs such as diamorphine (Heroin), Oxycodone (Oxycontin, Diludid (Hydromorphone), etc. To remove this avenue of recovery would only increase the usage of these substances while creating a whole new means of arresting and incarcerating individuals that merely wish to relieve their pain, anxiety, and addiction.

A study has shown that even Marijuana itself, now legal for recreational use in several States within the U.S.A., is more addictive.

Please contact me at 505-514-0062. I am able to provide considerably more information on this substance. It would truly be a crime in itself to schedule this substance as it does not fit any of the criteria of a Schedule I drug.

Additionally, as someone who has assisted professionally with disabled, infirm, and individuals otherwise unable to care for themselves, I believe I am in a position to provide accurate information. This is not a substance that 99% of the users ingest to get "high" from, the overwhelming majority are seeking relief from a mental or physiological ailment that they are otherwise unable to treat via stand medical care within this country.


E-mail Contact: KB3MGR@Gmail.com 

Phone #: 505-514-0062

(If calling from a non (202) area code, please make a second call)

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

Jameson Glenn Williams

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?
Sincerely,

documents.commentText: I'm a working professional with a Bachelor's degree in Advertising. When I was 12, I was put in the ER due to ovarian cysts bursting. Since then I have dealt with chronic pain due to cysts and endometriosis, which became so severe I was forced to start working part-time and only from home. I was prescribed Hydrocodone regularly for almost 3 years, which was the only thing I found would adequately help my pain, although I hated the side effects and "high" feeling it gave me. Recently, I had a laparoscopy to remove a large cyst and dealt with a rough recovery. After some research I decided to try kratom, which helped with my pain without giving me the "high" feeling of opiates I had been on prior. I also noticed that there were no noticeable side effects, unlike the Hydrocodone. After my discovery of kratom, I was able to stop taking Hydrocodone and all opiate pain medication completely. I have also been able to start working full-time again. Because of my (and others') experiences with kratom, I believe that its potential should be researched. This plant should definitely not be classified as a controlled substance.

In addition to my own experiences with this harmless plant, I have seen, first-hand, how Kratom has benefitted my wife's life. For the past year or so, since she began consuming Kratom tea, it seems as though my wife "came to life". Before Kratom, my wife rarely got out of bed or left the house, this made life difficult on me. Since my wife began Kratom she has gotten up every day and is helpful and productive at our business and in all aspects of our family life, this makes my life much easier. Kratom helps my wife be a better person, which creates a better environment, which creates more success for our family. My wife has never appeared to be "high" from ingesting Kratom, just a better version of herself. 

Kratom should NOT be banned. Kratom should be available to anyone who desires an afternoon nap or wants to live life better.

documents.commentText:
I have severe intractable back pain that appears to emanate primarily from the SI Joint, from where it also refers to the groin.  I am totally disabled by this pain, the resulting exhaustion and increasing effects of poor nutrition and inactivity, and drug side effects.  It is imperative that I keep the neurogenic pain flares to a minimum, because when they are up, I lie curled in a ball, wishing for death.  Flares like that occur a few times per week, and can last up to 8 hrs.  They are virtually guaranteed by activities like going in to town for any reason, or stooping to pick up after my dogs.  In order to survive long enough to find a cure (meaning that I survive the periods of literally preferring death to the pain I am feeling), I have to avoid flare ups as much as possibly by remaining immobile with my legs upon a large wedge pillow, on pain meds.  The pain med side effects are very unpleasant and take a toll on my strength and perseverance.

As as result of a failed sub dural steroid injection, I got numbness and tingling in my toes, and soon afterwards, in my fingers.  The only activity I have been able to engage in, immobilized and sickened as I am, has been crocheting simple items.  The neuropathy in my fingers was so exacerbated by crocheting that I had to quit, and it never improved very much after that, until I found Kratom.  Before Kratom, it had become almost impossible to type.  It is still very difficult and requires patiently erasing and re-typing almost every other word.  I drop things often, due to a lack of feeing in my finger tips.  For some reason, the Kratom seems to actually cure the neuropathy.  If I take the Kratom (5//8 Tsp, 2x per day) for two days in a row, with 4 days off in between, it keeps the neuropathy down enough that I can crochet for several hours per week - a much needed distraction from the fear and stress I feel about what will happen to me, if I can't become more active, very soon.  I have read that it can cause dependency in some, and since I have experienced the unpleasantness of slowly weaning from dependency on both Gabapentin and Effexor, I strive to avoid developing it, again.

Kratom also helps a lot with my pain.  It does cause side effects, but not any as bad as the narcotics I have been prescribed, and simply getting a half day off from the other side effects provides an important psychological break from the suffering.  Since they don't help enough with the pain, and cause horrible side effects, not to mention the resistance of doctors, normal narcotics (hydrocodone and norco make me very ill, morphine side effects are worse than the relief it provides is good, and Dilauded, though the pain relief is better, also makes me ill) I have settled on a mix of Tramadol, Gabapentin and Lyrica (at different times, alternated to avoid dependency), Diclofenac, and some herbals.  I would mention the herbs, but I am concerned that the overzealous bureaucrats in the pocket of big business would go after them, next.  (You should be ashamed.)  

Kratom is an important medication for pain sufferers to have access to.  I am sorry that our society produces so many psychologically suffering people that they seek relief in drug abuse; but responsible people should not suffer for that by losing access to useful drugs.  If you are so concerned about that problem, rather than denying the usefulness of herbal medications in order to remove them from shelves, you should focus on funding answers to the social ills producing addicts.  Denying that Kratom has medical uses is an obvious lie and point to some kind of institutional corruption.

documents.commentText:
I have no idea why the DEA would want to ban Kratom, a plant that has helped countless people get off of opiates, for several reasons:
1) Kratom is a plant, it is not a drug.  It does not have to be refined or enhanced in any way to make it effective.
2) An expansion to the already expensive "War on Drugs" is exactly what the United States doesn't need right now.
3) The opiate epidemic is absolutely out of control.  We lose a human being EVERY NINETEEN MINUTES to opiates.  We eradicated Polio, we can eradicate opiate addiction.
4) Big Pharma doesn't need more money.  They make plenty by selling dangerous chemicals to unwitting, uninformed consumers.
5) It has been proven that Kratom is an effective tool against opiate addiction, both acute and post-acute.

Please do not ban this miracle plant.  It's bad enough that we are locking people up for non-violent drug offenses.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

I can totally see why people turn to heroin after Pain Management doctors cease writing prescriptions.  Kratom is the one natural plant that can help all those in need.  I have never used a needle on myself, and god-willing, never will.

Kratom is helping turn my life from dependent on seeing my doctor every month - to happy and independent.  Please do not let Big Pharma win. They WANT us to be addicted and Kratom is the help to kick the habit that my Doctors started.

Thank you for reading this heartfelt message,

Matt

Dear Sir/Ma'am,

I would like to voice my upmost concern over the scheduling of the all natural, organic, life transforming plant known as Kratom. I am a full time manufacturing engineer, with a great income and very stable life. I contribute to our society as productively as possible, -"" while using kratom daily. I've been a user for 2 years, i get blood work done regularly, and myself nor my doctor have witnessed ANY adverse effects. Kratom is saving lives and has the potential to fight the absolutely horrible opioid epidemic that we are all well aware of. This is honestly a miracle plant, and poses no threat other than to pharmacy addictions that plague our communities. In my humble opinion, banning a plant simple due to the fact that IT IS NOT UNDERSTOOD is not only wrong, but irresponsible. I am an advocate for further testing, and even age restrictions (which 18+ is already in place within the community). This plant has given me power back over my own life. Most importantly, there has NEVER been a death associated with Kratom, when it was not mixed with other dangerous drugs. To put the blame on kratom makes no scientific sense, as the toxicity of prescription pills is well understood, and in almost every case, are also ingested by the victim. 

In closing, I am a hard working, socially active, politically active, engineer that contributes to my society and community, all while ingesting a simple tea, which is now being looked at as harshly as heroine. This. Is. Wrong. Let's use our resources to study this, not ban out of fear of the unknown. We are the greatest country in the world, banning a plant so it can be profititized as a pill is unamerican, and I promise you that's what will happen after the ban. Put the people first, not profit.

Respectfully,

documents.commentText: As a registered nurse I have had positive experiences with the herb kratom personally, and professionally I believe that it is a highly safe herb that should continue to be available over the counter to adults 18 years of age and older. The possible banning of kratom has terrified me as I was injured during childbirth six years ago, had two extensive pelvic surgeries with placement of vaginal mesh, and was diagnosed as having a collagen tissue disorder called Ehler-Danlos. The scar tissue from the pelvic surgeries, mesh implants, and the loose joints I have from Ehler-Danlos cause me chronic pain. However I love my six year old son dearly, and I needed a mild pain relieving medication that would not impair my cognition and activity level like narcotic pain relievers and even over the counter pain relievers such as Ibuprofen & Acetaminophen do. Kratom saved my life because it is a medication that I can stop and start taking as needed for pain without the withdrawal symptoms that narcotics cause. I can think clearly with Kratom, and am able to home school my son and do many household duties that I used to be unable to do before Kratom. Losing this literal lifeline of Kratom would harm not just those of us disabled and in chronic pain, but also our families and those who depend upon us being well enough to work without typical pain drug side effects. Professionally as a registered nurse I can find no evidence that this herb is anymore dangerous than a host of other herbs and synthetic medications currently available over the counter. Kratom is a surprisingly safe herb. It does not inhibit respiratory drive like narcotics, and is a mild pain reliever that is much like taking a combination of Ibuprofen with a cup of coffee (Kratom as properties in it similar to caffeine in addition to blocking pain). Alcohol, cigarettes, prescription narcotics, and marijuana are by far much stronger drugs. Alcohol causes poisoning, death, respiratory depression, and addictive abuse on levels that create genuine societal problems, and yet it is perfectly legal over the counter for adults. Health food stores have isles upon isles of shelves filled with herbal supplements such as skullcap, calendula, st. john's wort, valerian, etc and these herbs are perfectly legitimate for adults to choose to supplement with for a host of health reasons as they see fit. Kratom is an herb that poses no more danger than taking an over the counter herb such as calendula or skullcap. I understand the issues the DEA is facing now with trying to stop the rampant abuse of heroin and other strong prescriptive narcotics in the USA presently. My husband is an ER/trauma nurse and we have seen the effects of drugs like heroin and Dilaudid. Kratom may seem like a kissing cousin chemically to narcotics, but in its pure herbal form (non-synthetic) it does not cause issues that narcotics can in terms of respiratory suppression, cognitive issues, and severe addiction. Kratom is no more strong of a addiction than would be found with taking regular coffee/caffeine, chocolate, or sugar while providing enormous benefit to vulnerable and disabled individuals. These disabled individuals with chronic pain on Kratom seek to take the most minimal pain medication possible in order to function the most normally with work and other activities of daily living. I don't know what I will do if I lose this miracle herb. I am scared to think of having to go back on narcotic pills for pain relief as I was not present mentally when on them and could work much less effectively. Please note that the complications found which warranted closer examination of Kratom involved patients taking multiple drugs, and that items such as washing machine detergent pods and alcohol have caused far greater damages and deaths. It makes no sense to ban Kratom from a logical stand point medically, and from a moral stand point banning Kratom will punish and put vulnerable, disabled persons in the population at risk with no other good pain relief options. In an ideal world we would all heal and not have to deal with chronic pain and illness. Yet we live in an imperfect world and there are many of us suffering in the dark with pain and chronic health issues we will carry our entire lives. We are disabled and in need of pain relief, but we are not abusers of medications nor addicts seeking a euphoric high. Look at the sound evidence which shows Kratom to be a safe herbal supplement that can entirely reasonably be taken over the counter by adults of sound mind for useful purposes as the individual deems fit. There are thousands (maybe millions) of us depending upon Kratom as our lifeline, and the evidence shows it is safe to use so please keep Kratom as a legal herbal supplement for the good of our society. Thank you for your consideration. I am happy to answer to any and all questions on this matter to be of further use.

documents.commentText:
I am writing today to plead against the Kratom ban. The comparison of Kratom to other
Schedule 1 substances is just unfathomable. The proof that Kratom is not synthetic, and
does not give a traditional high has been proven over and over again. The war is being 
fought on the wrong battleground. While there may be some that feel that Kratom is 
addictive, and dangerous, how much more dangerous - by anyone's standards- are the 
alternatives?  Whether it be prescription pain killers, replacement therapy such as
methadone or suboxone, or illegal drugs like heroin, there is no argument that the 
obviously least harmful of all is Kratom. I personally have tried all the other alternatives
to manage pain, anxiety, and ultimitely addiction because of these dangerous medications. 
Kratom has not only allowed me to free myself from all of the legal and illegal drugs 
that caused me to be high, to withdrawal when I did not have them, and most importantly
to take me away from my family and from society, I am now also able to manage my pain
and mental health better than I ever have before. 
There is no doubt that the addiction and fatalities caused by both illegal narcotics and 
prescription opiods and medications is something that needs to be direly addressed. 
But, once again, it's being attacked in the wrong direction. For the million or so people
that have changed their lives for the better and escaped the dangerous cycle they 
were living in, taking Kratom away will absolutely and inarguably do more harm than good. 
Why take that chance?  If profit does not come before human life, and if a PROVEN 
non-synthetic supplement can provide so much positive with very little to no negative
repercussion, there really is no argument supporting the banning of Kratom left. 
People will always find a way to abuse a substances. Too many abuse their prescription 
medications, mainly due to the nature of the medication themselves - 
being prescribed by a physician or managed by thehealthcare system has not stopped that
abuse and it's lethal consequences in any way. 
We should have the power to choose what is found in nature. Not a plant that is 
adulterated as cocaine and heroin are, but a leaf exactly as we find in tea and
other supplements.
Taking this plant away would not only be unfair, it would be irresponsible. This plant 
has allowed me to become a mother again, a contributing member of society, while being
free of the pain that ruled my every waking moment. I can live without fear of losing
everything due to an addiction started by pain pills, prescribed by a well-meaning doctor. 
If the power of this plant can be studied, and harnessed into a pill that can be 
profited on, all while saving many lives with medications that started this epidemic, 
than how much more irresponsible would we be to take away that research?  I personally 
would rather the natural version, but the option should and could be there. Everyone
wins. 
Intentions were well-meaning, but there is no public health threat with Kratom. 
Those efforts would be better spent focusing on the synthetic drugs pouring
into our country legally. Better spent focusing on the dangerous altered illegal 
and counterfeit drugs flooding our streets. Better spent on education and oversight into
prescription drug abuse. Taking away prescriptions is now causing new problems to those
who need relief. Banning Kratom would only add to that, by taking away a safe alternative.
My vote goes to Kratom, and to keep it unscheduled and within reach of any and all.

Kratom and Cannabis as Schedule I drugs shows the absolute lack of scientific expertise and knowledge in the DEA. It's shameful. The DEA works for the people of this country, not against them. Many people with serious opiate addiction and illnesses will be in danger and ultimately killed by the DEA if this happens. Do the right thing!

documents.commentText:
I am a 35 year old male.  I enjoy a successful career in biomedical research, Im an eagle scout, hold an advanced degree in molecular biology, and have pursued computer technology certifications on the side just for fun recently.  I also take kratom regularly to help with my depression and anxiety.  In my teen and college years I used illicit substances or overconsumed alcohol in an effort to obtain relief from depression related symptoms.  10 years ago, I successfully quit all alcohol and illicit drug use, began exercising regularly and maintaining a reasonably healthy diet - all of which have improved my mindset, motivation and overall outlook on life.  Nevertheless, prior to discovering kratom I was still struggling frequently with strong feeling of depression and anxiety despite significant efforts to be healthy and productive.  After beginning to take a few grams of kratom each day and maintaining the other elements of an overall healthy lifestyle such as diet and exercise, I now feel much more positive, motivated and at peace.  Kratom has been a huge benefit in my life and helped me to reach my full potential in both my personal and professional endeavors.
The proposed action by the DEA to schedule and ban kratom will cause significant and immediate harm to many thousands of individuals such as myself who benefit from taking kratom as a supplement.  A ban will significantly slow or stop ongoing research that can help us better understand how kratom should be safely and effectively used.   Its time for US drug policy to move into the 21st century and acknowledge that prohibition of any and all psychoactive substances including plants and herbs is not always in the best interest of public health and can often result in unintended consequence that harm the public (black markets, black market related violence, sale of contaminated materials).  Please do not ban kratom at this time but instead allow research and public opinion to drive policy on how kratom and other herbal supplements are regulated.  
Thank you.

documents.commentText:
My sister has had multiple back surgeries and was suppose to be in pain management for the rest of her life. She was and is on enough prescription medication to immobilize a horse. I have introduced her to Kratom and our family has been so thankful for the hope it has brought us about getting our sister back. Her kids and her ex husband are also so thankful. My father was preparing her will because we were convinced she was not going to make it another year but now she is showing signs of improvement. The fact that my sister showed up to thanksgiving dinner and was able to participate in the annual wiffle ball game and the high stakes board games is enough for me to plead with any decision maker to not hastily schedule a supplement that has showed so much promise to our family.  We have have seen our sister clear eyed and cognizant for the first time in 10 years. I don't think this herb is a miracle but I do think it is a useful supplement for those trapped in pain and the fog of side effects that prevent people from being able to live a productive life. I am so greatful our family has had the financial, emotional and physical resources needed to try and attempt to negate the awful consequences my niece and nephew have had to endure over the years while their mother was suffering with legitimate pain. She will always have a metal cage in her back and she will always be limited as to how much she will be able to do physically but to witness such a huge change in her cognitive ability by choosing to lower her benzodiazepines and opiate use has been such a blessing to our entire family. For once in our life even the MD's in our family whisper a sigh of relief and see the change that we never thought was going to happen. 

Sincerely, 

Catherine Margaret Nutcher

documents.commentText:
RE: Docket No. DEA-442W - my comments

To Whom It May Concern,

Thank you for allowing me to express my concerns with the DEA's recent decision to classify Kratom as a Schedule 1 Drug. My story began 3 yeas ago, while trying to find a natural way to deal with my chronic migraine headaches (and other random ailments), all the while becoming more and more dependent and addicted to the legal opiates my doctor had been prescribing to me. Alas, i found Kratom, and a new life emerged. I have since been able to get effective relief with Kratom, without the horrible side effects that opiates have to offer. In fact, I became so impressed with what Kratom had to offer, that I decided to start selling it, as I knew it could help so many others out there. So that is what I did, and indeed, my 2 years of vending have helped thousands of people. I have received hundreds of communications of how grateful my customers were for the services I provided, due to how this tree leaf had benefited their lives. I never could respond to these testaments, due to the restrictions the FDA has placed on vendors and how the product is to be sold. Regardless, it is truly amazing how Kratom saves so many lives. Since the ban proposal, my business has abruptly ended, as it has become nearly impossible to sell Kratom since the ban proposal. Customs is unethically seizing/destroying shipments (to a still legal product), and merchants and payment processors are now afraid to work with Kratom vendors. This has been a hardship to my entire family, as it was my only source of income, as well as the only income for my staff. The Botanical Educational Alliance has estimated that as many as 10,000 Kratom vendors have been effected (if not more) by this unjust action of the DEA. https://www.botanical-education.org/economic-impact-kratom/ This in itself is a serious problem. We are talking about a benign plant, which millions of responsible law-abiding Americans use for very personal and usually necessary reasons. By banning Kratom (or scheduling it in any form), you are putting tens of thousands of people out of work in this economic crisis, and at the same time making criminals out of law-abiding citizens with the black market that will emerge overnight. Are you still not willing to learn from the past mistakes of the War On Drugs? Add to that, those deciding to make the choice of using a benign plant to help them (which would make them criminals), versus those who would rather not become criminals and go back to their old ways.. wow, what an unbelievable choice you will leave them.  Myself included. This has been one of the most trying times in my family's and my life. I can only pray you will listen to the people who have spoken.. the Kratom community as a whole, which involves consumers, scientists, doctors, vendors, and family members which your decision will affect. It is time to listen to the people.

Sincerely,

Anonymous Kratom Vendor

My name is Amanda and I am a 24 year old from Orlando, FL. 
I have suffered from Fibromayalgia and CFS for over a decade.  These conditions have hindered me in the past from working in my chosen field of work (welder). 
Since discovering kratom via an online fibromayalgia support group, I have been able to stop using all dangerous prescription or OTC painkillers which before were needed for my ailments despite all their nasty side effects.  Although kratom cannot treat or cure fibromayalgia (nothing that we know of can cure it), kratom is in fact the only thing I've ever discovered that can provide me with relief in a safe way.  I have not experienced any negative effects from kratom powder.   I have, however, experienced many negative and scary effects from Rx medications. 
Furthermore, I have noticed absolutely no dependency to kratom producing any withdrawal symptoms.  Most if not all painkillers which can help relieve such pain produce an incredibly awful dependency.  
So, in my honest opinion, kratom is a valuable and indispensable plant with many uses and great potential to help thousands of people.   I oppose a schedule I classification for that reason.  
I would like to continue to be a functioning member of society and be able to work, rather than have to receive any disability.  Kratom helps me be able to do that when nothing else could.  
Thank you for taking my comments into consideration.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I have been enjoying Kratom on and off over the better part of 4 years and quite frankly, I find it wildly perplexing that it is being considered for scheduling as an illicit substance.  It is hard to even consider it an adulterant, such alcohol, or marijuana (both which produce profoundly more intense psychoactive effects). In fact, I liken the effects of Kratom to that of a cup of coffee, minus the crash - and with responsible use, mind you, over the four years I have been enjoying it, I have truly noticed no adverse side affects.

What is there to gain from scheduling Kratom? Criminals do not involve themselves with it - and the people who enjoy it are not criminals. If scheduled, you will the place Kratom in the hands of criminals (if there is even a market for them, which I somewhat doubt)... Even worse, you'll turn innocent people into criminals. 

The DEA has been protecting our wonderful country for over 80 years. Let us focus on the real problems.... such as criminal organizations, and actual illicit drugs (which kratom is not) that truly hurt out society (heroin, prescription opioids, cocaine, ect).

I trust that the DEA will make the decision on this matter that is in the best interest of our country. 

Thank you so much,
Joe Hertler

I really do appreciate you taking the time to listen to public opinion on this issue about scheduling Kratom. I was shocked when I heard that this was going to be scheduled and even further dismayed by the false information that was being presented about Kratom.

Kratom is not at all deadly. Whenever someone has died in relation to taking Kratom it was OTHER drugs that killed them not the Kratom. Kratom is relaxing like valerian root. It has changed my life in relieving me of my anxiety with no side effect. 

I have been taking Kratom for about 5-6 years now. I have had no side effects and I am a productive tax paying member of society. Taking Kratom has allowed me to stop drinking all together. Before I found this herb I thought that I was going to drink myself to death. There are many nights that I don't remember because of alcohol.

We are adults, let us make our own decisions on what we put in our body. Especially if it is a God given plant that is as harmless as coffee.

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Charles Blackwell

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
    If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
    Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
    Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
    Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
    Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.


The War on Drugs has had a catastrophic impact on the trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. We need to restore that trust, and allowing for research and regulation of drugs like kratom will be a significant step.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

This quote is taken directly from Swogger, Hart,Erowid,Erowid, Trabold, Yee,& Walsh (2015), and speaks directly to the published research which indicates kratoms usefulness: Additionally, some studies have found that kratoms anti-nociceptive effects are comparable to widely used opiate analgesics (e.g., Watanabe et al. 1997). There is evidence to suggest that nociceptive responses to kratom differ from morphine and codeine, however, and that kratom may interact with opioid receptor subtypes involving serotonin path- ways (Hassan et al. 2013; Macko, Weisbach, and Douglas 1972; Watanabe et al. 1997). Recent animal research has also indicated that kratom has anti-inflammatory actions, antimicrobial activity, and can lead to suppression of food and water intake (Azizi et al. 2010; Shaik et al. 2009; Parthasarathy et al. 2009), making kratom an attractive area of basic research for a wide variety of human conditions. 

Additionally, Boyer, Babu,Adkins, McCurdy, & Halpern (2008) state Opioid analgesics remain highly effective modalities for the treatment of chronic pain, but their long-term administration is associated with the development of opioid misuse, abuse, dependence and addiction, the incidence of which is increasing [4]. Among individuals with chronic pain who are maintained on opioid analgesic agents, kratom is gaining awareness as a natural alternative to physician supervised opioid replacement therapy [1]. One striking finding of this report is the extent to which kratom attenuates potentially severe opioid withdrawal, yet cessation of kratom administration itself appears to be associated with modest abstinence symptoms. The pharmacological bases underlying this effect are uncertain. For example, mitragynine is theorized to stimulate contributions from adrenergic and serotonergic pathways that augment analgesia, but formal binding data have been obtained only for mu-, delta- and kappa opioid receptors [5,6].  Later in the case report, they claim these studies identified that mitragynine extensively inhibits radioligand binding at several central nervous system receptor systems (Table 1). The clinical implication of these results is that mu-opioid agonism may avert withdrawal symptoms, while kappa agonism attenuates reinforcement and produces aversion [7]. In addition, mitragynine, through its putative alpha-2 adrenergic agonist activity, may mimic adjunctive therapies for opioid withdrawal such as clonidine. Mitragynine, therefore, may exert several convergent pharmacological effects that could attenuate opioid withdrawal symptoms and blunt cravings.

From these two published, peer-reviewed studies, it is clear that this plant material (Mitragyna speciosa) contains alkaloids which have the potential to help the medical and scientific communities better understand pain response and develop new therapies to treat a myriad of conditions.  It is essential you do not schedule this plant in the most restrictive category, for if you do, a tremendous resource will be locked away from millions of people.  Instead, what should be advocated for is additional study into the plant and its properties so we can harness its ability to attenuate pain.

Sincerely,
Kevin Roux, M.Ed., RN

References
Swogger,M.T., Hart,E., Erowid,F., Erowid,E., Trabold,N., Yee,K.,  Walsh,Z. (2015). Experiences of Kratom Users: A Qualitative Analysis. Journal of Psychoactive Drugs, 47(5), 360-367. doi:10.1080/02791072.2015.1096434

Boyer,E.W., Babu,K.M., Adkins,J.E., McCurdy,C.R., & Halpern,J.H. (2008). Self-treatment of opioid withdrawal using kratom (Mitragynia speciosa korth). Addiction, 103(6), 1048-1050. doi:10.1111/j.1360-0443.2008.02209.x

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Alex and I am submitting my comment regarding the proposed ban of kratom.

I am 30 years old and I personally have used kratom for about a year and a half. I mainly use it to help with insomnia and anxiety. I typically take a small dose before bed, and anytime I am having trouble sleeping throughout the night. I currently get some of the best sleep I have ever experienced thanks to kratom. That is priceless to me. 

If kratom was made illegal, I would have to resort to other sleep aids that make me groggy and/or are worse for my health. I feel no noticeable negative side effects from kratom. I usually sleep very well when I take kratom, and wake up feeling great. This is more than I can say for any other sleep aid I have tried.

I only buy kratom from reliable vendors online and have never had any issues with the quality of their products. I see kratom as something that has similar potency and usefulness as coffee. It is a useful plant to millions of people worldwide, and it does a lot more good than harm to society. 

I am 100% certain that I am a happier, healthier, and more productive person thanks to kratom. If it was made illegal, my quality of life would suffer an my ability to contribute to society would be lessened. 

Please do not make another extremely beneficial herb illegal. It would cause a lot of suffering in this country, and that is the last thing we need right now. 

Thank you for taking the time to read my comment!

documents.commentText:
I am a 46-year-old retired Police Officer. I have 3 lifesaving awards, a Veterans Service Medal, and I had the first NARCAN save in my PD. I have seen firsthand how the opiate epidemic has ravaged our communities. One of my lifesaving awards was on a 23-year-old heroin overdose before the days of carrying NARCAN.  I am also OPPOSED to the emergency scheduling of kratom, Docket No. DEA-442W. For this reason, I have chosen to make my comments anonymously. 

I am very familiar with addiction. Not only have I dealt with addicts daily over the course of my career, but I am also the son of an alcoholic. When I first heard that people were consuming this plant kratom to assist them in getting off the opiates they were addicted to, I was HIGHLY skeptical. I knew too many heroin addicts who I later ran into as methadone or Suboxone addicts. I was distrustful of kratom, not because it was an unknown plant, but because I had yet to meet anyone who had successfully used one substance to get off another.

I know several individuals who have consumed kratom to help them get off heroin. They went from being "frequent flyers" as we refer to people we have repeat contact with, to clean and sober members of the community. They are working and in relationships. They are raising their kids and finishing their educations. Now, I see them as they work their jobs or shop for their groceries. I am not seeing them in handcuffs, being transported to County for yet another drug-related offense. My contact with them is positive contact these days, not negative.

I have seen these "kratom users" up close and first hand, and I cannot stress enough that this is NOT something that needs emergency scheduling and I am completely against this ban. At most, I would support an age restriction. We have an age restriction on alcohol and cigarettes, and if the DEA were being honest, I think the agency would agree that alcohol poses a greater threat than kratom.  According to the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism website, nearly 88,000 people (approximately 62,000 men and 26,000 women) die from alcohol-related causes annually, making alcohol the fourth leading preventable cause of death in the United States. In 2014, alcohol-impaired driving fatalities accounted for 9,967 deaths (31 percent of overall driving fatalities). I have seen the ravages of alcohol up close and personal. I have made the death notifications from heroin overdoses and traffic fatalities. Clearly, you do not have these numbers from kratom. Most of my brother officers do not even know what kratom is because it is NOT an issue in our communities! Quite frankly, law enforcement has enough on their plate going after the dealers of hard drugs like heroin and meth. Going after a plant that I have seen help people first hand? Give me a break. Please do not ban this plant.

documents.commentText:
I am strongly against the drug war to begin with. People are starting to realize that arresting, raiding, and prosecuting people for illegal substances has more to do with control, asset seizure, keeping private prisons full, and other false pretenses rather than keeping the public "safe",  which is only an illusion.  If a person is not harming another person,  it's not right for them to be told what they can and can't put in thier body.  It's often assumed that becuase a person is against the drug war,  that must mean they advocate drug use.  This is not true in my case as well as many other people.  

Banning even one more substance would be going in the opposite direction.  It would be undermining freedom.  I'm sure you are aware that marajuana was banned after alcohol prohibition ended.  A new revenue stream was needed to replace what was lost from the end of prohibition.  To get the public on board with this ban, Racist scare tactics were used that claimed marijuana "made Mexicans crazy".  This was reinforced by propaganda movies such as "Reefer Madness".

The same thing is now happening with Kratom.  Many people are discovering it's benefits and profits of Big Pharma are at risk.  People who did research into alternatives for medications such as Oxycontin have (had) an option.  Now the same type of propaganda is being used to scare the public into  supporting (or at very least accepting) a ban.  Like Marijuana,  it would be inaccurate to classify Kratom under schedule 1 (no medical uses) when so many people are finding relief from pain, anxiety, etc.  Kratom doesn't only help people avoid having to take dangerous perscription pain killers.....It also helps people who are already addicted to them.  Right now as far as prescribed medication goes,  there isn't anything available that isn't just as addictive as the substance being abused.  

Please reconsider this ban.  This affects a great deal of people.  Dangerous or not,  it shouldn't be the government's choice how people choose to manage their pain,  treat their symptoms,  or even experience an altered state of consciousness,  If that's what they choose to do.  Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I am a 41 year old mother. I have a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration with a minor in Psychology. Before I became too chronically ill to work I was employed as an Admistrative Assistant in the 2-year college system for ten years. My health deteriorated and I became bedridden at times with a very low quality of life.

Two years ago I learned of a plant called kratom through a chronic pain support group and I began my research into this plant. After extensively researching all aspects of this plant I decided that I would give this all-natural plant a try in an effort to better my quality of life.

Over the past 20 years I have been diagnosed with the following conditions: Major Depressive Disorder; Generalized Anxiety Disorder; Panic Attacks; PTSD;  Social Anxiety Disorder; Generalized Mood Disorder; Attention Deficit Disorder; Fibromyalgia; Chronic Fatigue Immue Deficiency; Sjogren's Syndrome; Moderate to Severe Arthritis; Degenerative Disc Disease of my spine and neck (L1 & L2; C5 - C7) with bulging discs; Carpal Tunnel in both wrists; and Fibrosis of my left thumb.

I have been through numerous nerve blocks and injections to no avail. I have been on more psychotropic medications than any one person should ever be prescribed. I have had extensive cognitive therapy counseling including a partialized hospitalization program and also individualized cognitive behavior therapy with little results. More prescription drugs were prescribed that left me feeling drugged, sad, and lethargic. Since then I have had a mixture of prescription medications for my physical and mental pain changed and then changed again and again. I became more depressed and virtually unable to leave my house. The prescription drugs were ineffective and the side effects seemed to make my health worse.

A year ago I began kratom as a dietary supplement. I no longer woke up every morning dreading life. I was no longer a prisoner to my chronic conditions. I was no longer too drugged to function. I still had physical pain. I still had mental pain. The difference being with kratom I was clear headed. I no longer spent my days bedridden. I was no longer a recluse. I became a functioning member of society for the first time in too many years. I was able to exercise, help care for my parents and my precious 95 year old grandmother. I was active in my son's extracurricular activities including being a "team mom" for his middle school baseball team. I was so grateful for finally feeling like a real, normal person again.

Kratom gave me a new chance at life and it is imperative this dietary supplement be available for people like me. The list of medications I no longer had to take included everything from anti-depressants, mood stabilizers, anti-anxiety medications to pain management medications.

Kratom is a safe alternative to pharmaceutical drugs with important medicinal uses and has changed my life. 

Unfortunately legislation in my State was passed to ban kratom. I was able to stop kratom as part of my all natural treatment for my conditions without any of the dangerous side effects or withdrawals caused from stopping my former prescription medications. 

Thank you for allowing my testimony.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should immediately stop considering placement of Kratom onto Schedule 1.  If the agency is concerned about its potential for harm or addiction, then the substance should first be subjected to a thorough study of those risks (and benefits).  Available information indicates that it has been used by millions without serious side effects, and is therefore a candidate for use in treating the current epidemic of opioid addiction.  Adding it to Schedule 1 would therefore prevent any meaningful study of its potential benefits or risks.  That is a classic "cart before the horse" scenario.  

The DEA should not take actions that would interfere with progress in treatment of opioid addiction.

The only parties who would benefit from immediate placement of Kratom onto Schedule 1 would be the companies who currently sell opioid substitutes.

Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
To the honorable Men and Women of the DEA and related Task Forces concerning Kratom,

My name is Carlos Nuques. 

 I would like to humbly and respectfully request that the plant known as Kratom, and all of its closely related variants, with all of their useable alkaloids, be kept legal in the United States of America, and protected and regulated to ensure quality and safety. 

 I come from a law enforcement family (Father, ex-wife, current fianc', 2 uncles and 3 cousins all officers, spanning 5 decades of service). I am a US Navy Veteran, disabled and honorably discharged, currently in the VA health care system. I have been blessed with the opportunity and challenge of having to overcome 2 herniated discs and 2 knees with inoperable cartilaginous tumors. I live with pain.

 Before implementing Kratom into my treatment plan, I was certainly not able to reduce my intake of opiates in a proper way. The VA doctors simply switched the types of medications, creating the illusion that my consumption was less, of course when focusing on only 1 particular brand or formulation. But in reality and objectively speaking, my consumption was indeed not declining, it was slowly increasing. Much like the overwhelming majority of patients on opiates. Ultimately I reached a point where I needed to reverse the direction I was headed, and find a way to manage my pain, health and overall situation much better. I knew there had to be a way. I searched and eventually found Kratom.

Kratom has been the single most important factor or weapon in my arsenal to fight this daily battle of pain and discomfort. It has allowed me to notably reduce my intake and therefore manage my pain much better. This small adjustment in my life, has yielded much fruit. My family and friends can attest to this. 

For some time now Kratom has been in the collective consciousness and proverbial medicine cabinet of humanity as a whole. In recent history Kratom has been the subject of many studies as its historical presence, use and recorded successes has come to light. These successes have been tested in modern studies and have indeed been validated. However different and varying, the undeniable common thread or theme in the modern feedback and findings from Kratom use is simply that 'quality of life is improved'. I am of the humble opinion that there is enough evidence supporting the benefits of the use of Kratom, primarily in managing pain, therefore we should allow Kratom to remain legal and in that, we should encourage the careful scientific study of the useable alkaloids and it's possible large scale medicinal use for treating a wide variety of human illnesses. 

I understand the DEA's concern when approaching this subject of Kratom. It may seem like a slippery slope, however, when objectively examined, I am confident that the DEA will find that Kratom has been unfairly marred in anecdotal reports of harm to humans and chained to the stigma of arising from the dark swamp of the 'drug culture'. But this is an illusion. 

Kratom is a good thing for humans. Please reconsider the pursuit to criminalize this plant. Thank you for your time, consideration and service to the American people. Please feel free to contact me directly via email. 

Carlos Nuques
