documents.commentText:
I am a 64 year old tax-paying citizen who has worked all her life, raised two children and has no criminal record.  About 20 years ago I developed Multiple Chemical Sensitivity, which is currently acknowledged by HUD and the SSA to be a legitimate disability.  Unfortunately the medical establishment largely has yet to recognize it, so unless an individual is able to afford practitioners who specialize in this disorder, relief is mostly denied to him or her.  Specialists in environmental illness are largely outside the networks of doctors whose services are covered by insurers.

I live in a semi-detached house with numerous air leaks between the units that I cannot prevent.  My neighbor has many animals and constantly uses pesticides which gives me headaches, earaches, stomach aches and overall feelings of malaise.  I could not sell my house for a long time because it was underwater.  If not for the relief provided by kratom I think I would have just walked away from house and let it foreclose. I think I probably would have lost my job from not being able to get enough sleep to perform at work properly.  Kratom has let me continue working and continue caring for my elderly parents. It has let me continue being a mother and a grandmother, instead of a homeless person who needs to be taken care of herself.  Kratom is not a recreational drug--it does not make people "high."  It is a mild pain reliever and relaxant.  

There will always be many people who fall through the cracks of the medical system for whom such a substance is literally a lifesaver and I think this very substantial human benefit needs to be weighed against any perceived liabilities.

documents.commentText: I have a long history of treatment resistant major depression. I have been on ten different medications and only one of them has worked and only then for about six months before It stopped working. As a result of my depression I have gotten into trouble with substances, mainly alcohol and other drugs. At my worst I was up to drinking a fifth a day of hard liquor and while I have a goal of long term sobriety it seems impossible to achieve with this horrible mood disorder. After experiencing a lot of failure with maintaining long term society I sought out a harm reduction approach. I tried using other drugs only to have it spiral into addiction. Synthetic marijuana, large doses of over the counter cough medicine and several illegal drugs were all alternatives I turned to in an effort to avoid drinking. I have used a lot of hard drugs and been addicted multiple times, kratom is nothing like those substances. I had heard about kratom through my online research and decided it was worth trying. I've found that it works very quickly to kill my depression and it alleviates alcohol cravings. I don't feel intoxicated while taking it and I have a lot more energy to devote towards work and being a better partner to my wife. Having experienced delirium tremors and nasty drug withdrawal in the past I can say that stopping kratom use is very easy. The benefits go away but I don't feel like I need to get more kratom. Additionally it's simple to use a kitchen scale to measure out my dose and keep it consistent. There is no incentive for me to use more and more of it because if I take too much it will make nauseous. Kratom has been one of the very few alternative treatments I have tried for my co-occuring conditions that works. I'm currently pursuing TMS  (Transcranial magnetic stimulation) treatment for my depression and I'm hoping that I can continue to use kratom as needed to supplement that and keep me sober from alcohol. Talk therapy and a good psychiatrist are also tools I have been using for years and I've been to two treatment programs and more meetings than I care to remember for my addiction problems. I stopped using kratom recently in September and part of October and had several binge drinking slips and a major depressive episode. If it were to be made illegal I genuinely feel that my quality of life would suffer significantly. With kratom in my arsenal I can function in society, I'm a better employee, spouse and student who will be graduating from a university in a few weeks with honors. Without it my choices for safe and effective treatment are limited and I'm not sure that I will make it. Please do not ban this wonderful plant because the small subset of users who are looking for a cheap, legal high. They are probably coming away disappointed. If a person like me, a chronically depressed alcoholic and drug user, can use kratom responsibly than surely it poses little if any actual risk to the public.

documents.commentText:
This letter is to express my opposition to the DEA's intent to impose a federal ban upon the naturally occurring Asian tree leaf known as Kratom. 
 Kratom has been chewed or brewed in teas in Asia for centuries. It's ingestion is known to help alleviate many of the aches and pains associated with aging, curb appetites for harmful addictive substances, and help promote an overall sense of well-being. Many aging laborers in Asian culture have credited Kratom for helping them stay active and productive, and thereby avoid being replaced by younger workers. It's effectiveness has long been highly valued in cultures that don't have institutionalized social safety nets, and remaining physically competitive as long as possible is of utmost importance.
 I believe Kratom use in America has been wrongly associated with the abuse of illicit and harmful substances. The existing body of knowledge suggesting that the ingestion of Kratom ALONE has led to bodily harm is sparse at best. The benefits of protecting American's rights to include natural herbal alternatives in their efforts to maintain an enhanced quality of life appear to outweigh any imminent risks. I am a strong advocate for limiting Federal overreach in limiting naturally occurring choices for self-care.
 Personally I have indeed incorporated Kratom into my health regime, and I believe it's been very beneficial in helping me maintain an active, productive, and self-sustaining lifestyle. I have children and grandchildren who depend on me to be a resource to them. And I consider myself an intelligent, responsible, and well-informed tax paying citizen.
 I sincerely hope the DEA will heavily weigh the consequences of restricting American's rights to make their own choices before advancing further with this proposed restriction.
                                                                                                   Sincerely,
                                                                                                    Robert McDermott

documents.commentText:
My name is Matt Snyder, and I'm currently a student (again). I'm strongly opposed to the scheduling of kratom. I have generalized anxiety disorder and major depressive disorder. A friend of mine who used kratom to escape opioid addiction told me it was helpful for stress, and after drinking some, I noticed that it also has a positive effect on mood. Over the next few months, as I learned more facts about kratom, the more enthusiastic I became. It helped calm me when I decided to taper off of benzodiazepines, a hellish process. Lately, I've been taking a teaspoon full in tea every day, more or less depending on stress. It's not a replacement for anti-depressants or meds for panic disorders, but it has a very real, very positive effect on my life. I'll be ok if it's banned, but many people won't.

For many, friends and family included, it's a way to fight opioid addiction without the use of deadly (and deadly expensive) Big Pharma controlled solutions, such as buprenorphine or methadone. I have a friend who's currently trying to get off of methadone using kratom, which should highlight where the real danger lies here. I have several friends and family members who might have lived had they only known about kratom.

Kratom was banned in Alabama in May. In June, the number of opioid overdoses in Birmingham doubled. [www.kratomliteracyproject.com/2016/07/drug-policy/] Overnight. Just like that. That should tell us something. A number of states have considered and rejected the idea of a Kratom ban. These states want kratom to be available to their citizens. The DEA has overstepped their bounds and I hope the FDA takes note of what the states and the US citizenry want in the midst of this crisis.

documents.commentText:
I am praying that you move forward with compassion and care as you work to understand this substance that has been a lifesaver for so many. Including myself. 

I am a 28 year old male living in Texas. I am against the DEA putting Kratom on the schedule 1 controlled substances list. 

I was twenty six when I started to use kratom. I live with severe depression and anxiety, and have since I was 13 years old. Before I started using kratom, I was abusing alcohol... Self - medicating daily. 

I have been in therapy for my conditions since I was sixteen. I have been on and off more medications than I can count. Some things would work for a little while, but the positive effects would wear off. The side effects would often make things worse. I would become dependent on the drugs, and began to abuse benzodiazepines. Because of my alcohol and substance abuse, frequent panic attacks, and persisting depression and anxiety, I was unable to hold down a job and frequently relied on the grace of my friends to keep me from being homeless.

My alcohol abuse took me to rock bottom on February 22, 2014 when I attempted to kill myself. By the grace of God, I survived. From that point I knew that if I was going to live, I was going to have to find something that worked. 

I quit alcohol cold turkey that day. Things were going pretty well for about a year until I relapsed with alcohol. Things started to look like they were going to spiral down again until I heard about Kratom.

Using Kratom has enabled me to quit drinking. Unlike alcohol, benzos, and opiates - all of which I have abused in the past - it isn't pleasant to take more than a moderate dose. I was able to replace alcohol with Kratom, and once I was confident that I was through the rough spell, stopped using kratom with no negative effects. 

Combined with therapy and light anxiety and depression medications, I am living a normal life for the first time since I was 13 years old. I continue to take a small dose of Kratom occasionally when I start to have a panic attack come on (two or three times a week). 

I have enjoyed steady employment and promotions for over two years at a growing company. I have repaired my relationships with my friends and family. I am paying all of my bills for the first time in my life. I could not have done that without Kratom.

If Kratom is designated a schedule 1 drug, I fear that I will turn back to alcohol and substance abuse. I will become a criminal if I continue to use this natural, mild medicine. I fear for those who rely on kratom to stay off of hard drugs like heroin - a few of which I know personally.

I don't want to be a criminal. I don't want to start abusing substances again. I don't want to die. 

Thanks to the freedom of this great nation, I was able to find a path to wellness that worked for me when nothing else has. Please represent MY interests and fight for a sensible understanding of this substance, rather than a knee jerk scheduling.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. Kratom should be legally regulated, allowing for quality control measures and product labeling requirements.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

7-hydroxymitragynine, the main psychoactive constituents of the plant Mitragyna speciosa, also referred to as kratom, to the list of schedule 1 controlled substances.

In June or July of that year, some close friends invited me to an ethnobotanical tea bar, and I began drinking kratom teas.  My alcohol consumption immediately dropped to almost none.  I still went out with my friends, but instead of several alcoholic drinks, I had just one or two kratom teas.  I had fun, and I REMEMBERED IT.  I read what I could find about kratom online, including a Scientific American article similar to the one at https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/should-kratom-be-legal/, where I learned that kratom could possibly help addicts stop using without withdrawal.  At some point thereafter, I did some intense yard work and discovered that drinking a kratom tea helped alleviate the intense muscle aches I had afterwards.  Since then, my socializing has moved from bars and parties to kava bars, where no alcohol is served.  At the four establishments I have visited, young people who wanted a place to hang out with peers sit alongside former alcoholics, ex-junkies and others.  The atmosphere is calm, friendly, and very supportive.  I have only once heard a voice raised in anger while at a kava bar, and the angry person was not a customer.  I have kratom tea two or three times a week now, except when I travel away from my home area.  Since I started drinking kratom teas, I have been on five trips lasting from one to three weeks each.  During these trips, I had no kratom and experienced no urges or symptoms of withdrawal.  Currently I drink kratom teas socially once or twice and week - often while I paint miniatures, which require steady hands and precise coordination, and additional tea once in a while to alleviate muscle aches.

I think kratom should remain available because it is a natural plant product similar to other teas and coffee that seems to help and be enjoyed by a lot of people.  In my experience, excepting two people who drank very large quantities (leading to nausea, much as drinking that much coffeee might,) no one has reported any negative effects from consuming kratom.  I have not had any negative effects from drinking kratom teas.  Additionally, I worry about the people I know who have told me they were able to stop taking addictive drugs, including illegal ones, and those who have moved away from their alchoholism.  I do not think I will return to drinking (alcohol) heavily should kratom become schedule one, but it unsettled me that my wife, upon hearing of the DEA's proposal to ban kratom, bought me a bottle of whiskey.

Please do not add mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine to the list of schedule 1 controlled substances or otherwise restrict access to this plant.

Sincerely, Don A. Sankovitch, M Ed

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

 I have personally been using Kratom for about 3 years now. A herbal business owner brought Kratom to my attention about a year before I started using the plant. I broke my pelvis, and a major part of my foot on two separate occasions. Needless to say, those injuries over a few years caused some major back problems (severe arthritis, multiple degenerate disc disease, scoliosis). With that being said, they prescribed me Morphine, which I wasn't very fond of being on a narcotic as such for 5 years. I really wanted to find an natural alternative to help me with my daily pains. I would love to have to not rely on anything, but my pain is so bad, it makes me such a mean miserable person, and with the young kids it just isn't an option. Plus I couldn't even pick up my kids, that is how bad it got, and the only reason Morphine at the time was an option. Kratom got me off the Morphine, and has helped me normalize through out my days. Yes, I can still feel pain, but it is lessened, and way more tolerable! Kratom not only helps with my pain, but also with my extreme anxiety, depression, PTSD, etc. Kratom gave me my life back, and has made me a better mother because of it! Kratom is a God Send! Not only has Kratom saved my life, but I have introduced the plant to others in need, as well. I have personally seen it help folks with getting of all types of narcotic (to include heroin), people with extreme pain issues (where they were bed ridding and now can move about), Others with extreme PTSD symptoms (to the extreme of never leaving their house, anxiety, suicidal, etc.) and now are living normal lives, all due to Kratom. Kratom is a gift from god, and should be used to help people get back to a normal life. Taking it away will only cause more drug issues. I am 56 years old.  I was diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis and fibromyalgia in 2003.  I have tried all the big pharma medications for pain, anxiety depression, fatigue and pain that comes with a chronic illness.  There were days I could not get out of bed because I was in so much physical and mental pain.
Approximately 2 years ago a fellow chronic pain sufferer told me about Kratom.  I was skeptical.  I joined a group she recommended.  I was still skeptical.  I conducted my own research, I asked questions and then I decide to try a sample.  I cried the first time I took Kratom because within 15 minutes my pain was at bay.  I felt relief, the kind of relief
I had not felt since before my diagnosis.  I couldn't believe it.  I told my husband who was also as skeptical as I and after a few days of taking Kratom I was finally convinced.
I was convinced that I did not have to continue to live in pain.  I did not have to decline invitations to parties and gatherings.  I could manage my pain, anxiety and fatigue in such a way I could have a decent quality of life.
Kratom have me a life I never thought possible with RA and fibro. I could now walk my furkids (dogs) and go to the mall with my husband.  I could work in the yard and clean my house without feeling like a truck hit me after only a few minutes of activity.
The best thing about Kratom was there were no side effects.  I didn't feel loopy or "out of it" like some pain meds and muscle relaxers make you feel. I could take a yellow strain or white one and have a little more energy while curbing my pain.  My anxiety lessened and I was able to stop the prescription meds.
Kratom helped my insomnia and I could have a decent night's sleep without waking up multiple times during the night because of pain.
Kratom literally saved my life.  I had a tremendous fear of addiction with prescription drugs and since addiction runs in my family I was even more fearful.
With Kratom I used what I need.  I can also take a reset tincture to help my body readjust to doses when needed.  I do not feel trapped in my life anymore.  I feel like I have a life. 
I am so thankful for Kratom and I pray you not take away the only thing that has worked for me.  I am not alone. There are so many others like me.  I have helped others find Kratom who in turn were as amazed and grateful as I.
Please please please do not outlaw Kratom.  For my sake and all the others who need it for a decent quality of life.
Thank you very much.  
Barbara Stalder

documents.commentText: Hello, I'm a 60 year old woman with chronic pain issues. I've had cancer this year, which hasn't helped pain issues, of course. I've drank kratom tea for about 6 years now, and I can't stress enough how much it's helped me get through day to day activitie! I have active grandchildren and I'm able to garden with them, bowl, swim, and many other things I'd not be able to join in without some sort of pain relief. I had a friend pass away in 2007 from pain pill addiction. It wasn't easy to be around her for her last year of life either. It was obvious that she was taking too many of the pain meds too. She became incoherent and difficult to deal with on a daily basis. I wish I'd have been familiar with this plant that God has put on this eart for us to use wisely. Maybe she would still be here, I just don't know. I do know I didn't want to end up like her. I've never had any problems with "withdrawal symptoms" when not drinking my kratom tea, and I don't feel the need to use it daily, only when I'm going to be fairly active around the house, or engage in activities with my grandkids. My life is my own now. I'm ever grateful for this plant. Please reconsider banning it. I have had no ill effects that I can speak of, and my bloodwork is done on a near monthly basis, and has looked pretty good, even throughout my cancer treatment. Thank you very much for taking the time to read this, and I hope it helps in some small way to curb making it illegal. I feel it would make matters worse if criminalized at this point. One more thing I'd like to add, and that is, I've gotten a bit nauseous if I drink more than one cup, so I do not. It does not get me "high" and I think it's nearly impossible to overdose on this gift from God. Once again, thank you for your time and looking into this matter. It means a lot to many of us older folks out here and i for one am very appreciative. Thank you

documents.commentText:
Hello, thank you for allowing us submit our thoughts on Kratom.

My name is Jake Chatterton, 22 years old, and a resident of Meridian Idaho.

I am in favor of keeping Kratom fully legal for those of adult age. 

I am against any restrictions that would prevent responsible adults from purchasing and using Kratom.

I was introduced to Kratom about a year ago. 

I use Kratom a couple times a week. 

It helps with my stress levels, anxiety and depression.

Previously, I was prescribed several SSRI antidepressant medications: Prozac, Effexor, Cymbalta and several anti-anxiety prescription mediations: Valium, Klonopin and Xanax. Those are the ones that I remember. I have been prescribed more than I can remember. 

All of them had to be used on a daily basis which forced an unwanted dependency to the medication. I didn't like them, they either changed my personalty or made me very fatigued. Some of the medications also made very forgetful and school became much more difficult.

Kratom, for me, is more mild but works better than all of those and I don't have the need or desire to use Kratom more than a couple of times a week after a stressful day.

Since discovering Kratom, I have gotten my mind back and I am doing much better in school. I can't tell you how much this has helped me. 

It's not that Kratom has a huge effect on my performance, but rather that I don't need to take powerful pharmaceutical medications that had side effects that I had no choice but to endure. I don't want to be on those.

Please reconsider the Kratom ban.

It helps so many people and has brought nothing but positive things to my life.

Thank you very much,
Jacob Chatterton

documents.commentText:
Kratom should absolutely NOT be placed on the Schedule of Controlled Substances.

My name is Jane, I'm 34 years old, I'm a married mother of one child, and I'm an office manager for my church.  I also have endometriosis, an incurable condition that causes intense pain on an intermittent basis.  For the past three years, kratom tea has helped me cope with the symptoms of this condition without the use of opiate painkillers.

Addiction and drug abuse are rampant and escalating, which is just one reason why it's absolutely counterproductive to ban or restrict an herbal supplement that helps to support people's health and well-being, in turn reducing the use of prescription drugs.  Without kratom, which helps to soothe and ease the extremely painful symptoms I experience with endometriosis, my choices would be very limited.  I would have to either take prescription opiates, which I am adamantly opposed to using, or undergo a hysterectomy at the age of 34.  Aside from the negative effects on my health, a hysterectomy would also be emotionally devastating, since I'm hoping to have a second child.  I am not exaggerating when I say that kratom is what is preserving my fertility, albeit indirectly.

The existing research is overwhelmingly in favor of the safety of kratom.  While there have been some negative reports, those reports are remarkably few, especially when compared to the number of negative incidents involving everything from energy drinks to over-the-counter medications to other common herbal supplements.  Furthermore, nearly all of those negative incidents have involved at least one of the following factors: adulterated or contaminated products (https://academic.oup.com/jat/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/anatox/35.4.242); combining kratom with multiple other substances; and modified kratom products, meaning the plain leaf (normally crushed or powdered for use as a tea) was converted into a concentrated extract or tincture.

This does NOT mean that kratom should be banned or "scheduled."  Instead, those who have studied kratom extensively are in favor of regulation that would require vendors to test their products for contamination and purity.  Indeed, the reputable vendors already do this.  We absolutely desire and recommend these kinds of quality-control measures, which could prevent the majority of negative experiences.  Most kratom is already sold in plain leaf form.  If we had regulation requiring that kratom products be sold only in plain leaf form, the sales of modified or concentrated products would be reduced even further.

Dr. Walter C. Prozialeck summarizes this quite clearly: "After evaluating the literature, I can reach no other conclusion than, in pure herbal form, when taken at moderate doses of less than 10 to 15 g, pure leaf kratom appears to be relatively benign in the vast majority of users." (jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2588524)

Surely we are beyond pretending that banning substances actually makes them disappear.  By "scheduling" or banning products, our government isn't actually controlling them; on the contrary, they are abdicating control.  They are simply handing the regulation of that product over to the black market.

People have been using kratom responsibly for many years with no negative effects.  Making kratom a controlled substance would cause irreparable damage to me personally, to thousands of others like me, and to our economy with the loss millions of dollars in legitimate sales and commerce (https://www.botanical-education.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/BEA-Economic-Impact-Report_V3-1.pdf).  Please don't rob us of our choices and our freedom to make our own decisions about how we manage and support our health.

documents.commentText:
There is no Constitutional amendment for the government to these issues.

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

My name is Wendi Rook, I'm a 47-year old woman from Oregon and I'd like to voice my opposition to making kratom (Mitragynine, 7-hydroxyymitragynine and Genus Mitragyna) a schedule 1 drug.
The alkaloids named above are naturally occurring compounds found in the leaves of the kratom tree (genus Mitragyna), a plant I consume to help treat my anxiety and depression.
I learned about kratom from a friend a couple of years ago who also consumes kratom for her chronic back and shoulder pain (she broke her shoulder and fractured vertebrae in her back due to a fall). 
I have suffered from anxiety and depression for years, and all of the pharmaceutical drugs (Zoloft, Wellbutrin, and Paxil) I have tried to use to combat it have had very unpleasant side effects- like sweating, sleepiness, agitation, and horrible dreams.
I spent the last 20+ years on and off these drugs trying to just feel normal without success. However, since I have been using kratom for two years now, I have not needed any of the pharmaceuticals- kratom makes things so much better for me.
This is a miracle plant for me and gives me the quality of life I want and feel I deserve. I finally feel normal now that I have kratom and I am so much happier. I exercise more now, I get out more, I am not afraid of being in large crowds, and my family says they have the old me back.
Please do not take kratom from me and the many many others who depend on it for a good quality of life.
Thank you for your time. 
Wendianne Rook BA ARRT RT (R) (T)

documents.commentText: Hello---   My name is Terri L. Stokes and I reside in Alabama, one of the few states which has banned kratom.  All of my adult life I have suffered from Major Depressive Disorder, PTSD and accompanying anxiety disorders.  Despite the obstacles this has caused in my life, I managed to complete college, graduating summa cum laude from Auburn University.  But absolutely everything was such a struggle for me, and unfortunately I was in the small percentage of people who aren't helped by more traditional psychotropic medications. My psychiatrist decided to try me on an opiate. They often help when other medications don't, and were actually created for use against depression.  My doctor started me on a small dose of oxycodone and it worked for me. It was an epiphany; I understood for the FIRST time in my life why people get out of bed in the morning. There was a small problem for me that I felt a bit "drugged." And also I knew that I would build up a tolerance to the medicine. All of this was about three years ago. And then for the first time in my life I heard of kratom and was made very curious. I told my doctor about it and he researched it thoroughly, as did I. What caught and held my interest was that this wasn't a drug that you got "high" from. In fact, all the literature made it clear that if one was looking to get "high" or "get off" or any other terms used by drug users, that one should look to other substances. So, with my doctor's consent, I ordered my first kratom. It worked for me better than I could have dreamed. I had all the positive effects that the oxycodone had provided, but didn't have any of that sense of being a bit "drugged." I continued to use kratom, and the positive effects continued. Or, maybe it would be more accurate to say that my lack of negative effects continued: my depression and anxiety were controlled for the first time in my life. I had an ability to function that I had never experienced. I can't find words to express what this meant to me, to have lived an entire life colored with a nightmarish quality that never ceased, and to finally, finally, finally have the nightmare end. Of course I was heartbroken when Alabama decided to ban Kratom. My doctor put me back on oxycodone and it does help, but I don't like the feeling of being somewhat drugged. And I think of the millions of people who have died from opiate abuse, literally millions as I'm sure you know. And here is a substance that has allowed countless people to kick their heroin addiction or prescription drug addiction. And all without any effects of "being high, or intoxicated." It doesn't cause any of those type feelings, and if you doubt this, I would suggest you try it. Coffee causes more of a noticeable change in consciousness. And most importantly, IT DOESN'T KILL. I believe maybe a handful of users have died, and those had other drugs in their system. I am one of the people who believe marijuana should be legalized; it is my fervent hope, especially after watching my husband die of the scourge that is cancer. But I understand that much is debatable in the question of marijuana legalization and there are pros and cons. Having used kratom and seen it's effects made me realize that it's remaining legal is a much more clear-cut decision than marijuana, and it is definitely safer in all ways than alcohol. I thank you sincerely for taking time to read of me and my life and considering my thoughts on the question of kratom.

documents.commentText:
Hello,
I'm a 40 year-old graduate student in psychology and a regular kratom user.  It shocked me greatly when I learned of the DEA's proposed ban on this safe and beneficial herb.  There is no substantiated evidence that kratom poses any dangers whatsoever.  In fact, it's quite the opposite scenario.  Kratom has been helping people to discontinue their use of substances which are known to be harmful.  How can a helpful herb be misconstrued as being a threat?  It simply doesn't make any sense to list kratom among Schedule I drugs, as it does not fall into the categorical requirements necessary for such restrictions.  I have been using kratom for several years and have never felt the need to increase dosage, which would be reflective of an addiction.  Likewise, I've never experienced any cravings or withdrawal symptoms when I haven't taken kratom.  Although I am not in the medical field, it seems apparent that with further research kratom may be found to have clear medicinal benefits.  From personal experience, kratom has helped me to maintain balance with my clinically diagnosed bipolar condition.  Additionally, I used to struggle with alcohol abuse but kratom has helped me tremendously to maintain abstinence from drinking.  I do not know why kratom has been so helpful for people dealing with substance abuse issues, but the evidence to this effect is overwhelming.  Given the current opioid "crisis" in this country, and the DEA's clear directive to combat opioid addiction and abuse, it seems highly contradictory to ban an inexpensive and easily grown natural herb which aides in the depletion of opioid use.  My biggest fear is that because kratom is a natural supplement, and cannot be patented by big pharmaceutical companies, that the suggested Scheduling was a means to potentiate financial gains for companies looking to market pharmaceutically derived opiate substitutes.  This circumstance would be a gross misuse of authority and a direct violation of consumer's rights.  Kratom should continue to be legally available for anyone who chooses to utilize its benefits, and for scientists to further research its medical potential.  There is no valid proof that kratom poses any threat to those who use it.  I cannot believe that this is even an issue!  There have been well over 20,000 documented opioid related deaths in this country over the past year.  It's completely irrational, and also dangerous, to prevent excess to a harmless opioid alternative that is saving people's lives!!  

Sincerely,
Daniel Bailey

documents.commentText: I have a few comments to make on the validity and efficacy of the DEA's intent to schedule Kratom. I think it commendable that the DEA is considering public comment on this plant derived material. I think Kratom in its natural unrefined form can act as a genuine pain killer without the addictive traits of other opiates; and while I certainly do not endorse the idea of any addictive behavior as being good for humanity, it would seem that a naturally occurring substance like Kratom could aid in opiate withdrawal and mitigation. My concern is that the FDA might also misjudge the benefits of a substance like this and error on the side of corporate privilege and regulation. Perhaps an issue like this might also be dealt with more judiciously on a State level. It also has to be said that people misuse and abuse commonplace devices and chemicals on a daily basis as they have the freedom to do so. Our social responsibility is to encourage and promote positive and life-affirming behavior. In summation I would say that the use of Kratom in its naturally occurring unrefined form could be of great benefit to opiate addicts as well as the medical establishment, without the stigma of contraband being attached. Please consider carefully the option of relegating this to the States for oversight.....Sincerely.....Greg S.

documents.commentText: Kratom (scientific name: Mitragyna Speciosa) is one of the only things that helps to reduce my pain from migraines, Fibromyalgia, arthritis, and other chronic pain diseases/conditions that I suffer from daily. In the past, every preventative treatment and rescue treatment for my migraines and body pain that pharmaceutical companies have available did not work for me at all. Every form of alternative therapy/treatment produced little to no effect at reducing my pain (Chiropractic care, massage therapy, exercise, Acupuncture, etc.). The one and only thing that did work (in the past) was strong, narcotic pain medications. I have been on 80% of the different strong opiate pain medications currently on the market (both long acting and short acting opiates). While most did work to reduce my pain and make me functional (but never completely took my pain away), they came with a whole host of bad side effects: sedation, nausea, constipation, tiredness, rebound headaches, itching, and many more. The negative side effects took me from functional pain-wise to not functional because of side effects alone. Also, if you have to go without pain medication for any reason or length of time (if people are taking it daily like I was), the withdrawal side effects are HORRIBLE and unbearable (especially with the pain returning full force on top of withdrawal side effects)! I became fed up of dealing with those negative side effects and the risk of overdose and death, and I decided to try another alternative therapy. That's when I found Kratom. When I tried it, it worked in the same way as pain medication but with less side effects and it's an all natural, herbal therapy. Kratom is NOT an opiate pain medication. It is an herb that acts on opiate receptors despite the fact that it's not an opiate. Kratom's cousins are the coffee plant and Ginseng. I was amazed and totally stunned that I had not found this herbal medicine years ago!! I was able to stop taking traditional opiate pain medication completely and switch straight over to Kratom. There are different strains of Kratom that allow for more energy, focus, motivation, or more in the direction of relaxation, stress relief, better sleep, pain relief, etc. I loved (and love) that there were (are) so many different strains so I can mix and match to meet my needs for each individual day and each individual dose. Some days I need more energy, and some nights I need better sleep. With Kratom, that is exactly what I get - pain relief and many other health benefits! I have been taking Kratom for one year and six months now. When I found out that this miracle treatment I have been taking for 18 months was going to become illegal, I was horrified! Kratom is herbal and all natural. Why would a natural and safe herb be banned (when there's no risk of harm when it's taken correctly)? Are coffee and ginseng (Kratom's cousins) going to be made illegal, too? Kratom should NOT be banned or made illegal! The alternative to Kratom for me and for many others is strong opiate pain killers that have the potential for overdose and death. I CANNOT go back to taking pain pills (or other pain medication)! I NEED Kratom daily in order to function, so I'm not bedridden, and so I can be a productive member of society. I can't imagine what that will do to me if it does get taken away soon. My life would literally go out the window. Kratom, when taken correctly, has NO potential for overdose or death. Narcotic pain medication CAN kill you, and it already HAS killed many thousands of people from accidental overdoses. If Kratom does become illegal, I will have to return to opiate pain medication (if I am even able to find a doctor that will prescribe it, which is rare), and I'll hate every minute of the bad side effects that I get from them. Please keep Kratom legal for myself and for many other people like me who have found relief through Kratom (for various health issues or ailments). I need Kratom to remain available to me, and I really hope you don't take that away from me and from so many others! Please research this herbal medicine more and allow more time before making a misinformed decision that will cause suffering to thousands upon thousands of people who depend on it. This has the potential to successfully treat many ailments in the future better than any pill can, but in order to do that, it must remain legal and open to the public. Please do not ban Kratom. Don't make it illegal, and please don't schedule it either. It should remain available to everyone. Thank you for your time and consideration!

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
At a time when opiate overdoses are at a record high, it is of utmost importance to make sure Kratom is legal and accessible to those who need it. Kratom is an opioid and can help to maintain opiate cravings. If someone is going to relapse from heroin, it would be much safer if Kratom is available to that person as a non lethal alternative. Making Kratom illegal takes away that choice and increases the chances that someone will die.

Kratom is an non lethal alternative to lethal and addictive drugs. 
Many opiate addictions occur after one has been prescribed them for pain. 
If Kratom works for a patient to manage pain, there is no reason they need to turn to a potentially lethal and addictive substance. 

It is painfully obvious that Kratom is a multi million dollar industry. Yes, millions of dollars not going to the opiate drug companies who kill thousands every year. 

Kratom is a plant. How can we actually claim to be a free people when we cannot even decide for ourselves which plants to grow and possess. 
If you want Kratom illegal, you hate freedom.

It is time to abolish the DEA. The DEA's existence has, since its inception, been based on racist and misinformed drug policy. The DEA works to protect big business, capitalism and white supremacy at the expense of people's livelihood and health. Their decisions are not based on science or the good will of the people, but on maintaining a complacent, crony capitalist society ruled by a rich business elite.

The DEA serves to protect the power of the elite by attempting to limit the cognitive experiences of citizens by dictating how one can and cannot alter his consciousness. If the substance serves the capitalist paradigm (coffee) or aids in the complacency of the citizens (alcohol) then the substance is allowed. If the substance threatens the market of synthetic, patented drugs, then the substance is illegal (cannabis and soon to be Kratom). 

If the substance allows an individual to experience paradigms of thought unconventional or disadvantageous to the the capitalist, white imperialist paradigm, then the substance is illegal. (Psychedelics & cannabis) The DEA is so concerned with this as to even limit the plants and organic molecules which a "free" man is allowed to cultivate, possess, and consume. In fact, every one of us is breaking this law, as we all possess dimethyltryptamine in our brains.

documents.commentText:
I am a 37 year old career professional, a member of church and community, a college graduate and a law abiding citizen.  I do not use drugs and have no criminal record.  I have been a Kratom consumer for the past 4 years.  

 I first learned about Kratom through my brother.  He was a member of a group of Iraq and Afghanistan war vets who've  suffered greatly from PTSD.  He joined the group after losing many of his friends to suicide and drugs and feeling his depression deepen, he was afraid he would soon be on that path.   He told me of the success of Kratom amongst his group and with himself. 

My father has been using Kratom to ease his Parkinson's symptoms.   Something that runs in my family.   When I begin to experience severe tremors and severe panic attacks I reached out to my doctor.   I was put on a multitude of different medicines, some making me worse and all having terrible side effects. When going off the medicine the symptoms would return far worse.  Eventually my work life begin to become effected.  My personal life was effected and my spirits were at an all time low. I tried a strict regimen of exercise and diet and it would help only so much.  The only thing that seemed to help was alcohol.  My family was concerned and told me about Kratom.   Compiled with a proper diet and exercise I've made great progress.  I have spent the past three years doing and accomplishing more than I have in the 15 before.  I went from drinking 3 glasses of wine a night to drinking no more than 3 a year.  

There seems to be a large degree of misinformation on Kratom from "lazy journalism" or internet articles written for shock value.  My family and myself have experienced no side effects or negative traits from Kratom use.  I've been in the best health in years and my check- ups are stellar.  Kratom does not get us "high". To many ignorant articles make comparison to opiates-  sorry but it's very far from the truth.  If anything Kratom has an effect no different than coffee meets a dose of NyQuil.   After a few times even this effect is subdued.  

Why the concern over Kratom? Those of us who are consumers are dumbfounded with this.  It has helped so many in such a positive way.

My life now is a full time 50 hr a week job that I have maintained for 8 years. My days off I'll hike 12-14 miles, surf for half a day, hunting during season, or spending every dollar on our new house & gardening. I've been married for 3 years, with a child on the way.

documents.commentText: Hello, my name is Audrey. I am 59 yrs old. I suffer from degenerative disc disease, osteoarthritis,  diabetes, cardiovascular disease and have had five surgeries.  I have had wrist dead bone removed, 2 fusions on my cervical spine from L2-L7, lumbar fusion from L2-S1 and a complete knee replacement. All of these surgeries since 2009. 28th the lower back fusion just one yr ago. The fusion is not complete and so far is a failed fusion. The bone is not growing over the surgery area. I love in constant pain. Even tho these surgeries have help keep me walking I can no longer work. I cannot sit or stand for very long as the pain is debilitating. I have depended on opiate pain meds for close to ten yrs along with other drugs for other medical illnesses. I have always made sure to take them as prescribed and under the care of a pain management Dr. I decided to start looking for something more natural to help stop or at least control my pain. That is when I found Kratom. I take one to two teaspoons a day and that is all it takes. It takes the edge off of my pain and I am able to function better physically. It also has helped me keep from feeling depressed.  I have been using it for about 8 months. It has been a God send. I have gotten off of pain meds for a month at a time at different times during those 8 months. I am not dependent on the opiates anymore. When I would run short on my pain meds because when I had flare ups of pain I took more pain meds. Kratom literally stops all withdrawal effects from not having the pain meds. It helps so much that is has become a daily routine to take kratom.  It truly is a natural miracle of nature. I have never felt I needed more than I take now. I have not had any negative side effects or withdrawal from Kratom. It works without the dangers of using opiates. I don't get a "high" feeling. I just feel good and can function better and more focused. If the DEA makes Kratom a drug it will take away my quality of life. I still take opiate pain meds only if my pain levelvgoes up to an 8-10 level which it does occasionally. I am a responsible person and take all my meds as scripted. The opiates have increased at times over the yrs. I also have found when I don't take the opiates my joint pain and morning aches go away.  Kratom has helped give me my life back. Please do not take that away from me. It is so much healthier, in my opinion as a user, than opiate pain meds. The long term use of pain meds can be crippling. documents.commentText:
I'm a 58 year old, Mother of 3 grown boys.   I suffered a terrible fall 20 years ago and was prescribed opiates, neurological drugs and antidepressants over the course of a decade.  I was given Fentanyl patches after being diagnosed with severe fibromyalgia and nerve damage.  None of those drugs did much to releive my pain and I ended up with a miserable cycle of opiate addiction.  I don't know what was worse, the fibromyalgia symptoms or the pain that comes from opiate use and opiate withdrawal.  A few years ago I saw a youtube video where a man kicked heroin using kratom tea.  Since then his life has turned around.  I thought, if it works for him it cld work for me.

I had heard about Seboxen and Methodon as the only pharmaceutical treatment for withdrawal but they are just as addictive as opiates and the withdrawal is just as bad in many people's experience.  

I decided to try kratom tea.

I slowly decreased the use of the Fentanyl patch as much as I cld stand.  Then I started drinking the tea.  It helped me sooo much with the hot and cold flashes, the shakes, the anxiety. I took a few weeks for me to feel free of withdrawal symptoms and I was overjoyed.  

I also experienced that I no longer wanted coffee in the morning and that my lifelong battle with anxiety attacks had decreased.  The fibromyalgia is not gone but I am so much better now.  I like my kratom tea like other people like their coffee.  

I also have several friends who are Vietnam Veterans who have found relief from the terrible side effects they had on multiple pharmaceutical cocktails they were prescribed and now all they do is drink kratom tea instead.  

Please DO NOT BAN kratom tea.  It's simply a leaf.  Thank you.   Sincerely, Sierra Jean Bailey

documents.commentText: Thank you for taking the time to read this. This is the most important message I have ever wrote. Peoples quality of life and mortality are at stake here. I spent 15 years suffering beyond belief with zero help from my doctors. I tried to get help and they turned me away many times. The first time they told me that I should be on oxycontin or morphine, but because of my age they did not want to make me a chronic pain patient, and left me wishing I was dead because of how much I was hurting. I am a disabled veteran who is battling severe pain from a horrible car accident, PTSD, arthritus, social anxiety borderline panic disorder, epilepsy, and something they can't even figure out that makes every inch of my body hurt non stop. When you have an illness they can't even find in a time when opiate abuse is out of control as a young man getting pain medication is impossible where I live and you either have to find relief on your own or try not to kill yourself because your life is endless torture. I can't even write this without crying because I am suffering so bad. I am expected to love on close to $20 per day for social security so I can't even afford the medication I need, but at least I get some days of relief. My doctors solution to my problems they can't figure out was to misdiagnose me and put me on so many pills I was bed ridden and having seizures daily. Doctors are failing people like me and if I was not religious I probably would have killed myself a long time ago, but I have faith I will get better. Please do not give us a death sentence or take away the only thing making our quality of life bearable. God put these plants on the earth for people suffering and nobody should just destroy peoples lives that are hard enough already. My body responds well to natural substances, but these chemicals from the docotor have side effects that are very hard on very ill people like myself. If you decide to go through with banning this harmless God given medication you will be directly killing and destroying thousands of lives and I beg you to reconsider. I have got to a point in my life where I will survive with or without it but I was not always this strong and many others are not. I have the utmost respect for you. I was military police and I love my country and support law enforcement. Please consider that ther are many people like me who are not trying to get high and do not use recreational drugs. I am suffering with nowhere to turn. I had to be my own doctor and using natural herbs I feel my life has been saved. I am scared and helpless and my quality of life is in your hands now. Please do not send me back to the horrible situation I was in for the last 15 years. Imagine suffering 15 years having the feeling liek you have a flu that never goes away with pain from head to toe after having shattered your hip and leg getting hit by a truck on my driver side door going about 55 mph. It feels to me like nobody cares about us and I have been forgotten and left to die. I would be homeless if I didn't have people helping me like many other disabled and veterans. We have enough on our plates without having a medication that replaced 15 pills that were destroying my liver and body just snatched away for no good reason. I know there will be some people who abuse it, but people abuse glue by sniffing it and we do not punish everyone who uses glue because of a small amount of fools. It has and will never kill anyone who is not on a coctail of other deadly chemicals. I will respect whatever choice you make on this, and I know God will take vare of me no matter what, but I worry about everybody else who is not mentally strong as I have just recently achieved. The truth of it is that alcohol and cigarettes are way more dangerous and deadly but those are ignored while recreational and not a medicine helping the most unfortunate disabled people. Kratom never killed anyone from lung cancer or psorosis of the liver. It never made someone beat thier wive or hurt anyone. Kratom has a slight euphoria and makes you feel good, but nothing close to the pills from the doctor that you can overdose on or be high on.  Tylonol is more dangerous and would kill you faster. I know your agency is not out to hurt us and you have already put a hold on this ban. The facts will show that the ban is a bad idea and would be a law that helps nobody and hurts or kills thousands. I am confident you would not make a decision like that and I thank you for taking time to reconsider it. You holding off on the ban and listening to our stories really means a lot to me as not many people or institutions care about the unfortunate these days. God bless you all.  I will pray for your safety out in the field and pray for God to guide you to make the right decision.

documents.commentText:
I have suffered from debilitating endometriosis for years. I didn't want to be on pain meds anymore, as they were making me into a zombie, and I did not want to be addicted to anything. When I found Kratom, I was able to immediately stop the opiates, and overnight. No chaos, no drama, no issues at all. A teaspoon in the morning, and one mid afternoon, and I had my quality of life back. 

Fast forward to later years, and it also helped me tremendously, when I had to face the illness and loss of my mother in 2015. There was much upheaval in our lives that even included a move out of state. If I had not been able to manage my pain and health with kratom, I don't know where I'd be right now. 

I have used Kratom with NO problem or issue at all for 5 years. While there is a sense of well being, and it can uplift the mood, it is SO mild and the thought of it being considered evil or dangerous is honestly ridiculous. The DEA keeps citing deaths involving Kratom. To my knowledge, every single death involved OTHER substances that were indeed dangerous, and not the Kratom itself. 

I am in extreme fear to think of how the prisons will fill up with people like me, who are not criminals or druggies (I don't even smoke or drink). So many of us have quietly lived our lives, with Kratom. The absolute destruction this will bring to good people, should be a crime itself.

It is horrifying to see the government so willing to gamble with the lives of so many, but I am grateful for this comment period and the chance to be heard. Kratom is safe. The fact that the emergency rooms are not filled to the brim with those of us who have used it, for a long time, should speak loudly.

I am fully prepared to face my future without kratom, as I refuse to become a felon over committing no actual crime than managing my own pain with a plant related to coffee. But it is my sincere hope and prayer that common sense will prevail, as the truth about Kratom, and all it has done to help people suffering, will shine through and lead your decision in this important matter.

documents.commentText: Hi my name is Julian and I am 30 years old. I work as a manager and head of maintenance. I have a degree in engineering from Penn State Behrend. For the record, I am fully against scheduling of Kratom by the DEA. I have been using Kratom for two years now. I use it after a physically-demanding day at work to help me relax. I also have chronic depression and social anxiety, which I've had since early highschool. I have found a personal correlation between the time I was in a terrible car accident in 2006 which caused a tooth to die and also the herniation of my third lumbar in my spine. I have been forced to use everything ranging from opioids, muscle relaxers, and pain creams to counteract the severe physical problems and discomfort associated with the accident. I stopped using pain pills due to nausea and disorientation, which made it extremely difficult for me to do my job. I began researching alternatives to SSRI's and pain medications and concluded that Kratom was the safest to test run. I have since been alleviated of my social anxiety to a point that I am not confined to my home after work and able to work and interact more easily/comfortably with my co-workers. Furthermore, I have been able to move more easily and have a more comfortable range of motion since beginning my use of Kratom. I have not noticed any nausea as a result of this use, either. It is the most beneficial substance I have come to use as a result of my car accident. documents.commentText:
Dear DEA:

Please do not put this plant on the Controlled Substances Schedules, and certainly not Schedule I.  Not only does banning Kratom extend and expand the ineffective war on drugs while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it, but it has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports Kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

So many people, including many members of my own family have struggled with addiction.  Kratom has and can be used effectively to help addicts wean or quit opioids entirely.  If the DEA schedules this plant, all promising scientific studies on Kratom's role in opioid treatment will immediately shut down.  Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

The side effects of Kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.  It does not belong on the schedules.

Please do not decide to schedule this helpful and very effective plant.

documents.commentText:
The thought of such a beneficial herb being placed on an a Schedule is unfathomable to me. I get that the Registry exists to keep our citizens safe from dangerous drugs like Bath Salts, or to keep things like Heroin out of the hands of children. These things are public health hazards. Deadly. Made for no other purpose than to intoxicate and addict the populace.

Kratom is none of these things. The people that call Poison Control and claim that they overdosed on Kratom are the same people that have panic attacks from smoking marijuana, or from drinking too much alcohol. Kratom has never, and so long as it remains unadulterated, WILL never kill or harm a user. We have centuries of empirical evidence as to its benign nature from the peoples of Southeast Asia who use it daily as a medicine, as a mild stimulant (it is closely related to the coffee family) and in religious ceremonies. 

Unlike alcohol and other legal drugs, Kratom doesn't make you "high." It doesn't give you a "buzz." It doesn't alter your conscience. It can promote a sense of relaxation and is very effective as a pain killer. I personally use it for the latter. After years on prescription pain killers, my tolerance was such that with the amount of pills I took, my liver would have eventually given out on me. Thank GOD for Kratom.

If you shortsightedly banish Kratom to the netherworld of illegal opiates, you will see an uptake in fatal overdoses, of an amount unlike any the civilized world has ever known. We're already in the throes of an epidemic of narcotic drug abuse; it would seem to reason that your agency would PROMOTE an all natural, safe alternative to such drugs rather than hinder its use. But then, reason has never stood in the way of hysterical knee-jerk legislation, has it? I pray, for this country, that your agency refuses to impose this death sentence on the people who trust you to protect them. 

Best to yours,  
Robert Hubbard

documents.commentText:
Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine do not pose an imminent threat, and it would be a mistake to classify it them as Schedule I restricted substances. The plant known as kratom has a long history of human use, with a relative scarcity of health issues presented. The potential therapeutic and medicinal  properties in the relief of opioid addiction are too compelling to ignore. Those effects deserve further medical study. Schedule I restrictions are far too limiting on research, preventing us from understanding the mechanisms by which this chemical interacts with the human body. 

It is my suspicion that, upon further subsequent study, it will be found that the reported fatalities and other harmful reactions to mitragynine have been exceptional rather than commonplace. If the goal of restricting legal access to such a substance is truly to act in the best interests of the public, we should not react in ignorance and fear by banning use of such substances without understanding them. Instead, the government should see it as their mandate to protect the people by pushing efforts forward in intense study of beneficial and detrimental effects, and only then acting based on accurate knowledge. 

I urge the DEA to consider studies such as the following:

 Kruegel AC, Gassaway MM, Kapoor A, Vradi A, Majumdar S, Filizola M, Javitch JA, Sames D. 
Synthetic and Receptor Signaling Explorations of the Mitragyna Alkaloids: Mitragynine as an Atypical Molecular Framework for Opioid Receptor Modulators. 
J Am Chem Soc. 2016 Jun 01;138(21):6754-64.

and 

 Singh D, Narayanan S, Vicknasingam B. 
Traditional and non-traditional uses of Mitragynine (Kratom): A survey of the literature. 
Brain Res Bull. 2016 May 28;.

These recent studies are the kind of thing we should pursue, until such time that conclusive studies establish a credible and genuine threat to the wellbeing of the public. If we as a country and culture are willing to allow individuals to choose to engage in tobacco use, despite the known harmful effects of smoking and addictive properties of nicotene, then it stands to reason that a substance such as kratom (which has narrow usage and beneficial properties) deserves similar treatment.

documents.commentText: I am contacting you to request that your agency recommend against scheduling this plant and/or its components. I believe there is a need for further research into the beneficial qualities of this substance. The leaf of Mitragyna Speciosa Korth appear to contain alkaloids which have beneficial effects for many medical conditions. The limited research available suggests that the beneficial effects of this plant are not a result of any single alkaloid, but are due to the cumulative effects of the naturally occurring combination. There is a need and an opportunity for more research into the medical potential of this plant which would be severely curtailed by the proposed entry in Schedule 1. There are also many testimonials of chronic pain patients who have experienced an improved quality of life due to this plant and its unique alkaloid profile. I would also like to clarify that the vast majority of deaths involving Kratom were due to a single criminal action, the adulteration of the brand Krypton Kratom with the chemical O-Desmethyltramadol, and that several others were Polydrug combinations which would likely have been fatal regardless of Kratom ingestion. There has not been a single death backed by forensic evidence that Kratom or the alkaloids in Kratom were the specific cause of death. There are documented side effects as with any substance. I believe that allowing this plant and/or it's component alkaloids to be scheduled at this time would be a disservice to millions of American citizens who could benefit from further research and development of medical applications.

documents.commentText:
At 23 years old I was sent to pain management for degenerative disc disease in my lower back. My pain was real and a lot of the time I couldn't stand on my own two feet for too long unfortunately. But instead of being sent to a back doctor I was sent to pain management. Physical therapy could have greatly helped my condition. At 23 years old I didn't really understand what pain management was even when they laid out the rules to me. For about four months I was fine on the medications I was on. The pain medicine helped and I didn't even use the muscle relaxers. However, my body began to grow used to the medicine and I needed more with each dose to feel the pain relieving effects. The first time I went to the hospital it was because of a fall that happened when I was outside on my stairs. I didn't tell them I was on pain medicine from a PM doctor because I wanted more pain medication. This became a slippery slope that landed me in the ER a lot. 

For about 2 years I continued this behavior even after my PM doctor found out and kicked me out of his practice. I was dangerously addicted to the pain medicine. It took over my life and when I wasn't able to have pain medicine I was a mess. I couldn't cope with the way I felt or didn't feel. When finally it completely destroyed the relationship between me and my mom enough that she told me to get help or leave I realized that my life wasn't my own anymore. The pain medicine controlled me. 

I went to a rehab facility in Reseda California called the Discovery House. And it was a good place to be at first. They were helpful and firm about getting me up off of my feet. But, the first time I took suboxone which is a government approved medicine to help with coming off of pain medicine it felt like I got high off of 30 percocet pills. I got violently sick to my stomach which lasted for about 12 hours. And when I came off of the suboxone a few weeks later I went through the worst withdrawal I could imagine. My skin hurt when air would touch it, my whole entire body was aching, and the only relief I ever got was sitting in the sun. Eventually I was released from the rehab, but at the worst time possible. I had a management position in the area at a retail shop in a mall and the rehab people could no longer house me. My mom did not want me home yet because she wasn't comfortable with that idea and she had moved. So I was forced to live with a friend and that situation went from okay to bad very quickly. Within a few days of being there I was already relapsing and by the time I left I was back on pain medicine because of the stress. Thankfully I went and lived with my older sister in Oakland. She helped me get on my feet again and taught me how to be a very responsible woman. I got two jobs and moved into my first place by myself. But even with two jobs I couldn't afford a $700 a month room and I ended up going to live with my brother and his girlfriend in Rancho Cordova. I again relapsed when I found pain medicine in their bathroom and finally I got to go home to my mom. 

I was still in the middle of a relapse unfortunately and took more pain medicine that I had at her house from my previous surgeries. But, it was then at this point that I tried Kratom. It took more than a few purchases of this magical herb for me to find the one that worked the best. When I did find the one that worked the best for me it was like such relief to find something that worked and helped. My cravings were gone, and yet the energy that I loved from taking pain medicine I got from Kratom. It made me feel better emotional and sometimes physically. 

However I did end up having to go back on pain medicine due to endometriosis that had been diagnosed two years back. I was on pain medicine for about a month and a half before my surgery. I had a partial hysterectomy and the pain was really bad after surgery. I ended up going back onto suboxone to try and ease coming off the pain medicine, but I again went through the WORST withdrawal that my mom now had to witness. She watched me through agony as I got off suboxone. And finally, after moving to Idaho from Mississippi I started to use Kratom on a weekly basis. Hello my name is Heather Jones I just wanted to write a comment on here to tell you how Kratom has positively effected my life, I started taking pain pills at the age of 18 I am now 26 years old, I didn't stop taking pain pills until April of this year I would take on average between 10 and 20 a day, I could never be satisfied and never could hold down a job so I became an adult entertainer, these pills were always avoiding me from living my life to my full potential that always knew I had, I had a really hard life growing up and I always felt like something was missing so I always resorted to drugs to the fill the void, one day I was detoxing really bad because I just couldn't find any of what I needed and my friends offered me half of a teaspoon of Kratom at the time I laughed at it I didn't think that it was going to be anything spectacular but when I took it I just noticed that my withdrawals completely went away, my pain wasn't as evident my depression had went away and I found a reason to live again ever since that day I put down pills and never pick them back up again, I have a full time job now and haven't missed a day, I am going full time at the end of this month which means benefits and vacation days, I have NEVER BEEN SO PROUD OF MYSELF in my ENTIRE LIFE, I've been taking Kratom for around 7 months now and have not touch the pills since in the months forward since being introduced to this amazing herb, my addiction stemed from wanting to feel loved and which my parents who were also taking around the same amount of pain pills I was, I introduced this herb to them two months ago, they of course laughed at first but one day when they didn't have any I offered them some of mine, I said if it doesn't work then you don't have to take it anymore, I know they saw the difference in me so they decided to try it, well I got my family back! My dream of having my real family has finally came true, I'm asking you please don't do this, please don't make it a controlled substance it's going to destroy our lives and thousands of others, Kratom does not give you an extreme High it just gives you a positive outlook that everything's going to be okay please please consider not scheduling this. Heather Jones

documents.commentText: My name is Laura Rice Crumhorn and I am a 56 year old female elementary school librarian.  I strongly oppose the addition of this herbal supplement to the list of Schedule I drugs that include heroin and LSD.  Kratom is nothing like those substances. It smells like tea!  I began using it this past summer when someone in a research group I was in mentioned they used it for pain.  I have had chonic back and neck pain for some time;  I did some quick research and had some kratom delivered to my door.  It took a bit of responsible experimentation, but I finally got my dosage right.  I only take a 1/2 tsp blend in the morning and about 3/4 tsp at night.  I have never had the back pain diagnosed, but that 1/2 tsp makes it disappear for hours.  I have been prescribed clonazepam for anxiety- I have a husband with pancreatic cancer and a daughter with a lot of legal problems.  I had no idea kratom would work to alleviate anxiety, but it seems to do just that.  I also had no idea it would decrease my desire for alcohol, but thankfully, it seems to do that as well.  All of these effects occur, for me, on a sub-perceptual level;  I didn't realize I was pain free until the kratom wore off late in the afternoon and the pain came back.  I have had to do my job in spite of some bad news on my mind more than once this year, and some aspect of this kratom seems to help me focus on the task at hand and not let my brain wander down a sad rabbit hole.  As I said, I am an elementary school librarian- I take a small dose right before I leave for work.  If this was as bad as heroin or LSD, would I be able to read and converse with little people and parents within an hour of ingestion?  NO!  I feel like this herb makes me a better person somehow.  I'm just . . .nicer.  It's not addicting.  I have run out the door without it a couple of times, and the only thing that happens is the pain returns.  I don't pretend to know how it works.  That's why we need research.  I hope you'll consider research over a ban.  This herb can help a lot of people.  It has certainly helped me.

documents.commentText: I am a recovered heroin addict. I started using because of deep depression that wasn't getting the right treatment from doctors and pills.  KRATOM has helped support my ability to stay clean from opiates. Since I started taking Kratom a year ago, my quality of life has improved. Before that I was struggling with staying clean. I'm balanced again and the urge to use has deminished. It's unbelievable how many addicts didn't know about this product before the possible ban. KRATOM has saved lives! It has helped save mine! It's a safe treatment with a ceiling level. You don't get high, but it does offer relief. If you take too much the worst that has happened is nausea. I refuse to be put on toxic suboxen. Suboxone is an addiction in itself. The shot that's available might take away the ability to get high, but it does NOT take away the urge and longing for relief. People continue to try to use when they're on the shot because the relief just isn't there. Counting down the days when it might wear off and give you the window to take matters into your own hands. I have not used Heroin or pills or had the need to since I started taking KRATOM twice a day. 10 grams total for the day. This is my body, I should be allowed to use a leaf from a tree to help with my depression and anxiety. God knows I've tried everything else legal and illegal.  If this becomes regulated though, other users will lose the chance to save themselves. Not everyone wants to turn to a doctor for help. Addicts aren't happy to be addicts, it's shameful, and telling someone is the hardest part.  Not everyone has the money to see a doctor for it either. Please keep this available to the public. I believe after all this publicity of the leaf, the opiate epidemic will dramatically drop
