documents.commentText: Hi DEA.  I just felt that I should comment on the kratm situation while I have the chance to.  I have used it in the past to deal with chronic pain (severe sciatica) And have found it very useful in dealing with that pain, as a substitution for the infinitely more addictive and destructive opioid painkillers.  I don't currently use it and feel no need to or cravings for it.  It also at the time helped me to overcome an intense alcohol addiction that was beginning to take hold of my life.  It seems to be counterintuitive to ban kratom if the DEA is so worried about the opioid epidemic, as kratom is an excellent tool in combating opioid addictions, as well as others.  One could argue that kratom is a "gateway drug" to opioids, but this argument is absurd, there are no studies to back it up, and it is just based on assumption and conjecture.  People who use kratom are using it because they specifically do not want to use powerful prescription opioids.  I hope you will reconsider scheduling kratom, as it has overwhelmingly impacted people's lives in positive ways.

documents.commentText: I am writing this in the hopes that a mother will be on the receiving end. I will keep it short and sweet. Kratom has saved my life. I developed a dangerous physical dependence on the pain medications prescribed to me, but had little to no relief from my pain. My life was in a very ugly downward spiral. I was on 80-120 mgs of Percocet every day. Until I discovered Kratom. Kratom helps with my pain a great deal without making me feel drugged, or high. I can actually function as a person. I'm so afraid of losing what I have gained from Kratom if it is banned. Right now I am able to take care of myself, my mother who has leukemia (CML), my grandmother who has esophageal cancer stage 4, and my grandfather who has pulmonary disease. Without Kratom I would not be able to care for them. Kratom has allowed me to become a better person, a better mother, daughter, granddaughter, etc. I'm terrified to think of where I will be, where my family will be, if it is banned. Please, allow us to continue to be productive members of society.

documents.commentText:
My name is Ian Seniff, a married 33 year old father of two who works in the software industry as an Inside Sales/Customer Success Representative.  I oppose the DEA putting kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances.

My story is as follows. Several years ago, shortly after the birth of my son, I  began to develop  pain in my check, neck, hip and back.  Thanks to inheriting arthritis and joint issues from my mothers side of the family, gradually the pain increased, then increased some more.  The pain made sleep next to impossible and exercise was completely impossible.  When my son turned one, I was up to 320 lbs from 225, I slept maybe 4 hours a night, and was essentially a miserable human being.  

During this year, when I did attempt to treat this pain, the medicine made things worse.  Anti-inflammatory medicine led to severe gastrointestinal issues which led to me taking about a hundred dollars of antacids a month.  I was also given prescription pain medicine (hydrocodone) which helped the pain but left me inebriated making work and interaction with my child impossible.

I also drank, a lot.  I am not proud of this but when you feel like I did you want to feel pretty much any other way possible.  

In fear of my lifer and life, I went in search of something else to help.  I went to the internet where I discovered kratom. I bought some, tried it and honestly felt better than I had in years.  My pain wasn't gone, but it was manageable.  The best part was I was clear headed.  I didn't feel "high", more like I had a cup of coffee minus the jitters.  After a week of using a small dose, I started my life over.  I began to exercise, which I didn't think possible.  I could play with my son.  Literally play, not just lay on the floor while trying to avoid not getting jumped on.  

After a year I was down to 260 lbs.  Not perfect, but in a state where I didn't need daily dosages of anything - no kratom, pills, alcohol, or coffee.  I felt good. 

Now that life was pain lessened (not free because I doubt that is possible) my wife and I were able to give my son a sister.  Something we wanted to do right after he turned one but had to wait three additional years to due thanks to how I felt.  

At this point ,I save kratom for a maybe 6-8 times a week when pain starts taking its toll on me.  The rest of the time I can just "grin and bear it" but the thought of it being illegal is very frightening to me. I am not saying kratom is responsible for my life change, but without it, I don't think that first week of the gym would have happened.  Right now there are many people suffering like I was and if kratom is added to the schedule 1 list, they might not have that catalyst to change either.  

Thank you.

documents.commentText: Reading these comments really breaks my heart. It is especially sad seeing some of the negative comments referring to users as junkies and of the like. The healthcare community has slowly realized that addiction is a mental disorder and not a moral failure. I, like many others on here, have discovered Kratom to help me stay off opiates. Consider all of the positive comments and stories on how it saved lives. There are many cultures that have used Kratom for centuries. Like everything else, there are positives and negatives to taking it. In a day where our country faces an enormous epidemic, taking away natural choices for pain relief is incredibly shortsighted and goes against the healthcare community. There is enough for the regulators to deal with in the illegal department. Read these comments and do the right thing. Keep Kratom Legal. I'm ok with age restrictions and warning labels like any other product.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,
  First off, thank you for the opportunity to voice our opinions. I am hoping this actually reaches a person and does not get lost on some internet server somewhere. Kratom has become a "life saver" for me. I have 2 herniated discs in my neck and have pain from this just about every day. I went the traditional route first through specialist doctors and worked my way up to a Pain Management doctor. I followed their advice and prescriptions only to find myself eating pill after pill often more than prescribed. You get to a point where you don't even remember how many you have had for the day so you take another just in case.. 
  After some time this caused major issues with my wife so I would pledge to not go back to the doctor. I then suffered HORRIBLE withdrawals and then would be off meds for a period of time. This would only last a couple months, then it was back to the doctor again for more pills but it will be different this time. Wrong! It was not different and it strained my relationship with my wife to the breaking point. I got fat, stopped exercising, could not perform sexually and was in a bad mood most days. I almost lost my wife and kids. She deserves better than a pill head addict. So I got off the meds, for good this time knowing I was making a deal that would force me to be in pain. Neck pain is better than losing my family no matter how severe. 
 I finally found Kratom looking for alternatives to pills and it seems to serve as a REAL solution to my problem. I am not "high" anymore but I am also not in pain when I take it. I have more energy to play with my kids and I am in a better mood. I can dose once in the morning and feel fine for most of the day, it knocks the pain down at least 80%. I would venture to say it is a more powerful pain reliever than the oxycodone I was on before but without all of the bad side effects. All of my negative side effects listed above are gone and I am happy to say that my relationship with my wife is back to being great again. Best of all, I have zero desire to go back to the doctor or take pills again. 
 I really hope this plan remains legal as it has really helped me and many people in the same position. Thank you

documents.commentText: Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars. Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: I never heard of kratom until I read that the DEA was about to put it in the CSA schedule 1. What could this be? Upon doing some research, I found that kratom is a natural leaf from a tree that grows mostly in the far East. People have used kratom for hundreds of years with no ill effect. Recent research has shown that kratom affects the same receptors in the brain as opioids, but without the harmful addiction. Some scientists have suggested that kratom would serve as a perfect natural alternative for people who are attempting to break their addiction to opioids. I have seen on the news that there is a huge problem here in America with opioid addiction and overdose deaths. The government has even made it a priority to address this national problem. How great it is, that there is a natural alternative which has been shown to help people quit opioids. But wait, just when one branch of the government is trying to quell the national epidemic, another branch of the government (the DEA) wants to put the alternative completely out of reach, not only to people already getting relief, but to researchers who can certainly find even more positive aspects of kratom, if they not held back by schedule 1. It is beyond ridiculous that the DEA claims an immediate danger to the public from constituents in kratom, given the years and years of harmless use by people all around the world. I can't help but surmise that the DEA is acting under the influence of certain pharmaceutical companies. I have heard that these companies are working to create a prescription drug mimicking kratom (at great cost to the pubic, undoubtedly) and they would hate to see competition from Mother Nature. Aside from this obvious pharmaceutical conflict of interest, it is really disturbing to see our government in conflict with itself. I do draw some comfort from the fact that the DEA did back off from scheduling kratom into schedule 1, due to both public outcry and several Congress member's objections. I hope that logic and compassion will overcome the DEA's urge to regulate kratom, and it will remain available to the public.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern: 

I am a 29-year-old female with a graduate education. I use kratom, a member of the coffee family, because it gives me a boost of energy without the negative side effects of caffeine. I have been using it in moderate doses for one year and have experienced no negative health effects, nor cravings - which is, incidentally, more than I can say for coffee! I find that kratom is a useful and productive plant, one that I hope will become more well-known and widely available. 

In my experience, kratom is a much milder and healthier alternative than energy drinks and large pots of coffee. I hope that you will do more research on this interesting and promising plant.

Thank you for opening the public comments period. I hope you'll take mine into consideration. 

All the best, 

Hannah

documents.commentText:
Kratom has been my go-to for about two years. This plant is inexpensive and it is about as harmless as taking an herbal supplement. Of course, anything can be abused, and any substance, including tap water from your home faucet, can be overdosed on.

People around the world have used Kratom for many years, perhaps many centuries. The plant's pain relieving properties are real, yet I do not feel the plant works for me like a scripted opiate; Kratom relieves my pain without the "loopyness" I get from scripted opiates. This is a good thing! I can use a red strain of Kratom and have my neck, back, arthritic, and muscular pain relieved while still being able to function normally and do my work through my business and around my home. Being able to have a clear head and a body that's not feeling drugged is a God-send.

I have taken scripted opiates for many years due to several old accidents and arthritis that's haunted my joints for almost three decades (it's not RA and the joint pain I have cannot be associated with an autoimmune disease as I have been tested several times and there is no particular reason for this pain and the flares I have). Kratom has been so helpful for me and has reduced what would be a dependence upon scripted opiates. Since the US Government and the DEA have taken my medical history and treatment out of my primary doctor and specialists' hands, being treated for chronic pain is a nightmare. You walk the line and never know if you will be able to receive another script for pain meds that you genuinely need. You never know when you might be sent to a pain management clinic that has no interest in treating your pain with scripted meds that help you; the pain management clinics seem to be more interested in forcing patients to receive injections that may or may not work. If you read patient forums (cancer patients, pain management patients, etc.), it's a crap shoot when you receive the injections pain management anesthesiologists force most pain patients to endure. My own mother who is Stage IV cancer with a limited prognosis is being forced to receive injections that, for the most part, are not working for her. She's also scripted Tramadol 50 mg for breakthrough pain. Really?????? 

This is our great government at work. Because of pill mills in Florida and irresponsible physicians who enjoyed the kick backs from big pharma's pill pushing over the last two decades, some people lost their lives. This is very sad and I am sorry this happened. My heart goes out to the families and friends left behind. However, that is NO REASON the US Government should step in and become the watch dog of my physicians who care for me. My physician and my specialists are responsible individuals who do not over script opiates or any other medication, for that matter.

And now the DEA and US Government are concerned about Kratom? This makes no sense. If you are truly concerned, DEA and US Government, allow independent studies to be conducted. Allow these plants and their various strains to be researched. But if you haven't researched the plants and if you don't know what you are dealing with - because you do not - then there is no reason to say that I have no right to consume this plant. 

You don't have a problem with me taking other herbal supplements for various reasons (St. John's Wort, Valerian, Kava Kava, etc.), so why pick on Kratom? Please do not schedule this plant and take something that works for so many people, people like me who cannot get relief from their pain through scripts, and people like me who do not want to take illegal drugs. Thank you for listening.

documents.commentText:
I firmly believe that kratom literally saved my life. When I was 18 I was assaulted and left with ongoing pain, in addition to anxiety and depression. I was also in a few car accidents in my early twenties which extended the amount of time that I was on narcotic pain relievers, so before I knew it I was hooked. I managed my addiction pretty well all through 2 rounds of college and through the beginning of a great careee, until one day I just couldn't, everything came crashing down. I knew that if I didn't find a real solution I would lose everything, my career, my house, or my pets, and most of all my fiance. I really just didn't know what to do. I have tried buprenorphine before and hated it. It made me feel sick, just ill, it took away all of my emotions and made me feel like a zombie. Most importantly, it just did not keep me off of the drugs. I was searching desperately for some sort of solution when I remembered that I had taken Kratom when I was younger. I did some research online and found that thousands of people we're also using kratom to come off of drugs, and to also deal with pain. 

At first, I didn't notice any changes due to the amount of opiates I had been on, but slowly I started to feel like a normal person again and I cannot describe how good that made me feel. Kratom took the edge off of the pain, not nearly as good as an opiate would but enough to where it wasn't constantly on my mind. It also essentially killed all anxiety and depression. Most importantly, it took away almost all of the drug cravings, and I can honestly say that I have not touched opiates since I started using kratom. 

Kratom has saved my life, and I know based upon the stories that I have read that Kratom has also saved thousands and thousands of other lives. As you well know, our country is in the middle of an opioid epidemic. News of overdoses are always splashed across the headlines, as well as our government's efforts to get some sort of control over this horrible situation. I don't want to politicize this argument, but I will say that a real solution has been offered here with kratom and I honestly can't wrap my head around why anyone, aside from pharmaceutical companies, would want to take away something that can save lives with little to no negative effects. I've looked over the Kratom overdose information, and from what I can see, every individual who overdosed with kratom in their body was also found with numerous other substances in their blood. 

My biggest fear is that the DEA will ban kratom, and that the thousands and thousands of lives that it has staved will be ruined as people will likely turn back to opiates. I beg you to please reconsider your decision to ban kratom, for your sake, and ours.

documents.commentText:
I am a mother, a wife, a public figure who works diligently with children. I have a Bachelors and a Masters Degree. I know what hard work and integrity means and I know about addiction. 5 years ago,  I found kratom. 

 I am healthy mentally and physically. Other than my yearly well-woman visit, I have not seen or required a doctor in 4 years.  I take kratom like a vitamin regime for energy, mood boost, and pain. I work long hours bettering and brightening the future for children. And I am one of the best in my field.  I dont get high from kratom. I use it responsibly. I dont drink alcohol. I dont smoke cigarettes.  I am the Best Me I have ever been.  Kratom has saved my life. 

While the DEA statistics say that Kratom has killed 15 people in 2 years (although the people who have died had other substances in their system), cigarettes are responsible for 480,000 deaths a year (CDC, www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/fast_facts/)  . Alcohol is responsible for 88,000 a year and 2.5 million years of potential life lost (CDC, www.cdc.gov/alcohol/fact-sheets/alcohol-use.htm).  Approximately 185 accidently die each year from Tylenol yet it remains on the shelves for public consumption because the FDA stated the agency saw the benefits of keeping acetaminophen widely available as outweighing the relatively rare risk of liver damage or death (U.S. Center for Disease Control and Prevention Multiple Cause of Death Database).  Many, possibly hundreds, of prescriptions and over-the-counter medications that the FDA and DEA allow for use as relatively safe, have been the cause of more deaths and more overdoses in one year than decades of Kratom use.  Substances that the DEA and FDA know are dangerous such as alcohol and cigarettes continue to be a part of our mainstream repertoire of consumption, yet those remain legal and a staple in our culture. 

Kratom has saved the lives of thousands of people. My conservative family members are thankful for kratom and what it has done for me.  Thousands of people use kratom to abstain from the very things that are legal and harmful. The people of this country are fighting and winning their own War on Drugs and Prescriptions by using kratom in their arsenal. That being said, kratom users are not all addicts getting clean from drugs that are illegal and legal. Many people use kratom as a healthy alternative to combating the effects of diseases, chronic pain, depression, and the list goes on and on. Their eyes are open to the harmful side effects of any prescription drugs that may be prescribed and they are choosing safer alternative methods such as kratom.  Please keep kratom legal for the sake and well-being of millions of Americans.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am a Marine Corps and Iraq combat veteran. I served 2 deployments to Fallujah and Ramadi. I was the lead machine gunner and driver for the lead vehicle of a route clearance team. We were in charge of escorting troops around Al Anbar province while clearing improvised explosives from the roads in order to allow clear passage for other troops operating in the area. During this time, we had 168 successful missions while our vehicles were actually hit by IEDs on 38 occasions. 4 of these hits were on my vehicle causing traumatic brain injury and compressed lower discs in my back along with other injuries that were able to heal through stitches and staples. Upon returning from deployments I had PTSD and was unable to go out in public places without getting anxiety. I turned to drinking and relied on it for years after because I thought it was safer than any prescription drugs. Not until just recently I found kratom after hearing a few people tell me how it's helped them. I tried it and immediately noticed a change in mood, energy, and also how I was able to be confident and curb my anxiety while out in public. Not only do I feel this medicine can help out fellow veterans, but also people struggling with addiction and taking prescription drugs. Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I am a 46 year old successful businessman, a law-abiding citizen with a family, a valued member of my community, and I have been consuming kratom regularly for 18 months for anxiety and depression. Kratom has helped me tremendously, and the ignorance surrounding this proposed ban is astounding. I can function normally after consuming kratom, as it does not impair day to day functioning. It reduces my anxiety and provides a feeling of alertness but without the jittery side effects of coffee. It also produces a slight feeling of well-being, which helps people with anxiety.  Making this plant illegal and classified the same as heroin and other extremely dangerous drugs is one of the most disheartening and disturbing acts I've ever seen by the government.

I have several friends age 40 to 70 who use kratom regularly for other ailments as well, including chronic pain such as arthritis. I have introduced kratom to these friends and they have been extremely thankful because it allowed them to stop using powerful pain killers with many negative side effects. It has enabled them to lead productive lives with less pain, and allowed them to perform their jobs and all their normal day to day functions. 

This plant is certainly much safer than alcohol, as it does not impair you. If taking too much, the worst that can happen is dizziness and vomiting, which are common effects of drinking too much alcohol. Kratom consumption does not create any kind of intoxication, and I am shocked that the DEA has proposed a ban. It is by no means a hardcore drug and can safely be used by people who just want to lead pain-free, anxiety-free, and productive lives.

I suspect that the motivation behind this ban comes from big pharma, as they are likely waiting to make billions by patenting a synthesized version of the alkoloids found in Kratom. If the DEA's motivation does in fact come from this profit-driving pressure to cash in on new prescription drugs, I will have lost all faith in our government and the DEA to protect us from the real hazards out there. 

As a successful and responsible 46 year old U.S. citizen, I strongly oppose the kratom ban.

documents.commentText: I would like to take a moment to share my story and encourage the DEA to reconsider its decision to place Kratom on the schedule 1 list alongside drugs like heroin and ecstasy. Kratom has helped so many people (including me) to live healthier, happier lives. For several years I battled an addiction to drugs and alcohol. I made several unsuccessful attempts to get sober. That changed when I discovered kratom. A friend suggested that I try kratom as it has helped others beat their addictions. I did and within 3 weeks of the first time I tried it I was completely off of the substances I was using (which included prescription pain pills, ecstasy, meth, and alcohol). I have been completely drug and alcohol free since trying kratom. It has given me my life back. I do not know where I would be without it. Kratom has helped people with addiction issues as well as pain management. Many people are turning to kratom as an alternative to dangerous and addictive prescription pain pills. The medications that are prescribed to people in droves by doctors are far more dangerous than any amount of kratom. Thousands and thousands of people overdose on pills every year yet there has never been a single death from kratom. The DEA cited roughly 660 calls to the poison control center and just a handful of deaths. However, not a single one of those deaths was from kratom alone. Every single case had other dangerous substances involved. Kratom has saved so many lives and has killed nobody. I believe that the reason kratom has become an issue with the government is because the pharmaceutical companies are losing money due to people weening themselves off of their products in order to seek a less dangerous, less debilitating, less addictive method of pain management. It is extremely frustrated to feel like the interests of big business are being placed above doing what is best for the public. In the midst of such a terrible opiate epidemic we need to be embracing any safe substance that is helping people stay away from these dangerous drugs. Kratom is no danger to the public. If kratom becomes illegal, addicts will go back to their old habits and lives will be destroyed. If Kratom becomes a schedule 1 substance scientists and doctors will not be able to continue their research in finding out what kratom can do for people. There is simply not the evidence to support turning kratom into an illegal substance. I would like to encourage the DEA to remember who they are supposed to represent and to do the right thing here. Kratom must stay legal and available to everyone who uses it to live better lives. I appreciate your consideration and your allowing the public to comment on this important issue and I look forward to Kratom remaining legal.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,
 This message is a comment on the sheduling of an important beneficial plant to the human species, which will lead to this plant becoming inaccessible to those who may have otherwise found its' many healing properties. As a researcher and consumer of this powerful medicinal botanical, I have experienced the overwhelmingly positive benefits kratom has provided to me over the course of my daily usage for over three years. I suffer from a variety of physiological and psychological discrepancies and kratom is one of the reasons I have the strength to make it out of bed in a positive mood every morning. While this is just my experience, I know of countless examples in which kratom has helped many different types of people overcome and maintain a wide variety of ailments. More specifically a massive benefit of this plant has been and is to help ease an extremely dangerous epidemic already gripping the nation... Opioids. Kratom helps those who suffer from opioid dependence to find an alternative, and those who are trying to quit opiates/opioids find healthier (and cheaper) means of treating and maintaining those side effects or dependencies. This is an undeniable fact, however painful it may be, kratom is being treated like marijuana has been throughout history up until just mere years ago, when the approval of medical marijuana was accepted. In a sense, kratom is very similar to marijuana in that it is more or less harmless with no deaths contributed (each alone) for hundreds if not thousands of years of human use...Also that it is difficult to tax and regulate because it can be so widely grown in tropical areas, that the government could not make a viable profit from taxation every time kratom switched hands from grower to distributor.. While much of my story may be conjecture, it is also personal experience and knowledge based in responsibility as a natural person and born sovereign. 

 I urge you to consider this statement on our natural rights as human beings. If laws can be passed to regulate what substances can and can not be consumed, what does that say about who owns our bodies? If I do not have the right to choose, with my own free will, what I will consume and put into the body I currently own and inhabit, who does choose what I am allowed to put into MY body?

Thank you for taking the time to read this and I sincerely hope the reader will grasp the medical value and beneficial impact this botanical ally has on people everywhere. I also hope that just like it's powerful sister plant marijuana, kratom will be recognized as a therapeutic tool to help people in a natural way conducive to responsibility and health in fair economic and environmental practice. Kratom is amazing, please consider our input as the people who make up the country in which the laws are supposed to "protect". This is also not just a battle on the scheduling of this powerful plant, but an attack on consciousness. Governement was created to maintain a structured freedom, a freedom that we, the people, constitute. Don't take our freedom to choose what we will put in our bodies and fill more privatized prisons with people of victimless crimes. 

I appreciate the recipients willingness to sift through these input letters and hope this finds a place you can relate to somehow, someway as a human being. 
Sincerely and with positivity,  
       
 John Perry

To the reader of this letter, I hope your day is well and thank you for considering my honest and truthful opinion on the beneficial aspects of Mitragyna Speciosa.
I'll start of by saying that I am a 25 year old male that has been living with severe and chronic pain since around 2003 around about my 7th grade year where it would inhibit me from being able to participate in my Pshysical education classes. Through the course of the last 13-14 years my pain has developed in a way that no medical specialist has been able to prescribe me anything that has helped in alleviating or reversing the condition I have. I was recently diagnosed with severe and advanced Ankylosing Spondylitis among a few other thing as the source of my pain.
At around 2010 I moved out to go to school out of state and out of desperation, I started searching online for ways of dealing with pain so I could physically hold a job and support my self and that was when I discovered Kratom. It has helped me cope with my pain in a way that none of the pain medication and various pharmaceuticals Ive had to take has. Although my conditions still exist, the pain that comes with it is much more bearable to where I feel I can live a much more productive life than I once was able to. It has even allowed me to get through a time in my life where I had to consider applying for disability assistance. I have had a doctor tell me to keep taking it at low doses along with Anti-inflammatorys since its continued to help my pain and hasnt given me adverse reactions and there weren't any clinical side effects or abnormalities noticed from blood tests. 
Along with the 800+ milligram doses of Ibuprofen I have to take daily (this dose is doctor recomended in keeping down inflammation) along with the 5 gram dose of powdered crushed leaf Kratom I take with it keeps me mobile throughout the first part of the day and significantly takes the edge off of the pain.
I know that this plant has benefited my well being and quality of life within the last few years and I know it has to have been a miracle to many other Americans in similar situations that have come to find this plant through they're search for natural and non synthetic pharmaceutical remedies for pain. 
On top of pain relief, I am also aware of the epidemic of opioids addictions inflicting many peoples lives in this country and have personally known people coming off opioid substance addictions through use of Kratom and then altogether lifting their hands of off every substance, illicit and unregulated. Even leaving Kratom itself, which itself tells me that Kratom can be/is a tool for an important problem and is most definitely helping people set they're lives straight from addiction. 
I would like to know that there will continue to be hope for myself and many others that are dealing with potentially debilitating diseases/conditions that use this plant to improve they're well being where nothing else has and please consider the availability ofkratom over much more harmful things. 
Sincerely,
 
Nathaniel Ashton Cemento

documents.commentText:
I am 42 years old and have had chronic pain from rheumatoid arthritis for 22 years, and more recently diagnosed with fibromyalgia and osteoarthrits. One of my arthritis medicines triggered pseudotumor, so now I battle constant migraines due to brain swelling.  I have taken Vicodin, then Norco, to ease the pain of these conditions. My doctor limits me to 6 pills a day; it's never enough. A friend of mine had been taking Kratom for his pain and suggested I try it; after looking into it and seeing its long history, I did. It does not treat pain as well as narcotic painkillers, but it is an adequate substitute when I have reached my limit. I have found that with Kratom, I am able to leave the house and get things done when otherwise I would not; I can function without painkillers, albeit at a lower level. 
I have never felt "high". I have felt slightly queasy, a feeling that is normal for many medicines if I haven't eaten. If I haven't had enough water on days I take a lot of Kratom, I tend to constipation. Those are the worst side effects that I have experienced. 
I respectfully request that you reconsider scheduling Kratom as a controlled substance. It has truly been a gamechanger for me; over the past year that I've been taking it, I've been able to be much more involved in my everyday life than I've been previously. And for a single mother of six, that's nothing short of miraculous.

documents.commentText: Hello, my name is Justin Stoner and I am 34 years old, I have been using Kratom for three years. I started it, because of back issues from years ago, I began taking prescription pain killers, such as Norco, then suboxone, and at times muscle relaxers such as Soma. When in Norco, my tolerance got so high, and I had become so addicted, in my worst years, I could take over 40 pills a day, and had to make more Doctor trips, and at times exaggerate my symptoms to get more and prevent from being sick. After years, I was then prescribed suboxone, which at first was great, one lozenge a day, didn't get me as high as the pills, but prevented withdrawal. After another two years on Suboxone, I lost my insurance and had to go cold turkey, which is horrible if you have ever been through it, especially after 10 years of abuse, it's the worst pain imaginable, physically and emotionally, so I would still seek out opiates. I found Kratom in a smoke shop locally and it says it helps with pain and energy, so I tried it once when in total withdrawal, it didn't get me high at all, but the withdrawal symptoms were tolerable and bear gone, I couldn't believe it, a natural plant. Kratom helped me kick my addiction, and when it came time to get off Kratom, it was 10 fold easier than getting off of the pills, little discomfort and tiredness. I have now been using Kratom on and off for two years, it helps with my pain, as well as gives me energy and helps with my anxiety and mood as well, but does not incapacitate me, there is NO high at all, not like taking pills, it is so mild, that I don't think anyone would even try to abuse it, if they did, they may get a headache and feel Nautious, (as I have when testing my preferred dose). And my tolerance is high, since I used it to get off of these killers. Usually 15 grams per dose, anything past 20 just makes me Nautious, but you won't see anyone nodding off, or stealing from their grandmother to get this stuff. Please do not outlaw this natural substance. Just regulate it as an herbal supplement, maybe an age restriction and quality standards, but finally something natural gets found to help, for it to get taken away, would be very bad and very sad for many suffering people, thank you and regards, Justin Stoner.

documents.commentText:
Kratom is potentially life saving for the many people faced with opiate addiction in our society. As a biomedical researcher who works on addiction, I know how dangerous these opiate problems can be. Any potential alternative needs to be seriously considered and researched before being essentially banned by making it a Schedule I drug. So far Kratom seems much safer and more manageable than alternative pain medications, but it's also important that we do the proper studies to understand the short- and long-term effects of this plant's use. Making it Schedule I will make any further research nearly impossible, and in the meantime many more people will have their lives ruined by doctor prescribed painkillers that they become addicted to, leading to harder drug use such as heroin, or overdose from.

PLEASE KEEP KRATOM LEGAL AND ALLOW PROPER RESEARCH INTO ITS ADVANTAGES AND DISADVANTAGES. AS A SOCIETY WE CANNOT AFFORD TO LET MORE PEOPLE SUFFER FROM OPIATE ADDICTION WHEN WE KNOW OF POTENTIALLY LIFE SAVING ALTERNATIVES.

I hope you consider this issue very seriously moving forward. The decision you make on this issue will have an impact on many thousands if not millions of American lives. Thank you for giving the people a chance to speak up on this issue.

documents.commentText:
The Honorable Chuck Rosenberg
Acting Administrator, Drug Enforcement Agent

Dear Acting Administrator Rosenberg,

I write this comment today, anonymously, due to the prospect that a plant I have consumed on and off for years may be moved to a Schedule 1 status.   The seriousness of such a ban, would make a public comment with my legal name on it, capable of irreparable damage to my career and reputation.   
I am a 40 year old, proud father of one.  I am a Marketing professional with 19 years of experience working for two Fortune 500 companies.  I started taking Kratom tea leaves for back pain after a serious injury playing Lacrosse five years ago.  I have taken Kratom on and off since then to treat the pain which has helped me get through Physical Therapy and get back to the gym without with the drowsiness of prescribed pills.  When I was taking higher doses during my most severe pain, I don't recall ever having any kind of side effects if I suddenly stopped taking it when my pain became more sporadic.
This plant has been nothing short of incredible to my recovery and my ability to exercise regularly.  I respectfully ask for you to keep this plant legal and accessible to people like myself who use to improve their well being and quality of life.  Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
Making Kratom a Schedule 1 drug - as a knee jerk reaction no less - can cost us thousands of lives. In America we have an opioid epidemic and Kratom represents an accessible alternative to a deadly addiction. We need to stop the opioid deaths and Kratom can help with that. Furthermore, the war on drugs has to end and banning Kratom will only make it worse. It is a plant that has been used for thousands of years. Yes it needs more research, but we all know that Schedule 1 drugs cannot be researched. Kratom has been used safely by millions of people. That bears repeating: Kratom has been used safely by MILLIONS of people. 

Kratom needs more research. I totally support that. As a tax paying citizen, I want my tax dollars to fund research to better understand the plant. I do not want my tax dollars going towards making it illegal and funding a war against it. At this moment in time, it has had no ill effects against anyone when used by itself. Making it illegal will destroy lives. It will prevent millions of people suffering from chronic pain access to relief. Making kratom illegal will prevent the millions of Americans suffering from opioid addiction from having a safe, non deadly alternative and a way out of their own personal addiction hells. 

Do not schedule Kratom at this time. Do not make Kratom illegal at this time. Get some research on it before taking any action. We are approaching 20 years into the 21st century. We know from the past that banning plants and alcohol only leads to negative consequences. It is time to take a reasonable approach based on science, testing, objective and unbiased evidence. America is capable of that and now is the time to exercise our logic, reason, and science. If we can put a man on the moon, invent the internet, and be the best country on the planet, we can certainly figure out how a plant can help human kind and what, if any, negative consequences it can have before making a decision that will affect millions of lives.

I am a 44 year old woman, and I have Ehlers Danlos Syndrome. I use kratom as one part of a multi-pronged strategy of pain management, and with the knowledge of some of my physicians (I have several). I use kratom 2-3 times a day, and this enables me in part to hold a full time desk based job (working from home). I have a Master of Science in Health Communication, and I have thoroughly and carefully considered the literature, and determined it is of very low risk to my health, while offering a high potential for managing my ongoing and daily pain because of Ehlers Danlos. In short, my body feels like it is being pulled apart, as my connective tissues are degrading. I also have two children, and a husband. Kratom also helps me spend time with my family and focus on them, rather than my own pain. I believe I understand the ramifications of Ehlers Danlos and various management techniques proposed by my care team, and should be empowered to make choices myself, including choosing to have kratom as part of my care regimen. 
I hope you will take my views seriously as it is painful even to type out a reply such as this. 
Keep the kratom leaf freely available for me and so many others who have turned to it when so many other options have failed. 
Sincerely,
Tasha van Es
Massachusetts

documents.commentText:
Kratom should not be banned.  

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. 

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
I am a 56 year male, small business person that works at home with pretty constant arthritis pain in my neck, shoulders and back. It is very difficult to get pain management doctors that understand that there is a difference between addiction and dependency on substances. There are a lot of terrible side affects with taking to many Tylenol or Ibuprofen products and it leaves little choice out there for additional pain relief and this substance really seems to help break through that barrier a little better. It gives me an extra choice to rotate through for pain relief in a time when all other pain relievers that are normally available for doctors to use to treat and manage people with chronic pain problems are being restricted so much. You practically have to be a person diagnosed with cancer to be eligible for pain management. 

We do have legalized marijuana in our state, but as a going on 3 year X-smoker that also has COPD this is not the best choice since it is primarily a smoking product. Side effects of marijuana and Kratom are quite different.  Marijuana's pain relief has limitations on how well you can function and do your work when using it and it is legalized. 

Kratom is something that is just strong enough for me and helps with pain throughout the day and does not have the side effects that a substance like Marijuana or Alcohol do and tend to leave you to effected to do your work. Kratom is not smoking product either. It can be added to hot drinks of tea or coffee. After consuming Kratom I am still able to function quite well at my job, there is no driving risk at all for me because I work at home, but also because the product once used does not really impair you physically that much or last to long in your system. 

I am a productive tax paying citizen and I am really getting tired of anything stronger then the limited over the counter pain relief items being regulated and rescheduled to Level 1 with little or no good long term human studies being presented. How do you really know that it just automatically has to be scheduled this way and made an illegal Schedule 1 narcotic and no one should be able to get it at all without the studies and proof backing it up and being presented to the public in general. 

Please do some serious human studies on Kratom before just automatically changing it to a something that is just taken off the market all together and further limiting law abiding people trying to truly manage pain in a responsible way with limited side effects.  

I would like to add that if you take this product off the market before even studying it that you also review other products that are used in other countries. They are legal in other countries and help people that can manage their pain responsibly.  People need choices and help with chronic pain relief such as Tylenol with codeine or Ibuprofen with codeine for responsible people that are really just trying to feel normal, get through the day without having constant pain and still be functional. There are a lot of people in pain that need more help at a reasonable cost with something that still allows them to function with less impairment to normal senses, thoughts and physical functioning of their bodies.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this product.

documents.commentText:
DEA,
        Please take into consideration. I'm a 90% Service Connected, Disabled Veteran.  I love my country, I love the freedoms we are afforded and the rules we have to live by. My body is pretty abused after years of service. The VA will care for an individual to death,  if you have a problem they will prescribe away the issues till either the problem goes away or the individual is killed from over medication.  I receive care for visible and non-visible injuries. Regardless of the issue, pills are the solution. They wreck havoc on the body and the mind. 

Kratom is not a perfect solution, but neither are the rest of the pills. At a minimum the leaf is natural. Although it can be abused or enhanced many other products can be as well. I'm not going to try and justify risks by comparing it to alcohol or caffeine or other substances; however, the potential for misuse or harm is significantly less than people seeking synthetic chemical alternatives. I've been on dozens of pain medication, other medications, and Kratom is by far the most promising. I can walk without pain after 3 ankle surgeries and spinal fusion. I hope that I can run again.

Hope is the operative work in that sentence, hope is something I have lost in pain medications and other pills. Hope is not having to beg the doctor for a script they are afraid to write because of the scrutiny of controlled substances. Please don't force me back on pills and regulated substances. Alkaloids (active ingredients in Kratom) in their natural form work much better than synthetic medications. 

If its required, fund the proper "due diligence" to find the answers being sought through research, but until there is a satisfactory answer, please do not punish us our of fear and ban something that is helping people. Please spend your limited resources on higher priority problems that plague us rather than something that may not be understood by policy makers. 

Thank you for your consideration, its the most I personally could ask for.

documents.commentText: Hello. I would like to share my thoughts and experiences in regards to Kratom. Ever since I was 26 years old I have suffered from two bulging disks in my lower back. This has over the past ten years caused severe spinal stenosis which besides the back pain and spasms causes quite a bit of neuropathy/radiculopathy in my legs. In addition to this I also have inherited rheumatoid arthritis from my dad's side and poly cystic kidney disease from my mom's side. Sounds like quite a mess doesn't it? Before I knew I had PKD there was a few years I took prescription pain relievers in order to continue working and providing for my family. Now however, I can not safely take narcotic pain pills due to my kidneys. My kidney function numbers and levels are still great and it is my desire to keep them that way. Pain pills caused a slew of other problems as well. I'm not an addictive person by nature but my tolerance for the opioids would increase at a rate that was very surprising to me. It also changed my personality in a negative way.  I noticed myself becoming more or less a jerk. Lacking empathy or concern for those I love. All the while not adequately controlling the pain. I quit taking the opiates and lived on Motrin until that was useless. I was at my wits end and was contemplating going back on opiates after being off them for years . The spinal stenosis was really starting to wreak havoc on me. On my way to the doctors I called my friend who owns a vitamin/health store. I asked her if there was really something natural that works for pain. I didn't expect to hear that there was. Long story short, I was introduced to Kratom. I have now been taking  Kratom for almost one year. In that year my pain has been the most managed as it ever has been and I have not had to increase my dose at all.  There are practically no side effects and if I'm having a good day with little pain and don't take Kratom I have not experienced any withdrawal symptoms. I have recently had my blood work done and my kidney and liver functions are perfect. Sounds too good to be true. Please, there are many of us who for one reason or another are in pain,  suffer anxiety and depression or perhaps have symptoms of ADHD. Kratom is a safe, cost effective way to manage all those things. It actually is known for boosting your immune system as well. There is a growing number of people who do not want narcotics to be the only option. Kratom has given me and many people I've come in contact with their lives back with no ill side effects or dependency issues. I have worked with addicts in the ministry I am involved with. I've seen what these heavy duty synthetic drugs can do to people. Please don't make people have to choose between pain and breaking the law. Or choose between pain and addiction. We have an alternative. If your afraid of kids getting it, don't be. The worst thing that could happen if someone tried to get high off it they say is that person would throw up. Those of us who utilize it don't take it to get a buzz. It doesn't work that way anyhow. It blocks certain receptors while working on the others. Truly amazing. It deserves to be studied and utilized. Please keep it legal. An age requirement would be fine. However, criminalizing this plant would just add more headache and more cost to try to add it to the already failing war on drugs. I do hope and pray that you will keep this plant available for so many people who have their quality of life back. I thank you so much for your time and for the opportunity to be heard.

documents.commentText: Kratom has saved my life. I was diagnosed with lupus around 9 years ago. I was on many medications with many, many side effects. Some of the medications made me sick to my stomach, others made my long beautiful hair fall out. I was unable to go into any type of uv or natural sunlight at all because of one of the medications, and the consequence of doing so would result in large burn like patches all over my skin. Another medication caused seizures, seizures I'm which I had never had before. I would also like to mention that I was a college student, my lupus medications could cost a few hundred a month, and infusions could cost a few thousands. I went years being on all of these medications, with all of the horrible side effects. Sometimes, the medications wouldn't even begin to touch the pain lupus was putting my body through. I found kratom around four or five years ago. I have since been able to stop most of moths medications I have been on, one by one, with the support of a doctor. I now only take one medication, a steroid as needed. I haven't had to take it for almost a year now. I have been pain free for four years. I have been able to rid myself of all the ill side effects from the many medications I was on. I can go out and enjoy the sunlight. I have even been pain free enough to take up activities like hiking and kayaking. Kratom honestly gave me a life again. My lupus finally went into remission this past summer. My hair is growing back, I was able to start excercising and losing the weight gain the steroids have caused. This plant has changed my life. I am happier than I have been for years. And one day, since I have been able to stop the chemotherapy medications, I will be able to achieve my biggest dream. I will be able to have a baby and raise a family. Many of the lupus medications I was on can are too dangerous for pregnant woman, some even caused blood issues which can lead to miscarriage. I pray that this plant can be given a second look. I don't think I could have a life without it. If this natural plant is no longer available,my biggest fear is having to go back to the lupus meds, the infusions, the chemotherapy. I will have to live in pain again, and I may never get to experience the beauty of motherhood and children.

documents.commentText:
I am a 33 year old married mother. I served in the military, I am a homeowner, hold an associates degree, and am pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Finance in Accounting. My husband works in retail management. I am a Procurement Supervisor at a growing company, and am aiming my career towards finance.

While I've always had tight and achy muscles despite frequent stretching, In 2007 I began experiencing extreme fatigue. I drank copious amounts of coffee in an attempt to keep myself awake. I also started experiencing more pain in my shoulders and back. By 2011, my primary care physician - who I have visited dozens of times for these symptoms - diagnosed me with fibromyalgia, prescribed me Cymbalta and sent me on my way. The pain did not cease, and neither did the fatigue. I found myself regularly falling asleep while driving - once causing an accident while my children in the car. This was in spite of sleeping 9 hours a night and eating a whole food diet. At the time, I was employed, but quit my job in 2013 because I was physically unable to sit at a desk and operate the computer mouse because of the pain and fatigue and I ran out of FMLA time. I started drinking energy drinks instead of coffee to keep myself awake at the wheel. By that time, I was seeing a chiropractor three times a week for chronic neck pain, headaches, and minor scoliosis. In 2014 I took a temporary work from home job with a well known tech company, but found it difficult to stay awake and focus on my work. I became severely depressed, and began seeing a therapist and psychiatrist. My PCP prescribed Vicodin and Percocet, but they did not help my pain. My psychiatrist, suspecting underlying ADHD because of my inability to focus, prescribed Adderall. While very effective at keeping me awake, it made my mind race and did not help my pain. Still, with his guidance, in late 2015 I was able to secure a decent paying temporary job in Procurement. It was hard - I was convinced I was not going to be able to keep it. I was so tired all of the time. When I took the Adderall I was able to stay awake, but could not keep my mind fully on my tasks. When I didn't take the Adderall, I could barely keep my eyes open. My children were not given nearly as much attention as they deserved, and my house was in disarray - I was too tired to clean. I would cry to my husband - if I hurt this much and am this tired now, what in the world would our lives be like when we're 60? I could not imagine 20+ more years in this amount of anguish. I wasn't living - I was only surviving.

One night shortly after starting my new job, I found Kratom while searching for a natural solution for chronic fatigue and pain. At the point of "I'll try anything", I ordered 4 ounces of the powdered leaf. I put 3 grams into a cup, added hot water and drank. 30 minutes later, I noticed that not only had the constant pain in my back and shoulder dulled, I was awake. Not jittery like the Adderall made me, or artificially propped up like with coffee, but like I'd actually had a decent night's rest. I had one of the most productive days at work to in years, and felt amazing. Since that day, I take kratom the exact same dose on weekdays - 3 grams in hot water before I go to work. I only use it on weekends if I have a busy day. Since using it, I was promoted from a temporary procurement specialist to the supervisor of my department. I was able to re-enroll in school. My house is clean! My children got their mother back. My husband got his wife back. I haven't had an energy drink in months. The pain isn't entirely gone, but the degree to which it has lessened is incredible. While I do still enjoy coffee, it's no longer a thing I need just to keep my eyes open. I'm not getting high - kratom does not create a sense of euphoria for me at all. It only makes it so I can function, and I finally feel like myself again.

With kratom, my 2016 earnings will be more than double my 2014 earnings. My personal income is up over 68% in the last 12 months. I pay more income taxes and am actually contributing to society. Rather than dreading the day I am forced to give up and collect disability for chronic fatigue, I'm looking forward to my next promotion and a long life filled with those I love. 

If Kratom is made illegal, you will have sentenced me to either become a criminal, or to become a disabled young woman who can no longer work, and who can't even drive for fear of falling asleep and killing others. You will turn me into a burden on the social safety nets that I proudly pay into now. Either that, or the amount I pay in taxes will potentially become nullified if I am arrested and prosecuted for a federal drug crime. 

The alternative would be legally getting myself addicted to Adderall, just to get by. Modern medicine has failed me, but a plant found in nature has given me my life back. For my sake, the sake of my children, and the countless others who are in similar situations, do not ban my miracle.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,
 I am a 41 y.o. Male who suffers from chronic pain due to a serious motor vehicle accident in '06.
I have tried everything from painkillers to reiki to heroin. All of which had their pros & cons, some much worse than others with various degrees of success. After totally falling apart on street drugs, I was lucky enough to get some professional help in recovery which basically saved my life. Those were hard times.
Fast forward to last year & I'm gainfully employed & rebuilding what I destroyed in my quest for some relief from pain. I discovered kratom while searching for natural supplements that support pain relief. Admittedly doubtful of what kind of claims this herb had sparked online, I ordered a small amount to try.
Now today. Today I'm much happier & able to work & sleep almost normally! Doctors are hesitant to prescribe drugs to people with substance abuse history, so I have suffered for YEARS almost to the point of suicide! I haven't felt this good in a decade & now it's looking like it's going to get pulled away in a hasty panic.
please reconsider at least regulations or mandatory age before an all out ban! This plant makes my life and thousands of others infinitely more live able! Give kratom the chance it deserves!
Thank you for your consideration.
Neil cook

documents.commentText:
Kratom should be treated as a dietary supplement and not regulated as a drug. Its safety profile is comparable to other natural substances such as St. John's Wort, Valerian Root, Chamomile, Ashwagandha, etc.

I have used kratom regularly for many years and have never experienced any serious adverse affects. Even considering the occasional negative reaction to kratom, there is no reason it should be subject to regulation any stricter than caffeine. Statistics will show across the board in calls to poison control centers, ER visits, or alleged problems with dependency that the effects of caffeine will be more severe and occurring more often in each and every metric. There are confirmed deaths from caffeine overdose, there has never been a single death in history linked definitively to unadulterated kratom. If the FDA and DEA have determined that caffeine needs no significant regulation, then it would be entirely unreasonable to revoke the liberties of so many Americans who unanimously wish to continue to take kratom undisturbed. 

The public has not asked for regulation. A simple tally of the collective comments will show that the overwhelming majority believe the status quo of kratom ought to be preserved. Any scheduling by the Drug Enforcement Agency is utterly without justification. The Food and Drug Administration should cease all of its efforts to seize kratom shipments from law-abiding, American small business owners. In my experience with kratom vendors, I have seen nothing but the most responsible and ethical business practices.

documents.commentText: I am a pharmacist who has endometriosis as well as a bad back and I had a fusion in 2012.  I have been on chronic pain medication including opiates since 2009 and I haven't been able to work for 4 years.  My mom also has chronic pain due to lupus and spinal cysts and she had been on opiates for 13 years.  About 4 months ago my mom decided she wanted to get off the opiates and with her pain doctor she slowly got off but she was still having terrible pain.  I did research on Kratom and thought it would be worth a try for her because she tried marijuana and it wasn't helping much so she was thinking of going back on the opiates.  About 2 months ago she tried her first dose of kratom and had significant pain relief with no side effects.  I decided to try it in place of my opiates during the day and to my surprise I could go 8-12 hours without my opiates and with no withdrawal symptoms whereas if I had done that without kratom I would be having significant withdrawals.  I am working now on tapering off the prescription opiates solely to kratom and it is amazing.  Both my mom and I have significant pain relief and we don't have to take it every 4 hours like with the opiates or even every day.  Kratom has been a godsend for my mom and I and I am scared of it is no longer available my mom will go back on the prescription opiates she worked so hard to get off of.  As a pharmacist I am greatly encouraged by the possibilities with Kratom in getting people off chronic pain medication to something that truly can be taken only as needed without the strong dependence of opiates but with similar pain relief.  Please allow people to continue to use this herb that has helped so many people, thank you.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to you because I currently have not tried Kratom for my severe chronic pain, but want to as all other treatments have failed me. Let me give you some background information, I'll try to be a brief as possible. I promise, I do have a point at the end. 

My most disabling pain condition is chronic migraine (I haven't had a pain free day, or even hour, in over a decade now), along with other chronic pain. I got my first migraine when I was 4 years old, I didn't know what to do. I began banging my head on the floor at preschool, I was yelled at and put in time out. I tried to explain the pain, but I was ignored. I found out many years later that I wasn't alone, others also hit their head at a young age when the pain started. My mom knew immediately that it was a migraine (they run in our family), she had them bad as well, but no one got them as young as I did. I began having migraines once or twice a month and headaches weekly. Then as I started middle and high school, I began getting migraines a couple days a week, with more mild headache pain on other days. The pain was so bad that I would miss school weekly, but always made sure I did my work and had near straight A's through high school. When I was 17 to 18, I realized my pain just didn't seem to ever let up, and it was moderate to severe every day. By this time I tried several preventative and abortive medications, and saw a neurologist at UC San Francisco, but never got any relief. I was determined to keep "pushing through" the pain every day because I wanted to finish college, work a job, and support myself, I just wanted a normal life. I made myself hang out with friends, but always had the pain and always would collapse the second I was alone, into my bed in a dark room, no friends understood my pain. I graduated college, worked some jobs, supported myself for awhile, but it finally became too much to keep "pushing through." 

About 5 years ago I moved in with my mom, stopped working for a year, went back to work when my savings disappeared, then had to quit for good about 3 years ago. I am now on disability and have my mom basically taking care of me in every way, this isn't how life should be for a 30 year old. I can barely stand up long enough to shower because I'm too dizzy, I can barely stay at a healthy weight because of my nausea and vomiting, and I'm unable to drive anymore. Through all of this time, I've tried literally every medication and treatment in existence, even some meds that are only in trials now because my doctor wants me to feel better. I've been hospitalized several times, but the doctors can never get my pain down. I'm suffering constantly and I have nothing to turn to. 

I tell you all this because those of us who are in such constant pain need more to turn to, and every time the government just bans a potentially life saving medication before they even know anything about it, they're giving chronic pain patients even less options. I know many people through online pain support groups who have gotten some relief through using Kratom, and I recently began looking into it. Shortly after I did, I found out it was going to be banned. I literally cried because it's another thing that I can't even try now for pain relief. Chronic migraine disease is one of the hardest and most disabling conditions a person can have because the symptoms affect every part of the person (I'm unable to read because focusing my eyes increases pain, I can't enjoy concerts because I'm sensitive to sounds, I wear sunglasses constantly because light is so painful, I can only eat a few items because so many foods increase my nausea, I can't stand or walk much because I'm too dizzy, I barely sleep because the pain is so severe, the list goes on). There isn't a single treatment that helps everybody, in fact, most available treatments only help a small percentage of patients. This is why we need everything in existence available to us. 

I completely support further testing and understanding of Kratom, but please don't make it unavailable in the meantime. All the testing could take years or even more than a decade, and people who are suffering don't have that long to wait. Kratom has the potential to help so many people, and to have few side effects compared to most alternative medications. Patients who currently are using it don't have another option, please don't take it away from them, or from me. Kratom could be lifesaving for myself, and may even mean that I could function as a normal human, work and support myself, live my life. I can't afford to have access denied to another medication. 

I am sorry for such a long message. I sincerely hope that my concerns are listened to and taken to heart. The current medications that are available are not helping me or thousands like me, so we need other options. Kratom is more natural and very different from what's available, please keep it available to patients who truly need it.

documents.commentText:
First of all, I think that kratom would be more appropriately regulated by the FDA than by the DEA. There appears to be a consensus among scientific evidence and user experiences that kratom is far less harmful--using almost any metric--than alcohol or tobacco, which are both effectively regulated by the FDA. Under FDA regulation, quality standards and age restrictions could be imposed upon kratom cultivation and sales, which would effectively reduce any harms presented by the plant. Not only would this solution be appropriate in light of other currently-regulated substances, it would also be the optimal solution for the purpose of public health. There is considerable evidence for public health benefits associated with kratom (e.g. diversion from illegal drugs, cessation of illegal opioid use, improved productivity and motivation, pain relief), but significantly less evidence for public health risks associated with kratom (e.g. dependency that is far less severe than that associated with alcohol or prescription opioids, overdose toxicity only when used in conjunction with other substances, liver toxicity in some extremely small percentage of the population). Considering that kratom's public health risk-to-benefit ratio is relatively trivial when compared to substances currently controlled by the DEA (e.g. heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine) and is even less than some substances currently regulated by the FDA (e.g. tobacco and alcohol), it would be more appropriate to subject kratom to FDA regulation than to DEA regulation. I would estimate that kratom's public health risk-to-benefit ratio is much closer to that of caffeine than to alcohol or any controlled substance. 

Second, I am strongly against regulating kratom as a prescription drug, as I believe that this would severely undermine its public health benefits for two reasons. First, many adults responsibly use kratom for occasional recreation or self-medication without causing any social harm; regulating kratom as a prescription drug would unduly interfere with their autonomy to consume products in accordance with their preferences. Second, and perhaps more importantly, many former opioid addicts have ceased using opioids through use of kratom, which is far less harmful to their health and overall well-being; arguably, the health effects of kratom are much less significant than those presented by pharmaceutical opiate cessation products like suboxone or methadone. Unfortunately, many people who use kratom as an opiate cessation product do not have health insurance, cannot afford pharmaceutical treatments, or prefer to maintain their privacy by avoiding healthcare providers; whatever their reasons, they have decided that self-medication with kratom is the best solution for them, and the government should not interfere with this freedom of choice without some compelling reason for doing so. Our government currently allows for the unregulated use of many different herbal supplements and health products, and kratom should be treated similarly to these other legal herbal supplements unless there is overwhelming evidence that it presents significant risks to public health, which there most certainly is not. People have been safely using kratom for centuries around the world, and I see no compelling reason to suddenly ban it; I am certain that doing so would harm many more people than it helps.

Finally, I would like to give you some background information about myself and my reasons for writing this comment today. I am currently a law student who has used kratom over the past few years to manage my chronic muscle pain and fatigue; more importantly, I have used kratom in order to avoid using dangerous illegal drugs that I previously struggled to stay away from. In my experience with kratom, I have found that the benefits greatly outweigh any risks. Since I began using kratom, I have been able to consistently manage my personal and professional affairs without suffering from the bouts of depression and fatigue that used to severely hinder my achievement. Moreover, I have been able to abstain from using illicit drugs, which were once a major problem in my life. The only downsides I've experienced in using kratom are occasional constipation that I've effectively managed by increasing my fiber intake, an extra monthly expense of around $100 that is well worth the benefits to my overall well-being (and far cheaper than pharmaceutical or black market alternatives), and a dependency that I find far less harmful and debilitating than the dependencies I would otherwise likely have (i.e. alcohol, illegal opiates, etc.). As far as I know, no one has ever died from standalone kratom use, but only when concurrently using other more dangerous drugs. Furthermore, anyone who has used kratom will agree that there is a definite "ceiling" on its effects; taking more kratom will not result in stronger desired effects, but rather, regular moderate usage produces optimum results.

documents.commentText:
PLEASE do NOT put Kratom on the List of Schedule I Drugs. KRATOM IS NOT A DANGEROUS DRUG.  I am 59 years old and I have been using kratom everyday for OVER 3 years now. I take kratom for my back pain (I have 2 compression fractures of the spine) and for my osteoarthritis AND IT DEFINITELY HELPS. I also take kratom for my severe anxiety and depression and sleep problems AND IT DEFINITELY HELPS. I also should mention that I do NOT take any RX or OTC drugs -- NONE. And, I do NOT drink alcohol.

I do NOT take kratom to get high. Kratom does NOT get me high no matter how much I take. I  do NOT crave more and more kratom even after daily use for 3+ years -- I always take the same amount everyday. Kratom is not addicting like heroin, it's much closer to a coffee addiction which I can easily deal with [IF] I have to. We all are addicted to something, be it coffee, sugar, wheat, cigarettes, alcohol, drugs, gambling or fast food. The fact is... too much of anything can be bad for you and could lead to an addiction. The fact is nobody has died [specifically] from taking too much kratom ALONE. 

Why not just regulate kratom in the same way you regulate alcohol, cigarettes and E-cigarettes which are definitely more of a health problem than kratom. The industry needs to come together to self-regulate and self-police one another and get rid of some of the bad apples out there.

I support placing an age restriction on kratom for consumers who are 18 or older. I also believe that stricter labeling guidelines are necessary. Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding shouldnt use kratom, for example, and anyone with a medical condition or who is taking prescription medications should consult their doctor before trying kratom. Perhaps most importantly, make sure that products arent being deliberately marketed toward younger consumers, or with the intent of comparing its effects to other drugs, like actual opiates.

Kratom is a tropical plant in the coffee family from Southeast Asia that has been used to support energy and focus, as well as a potent immune system booster.  Kratom is inherently safe and shares many therapeutic constituents in common with other widely recognized medicinal plants such as Cats Claw and Yohimbe, which currently enjoy wide spread safe usage as dietary supplements in the United States and abroad.

The DEA, without a serious review of the available scientific literature, has chosen to emergency schedule Kratom and designate it as schedule I substance; one that has no accepted medical value. The common citizen can easily perform a search for Mitragyna speciosa in Google scholar and find over 1,660 search results documenting the potential medical value of Kratom.  The DEA has not only turned a blind eye to the scientific literature, but it has also taken the stance that it is uninterested in hearing testimony from Kratom users who use it for its therapeutic value.  Thus, the DEA considers any and all use of Kratom to be abuse, while ignoring the medical literature, NIH funded studies, numerous patents, and millions of users testimonies, all of which point to its therapeutic potential.

Rather than consider the therapeutic potential for Kratom, the DEA has unilaterally moved to make millions of felons out of Kratom users who are simply using Kratom in accordance with its historical use, its patented use, and the conclusions of thousands of scientific studies. Allowing the DEA to unilaterally criminalize the use of Kratom will not only create millions of felons out of otherwise law abiding citizens, but it will also halt all scientific investigations into Kratoms medicinal benefits which would benefit millions of other law abiding citizens.  With America currently suffering from an opiate epidemic and opiate related overdoses at an all-time high, a policy that prohibits the research of therapeutic compounds does not make sense.  

Furthermore, the economic impact of the criminalization of Kratom will have unforeseen consequences due to the enforcement costs and public health costs associated with addiction such as emergency room visits due to substituting Rx medicines, petty theft to obtain said Rx medicines, etc.  Lastly, harsh penalties, such as a felony charge for possessing Kratom will not only be ineffective in preventing its use but it will also severely limit otherwise law abiding citizens future prospects, a challenge that can be permanently damaging to individuals, while costing US citizens tax revenue that can be better spent.
