documents.commentText:
Im a 46 year old professional. I am a registered pharmacist, but have been employed as a software engineer in the healthcare industry for the past 20 years. 
I have a long history or social anxiety, anxiety, and panic attacks. I went the route of prescription medications for years, suffered debilitating side effects from them, and realized very little benefit from them. My doctor and I werent able to find a medication or combination that would help me. For a while, I wasnt even comfortable leaving my house and going into public, driving to work, and the like. I used to dread just having to get in the car to go somewhere and I almost lost my job because of this. There were several occasions where I ended up in the ER from panic attacks, and on one occasion, was even admitted overnight since I was having chest pain and was convinced I was having a heart attack.

I found out about kratom about 12 years ago when browsing a social anxiety support forum and have been using it daily since. I was able to stop my prescription anti-anxiety and antidepressant medications and feel better than I ever have.  I am now a productive member of society, hold a respectable job, and can go to work and in public without worrying about panic attacks and anxiety. Even on medication I wasn't comfortable doing this. Now, even large crowds arent an issue for me.

Once I started using Kratom, I no longer had the urge to drink since my anxiety was under control using kratom. I drank daily for quite a long period of time (in attempts to ease my anxiety) prior to finding this wonderful plant. I have not had a drink in the past 12 years. The amount of kratom I use has not increased or changed at all over this time period. Using it for anxiety and panic disorder, I have used the same amount daily for almost 12 years without any reduced effectiveness. 

Kratom has completely changed my life for the better and I am just one of a large number of Americans that benefit from it. Over the past 12 years I have not noticed the slightest side effect and I am as healthy as I have ever been. My doctor is aware of my kratom use and has encouraged me to keep using it since it has enabled me to stop taking SSRIs, benzodiazepines, and no longer drink. My lab work is all within normal limits, and she feels this is a great alternative for me since it has kept me off of several medications that are addictive and have side effects. Also, removing the desire to consume alcohol is a big win in her opinion since in the long run (outside of its damaging health effects) it really just aggravates and exacerbates my anxiety issues. 

Kratom has been the only thing that has worked for me after suffering for years juggling many different prescriptions medications that provided little if any relief and I finally found something that returned me to being a functioning member of society. I feel the benzodiazepines and SSRI medications I was previously prescribed are both very addictive (again Im a pharmacist) and were extremely hard to taper from when I stopped using them. I think the SSRI withdrawal was worse than the benzodiazepines for me. I didnt feel normal or myself for almost six months after coming off of Paxil. My doctor helped me slowly wean off of them, but it was still not easy. In contrast, there have been several times I have gone without kratom for a few days here and there, and did not notice any significant withdrawal, just my anxiety symptoms returning. 

I do not want to have to return to taking a cocktail of SSRI and benzodiazepine medications to control my anxiety, but thats what I will have to do if kratom becomes a schedule I substance. These medications clouded my judgment and basically turned me into a zombie. I didnt feel like myself. In contrast, kratom is almost like having a cup of coffee in the morning. It wakes me up, allows me to focus and controls my anxiety, all without clouding my head. I basically feel normal and like myself again. Kratom is the only thing that has worked for me.
 
Thank you.

Kratom seemed to excise that addicted part from my brain and I've had a reawakening in my mid-40s.

I experienced no cravings for more kratom.  When I've taken it, the most I've gotten from it recreationally is a sense of clarity and greater cognition, some mild elation and sometimes chattiness.  This does not come close to opioids or benzos, both of which have stronger effects and are definitely addictive.  Taking too much kratom just leads to sleepiness and dozing off. 

Any crimes committed that involved kratom were all found to include drugs that cause people to do crazy things (PCP, booze, etc).  Its not the kratom!

documents.commentText:
Kratom has helped give me my life back. After a bad car accident (of not my fault) left me with a fractured spine (in several spots) I was told I'd be in pain for the rest of my life- all before the age of 20. Post accident I was written prescriptions left and right for nerve damage, pain and the resulting mental illness (depression). The pain medications (all various opiates from dilaudid to hydrocodone) definitely helped cover the pain but did nothing for my life improvement. I quickly got addicted and ended up failed out of college, self harming and nearly suicidal. Going through constant withdrawal until my next prescription and running out too early from taking more than prescribed. It sucked because while I knew I couldn't be on these substances (for health and social/work/general life reasons) I could hardly function due to pain. A double edged sword. Then a friend told me about Kratom, sold at my local health and wellness store. I was skeptical and at first used kratom to help ease withdrawal between prescriptions but then I noticed the pain relief AND it didn't make me foggy or tired. I never craved more kratom as I had the opiates. Ever. And still to this day (2 years of kratom) do not. Switching to kratom has helped me get my life back. I can work an 8 hour day and go to class with full focus and minimal pain. I can do normal things with my friends and family without worrying when my next 'dose' is. I'm a normal person. I actually feel like I contribute to my home and community. I am not a drain on resources. All other pain/accident prescribed medications are out of my life- for the better. Kratom has helped me become me again, someone I sorely missed when opiates had their grasp on me.

If kratom becomes schedule 1 I am terrified for my future. Will I be able to continue to excel at work? Will I be able to finish and graduate college? All because pain is back to controlling my life? Will it be so bad I have no choice but to go back on opiate medications? 

Please hear us. Kratom saves. It doesn't kill.

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText: If there is one thing I want to get across in this comment, it s that kratom helps and it has never hurt me. My name is Sarah Oliver and I am a twenty two year old woman living in Colorado with my small, but close, family. I have been taking kratom for six years. I have been experiencing severe and debilitating chronic pain my entire life, which has impacted my mental health in the past. This pain prevented me from getting any sleep, ever. I lost so much weight because I could not eat. I  nearly even lost my life to suicide. I lost the ability to stay standing for more than a few minutes at a time and have been dependent on a mobility aid since my freshman year of college. I suffer from a plethora of conditions that make day-to-day life almost unbearable, but I press on every day and have actively been taking charge of my own life. I am proud to say that I am pursuing a degree again after my chronic pain stole away my first attempt at higher education, as well as both my jobs, and I am working with a doctor who supports my choice to choose kratom to make my pain a little bit better. I am not making any health claims when I say this; I take kratom because my pain prevents me from being able to stand up and take care of myself, and I suffer. I want to be able to stand up long enough to prepare food to myself, and I want to be able to help out around the house, and I want to be able to walk outside and check the mail. When I found kratom, I was struggling to adjust to my disabled body. My abilities had changed so drastically and so quickly, and I was still so young. The frustration of not being able to walk like I used to was awful. I came across kratom in a little shop along a street in Savannah, and was told that other customers buy it for their back pain. I bought it, and Im very glad I made that decision. Kratom helps me because even though there is nothing I can do about my illness and I still wake up in exhausting pain every morning, I know that when I take my kratom, I wont be in such a state of suffering that I cant get out of bed and I will be able to have some sort of quality of life. I want to maintain this quality of life. I have never experienced any form of respiratory depression from taking kratom, and kratom has never caused me to suffer. Kratom has not cured my illness, but it is an immense blessing for me. Please save kratom.

documents.commentText:
I am a 35yr old father, husband, and am employed full time in IT. I have been diagnosed w/ myofascial pain syndrome(very similar to fibromyalgia) in 2009.

 I have chronic pain in my shoulder & spine that I deal w/ on a daily basis. As anyone who has chronic pain issues the quality of life is extremely low because of how you constantly hurt. Every single day I have pain, pain that radiates throughout my back & shoulder & just doesn't stop. 

It also causes depression due to the fact that I cannot partake in the simplest things in life like going to the movies, helping around the house, or even holding my child to put them to sleep or hold them in general. All I can do is lay down because the pain is so intense. Pain has robbed me of the joy I used to have in my life, pain changes who you are, it makes you easily irritable because it just doesn't stop, it's inescapable.

When you are in pain like that, you are not the same person.

I've been on many different pain meds, muscle relaxers, anti-depressants and like most people they stop working after a while because your body gets used to them. So when you have to ask your doctor for something else/stronger they treat you like a drug addict because of the medication you need, when all you want is relief so you can have a semi-normal productive life.

I've been made out to be a drug seeker or liar because I've gone through different pain meds over the years because  they all eventually stop giving you the relief you seek. 

So where does that leave someone to turn?

I decided to seek out something natural to help w/ my chronic pain & I found Kratom.

I started Kratom in 2012 & Kratom has been a Godsend for me!  It has given me pain relief when narcotic pain medication failed, to me that is priceless, it is lifeblood, it is my light in the dark.

Kratom has given me the ability to live & work & be a productive father,husband, friend, a human being again!

If Kratom becomes illegal, you are denying people the fundamental human right to seek something natural & not chemical for their well-being, for their health. If we don't have our health then what do we have? 

Why punish those who seek a more natural treatment for themselves rather than known addictive substances that have shown to destroy lives, families, and cause death??

Everyone sees the epidemic of narcotic drug abuse & death in this country, why take away a more healthy alternative to that which is non addictive & does not ruin people's lives?

If Kratom becomes illegal you leave people w/ chronic pain no choice of what to use for relief. 
You create a bigger monster, more lives destroyed, more children w/out parents, more parents w/ out children.

Please don't leave us w/out a choice, that's what made this country & makes this country great = choice!

Please keep Kratom legal, it gives people like me the ability to have joy again, to feel normal again, to hold their children again.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
Thank you for the opportunity to allow for a public comment. I hope that my comment, along with many others will help keep Kratom save, legal, and regulated like tobacco and alcohol. Opioid addiction dependency is something that can happen to anyone. It is not something that is reserved for teenagers looking for a high. I imagine my story is going to be told over and over in these comments. For me, pain pills were just a once in a while recreation used to help with a sore back or when I just wanted to relax. I graduated with a bachelors and got a good full time job right out of college in 2009 (worst time to come out of college). Then, like many people, I began self-medicating and turned a once in a while recreation into an everyday habit. It did not affect my work, but it turned into a regular thing to get normal. It took a huge event to scare me off to quit cold turkey. I felt the after effects of Vicodin withdrawal for at least 3 months. 
This disgusting habit was a huge financial burden and the craving always remained. A friend told me about Kratom as a cheap, safe and effective pain relief. After one use, my craving was completely gone. Unlike opioids, it doesnt actually get you high or mellow your mood. You function the same as normal but it helps with aches and pains from sports or whatever else. As someone who has tried to quit with other drugs like suboxone and weening myself off, this was much more effective. It simply gets rid of your craving and feels much like a real good cup of coffee or green tea. 
I get that Drugs are not accepted in society as an illness. It is a stigma and we throw people with addiction under the normalcy of society and force people to hide it or even worse, put a blotch on their criminal record or throw them in jail. Many countries around the world have figured this out but we lag far behind. The kratom community is not a large one but it has helped us. We are 100% supportive of regulation and age restrictions but banning it would be horrible for us. Its not only a potential research opportunity but it saves lives now. Banning natural herbs that help responsible adults will only drive us back into the spirals of previous life. There is a real opioid epidemic that our society is struggling to solve. Getting rid of options for people who dont want to be addicted to pain killers in their 30s is the opposite of what we should be doing. Please hear us and take our voices into account.

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.

http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

Please reconsider your decision to schedule kratom. It is unconscionable to make a move that is so severe, and one which has proven to be nearly irreversible, based on absolutely zero facts and/or data. This plant should be studied and analyzed, but labeling it a schedule 1 drug guarantees there will be no studies, or so few that its use, and more importantly, the understanding of its usefulness (or even dangers) will be hamstrung for decades to come.

We have already seen the effects on scientific analysis that labeling anything a schedule 1 drug can have. Instead of science giving us hard facts on the efficacy or dangers of marijuana, we have the people from many states speaking louder than the government voting to legalize without any facts to back or refute these votes. Don't add another mistake to your resume.

documents.commentText:
Dear US Representatives of the American People,

Here is the subject:  Docket No. DEA-442W, Please Do Not Place Kratom as Schedule 1.
I am writing this letter asking all my elected representatives, including US President Obama, Members of the US House of Representatives, Members of the US Senate, and my Nevada State Lawmakers, to thoughtfully and with great consideration, to NOT place Kratom on the Scheduled Substance List.

Through no fault of their own, millions of Americans like myself have suffered with debilitating health conditions that have adversely impacted their ability to function a quality, pain free, normal daily life.  With limited resources, many as myself, soon found themselves seeking relief in differing ways.  Some options, as opiates, feed into the ever-growing opioid addiction epidemic, while other alternative dietary supplements, as Kratom, not only mitigate and provide relief from suffering, but can also be utilized to assist those with opioid addictions to safely wean and withdraw from opiate use, lessen the super harsh withdrawal side effects of opiates, and mainly support a natural, more healthful lifestyle and life choices. This is true for me personally, an active 62-year young, public school teacher who aggressively and lovingly educates a classroom full of energetic 3rd graders daily in a Title 1 School here in Las Vegas.

As the Information Age and social media opens up our world to vast stores of information, folks as myself are more empowered to do their own research and discover alternative ways or methods to enhance the quality of their lives and to become more healthy in the process.  Kratom has had a positive effect and impact on 3 to 5 million Americans today who have willingly come forward to share their personal experiences with Kratom, which, by the way, many such individuals have attested to successfully withdrawing from opiates while consuming Kratom. Overall, the vast population of Kratom consumers will happily share with you their much improved health and well-being, reduced suffering from existing conditions, and gratitude that they had at last found Kratom! This as well, has also encouraged me to step forward and speak about my own happy experience to you. 

The streams of Grass Roots, positive affirmations that Kratom is both safe and healthful should mean something to our nations Lawmakers, and I pray that my letter will be added to support Kratom because I have used Kratom and have also benefited greatly in my health, well-being, and stamina as both as a senior citizen, but also as a full-time elementary school teacher with a classroom full of energetic third graders. Over the years I have written to you and signed petitions about my growing concern with the health industry to both you and in the newspapers.  Recently, out of desperation, I did my own research and decided to try Kratom.  My family members and friends know how awful and debilitating my own chronic health had been for over a decade, and can tell you theres a light years positive difference today with me consuming Kratom.  To my amazement, Kratom is really helpful, and is truly safe.  My wish is for Kratom to remain freely available and it also would be wonderful if my teachers health insurance would cover some of the cost because it is a bit expensive. But I am thrilled at this point, and would gladly come to testify as a citizen if called to do so.

Truly, Kratom does not belong on the Scheduled Substance List.  Kratom should continue to be available as a dietary supplement for conscientious consumers like myself, in the health market.  Individuals are far better served in such a way, and this practice is sustainable, freeing up our country and community to pursue other more pressing concerns that affect our quality of life.

Thank you for your time reading my letter of support for Kratom, for your kind consideration in keeping Kratom off the Scheduled Substance List, and for continuing to make Kratom available to the health conscious and aware public consumer.

Ranting aside, my experience with kratom specifically is that it's really not that much different or intense than coffee.  You worry about this as an addictive entity, it's not; at least no more than you could mentally become addicted to anything. Granted I only use about once a week, but I've not dealt with any withdrawal symptoms ever.  The potential for abuse is low because at higher doses the effects become unpleasant.  Everything I've read about it has indicated that it does NOT lower your heart rate like opiates do and the deaths that supposedly have been attributed to kratom are not the kratom itself, but it's because they were in combination with other pharmaceuticals.  Folks who have been addicted to opiates are using kratom to get off of opiates.  Don't stand in the way of freedom!

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

As a graduate student in Clinical Psychology, I've seen first hand how kratom can help patients alleviate pain. Given the median lethal dose is incredibly difficult to reach, it has a favorable safety profile compared to stronger opiates. 

My primary reason for opposing the scheduling of this drug is so researchers can continue to study this chemical and elucidate it's mechanism of action and discover potential medicinal uses. There is currently a paucity of literature on this topic, it would be extremely beneficial to study this drug further. Perhaps there are some negative side effects which have yet to be discovered, or perhaps not. Either way, by scheduling kratom many patients will be harmed and research will be limited to other countries. 

Finally, I would like to report an anecdotal report of one patient who tapered off prescription opiates and regularly uses kratom instead. This patient reported some side effects of the prescription opiates (severe constipation), which lead to a number of medication changes. Now, they just take kratom.

Sincerely,
Travis Stewart

documents.commentText:
It's almost impossible to compare Kratom to illegal narcotics.  Just like any kind of medicine, an overdose can lead to very unpleasant effects and therefore care should be taken to avoid such complications.  I support restricting its sale to those over 18, but that's about all the restriction necessary to keep people safe.  Kratom is not deadly, aside from the rare cases where there is an underlying medical problem or the kratom has been mixed with another substance.

Side effects aside, kratom is helping hundreds of thousands of Americans battling opiate addiction, pain, depression and anxiety.  Placing kratom into an illegal substance category will have  unintended consequences, such as addicts returning to their more volatile prescriptions or illegal opiates.  This will undoubtedly lead to more dangerous substance abuse, causing deaths, relapses, and increased property crime.  The DEA should take all of the repercussions into consideration before hastily banning the component, of which they know so little about.

documents.commentText:
My name is Greg Walker and I'm an active voter in NJ.

Kratom is a plant leaf that has been helping me for over 3 years with NO NEGATIVE EFFECTS. 
[I use it 3 times a day as a supplement and it helps me a lot with my daily life.]

I work full time as a Coordinator of Technology Services at a school in NJ and have been there for 7 years. In fact, with the exception of during college I've been employed ever since the age of 12.

I provide for my family of 3 (soon to be 4).
I pay my taxes.
I give back to my community.

I'm sending you this heartfelt letter to let you know that this plant (a member of the coffee family) has been helping me stay on a straight path. A car accident and the subsequent pain medication I was prescribed caused a physical and mental addiction just like it does with millions of people. Thank goodness I had family and friends to help support me through my recovery. I've been fully 'clean' now for over 7 years and I feel great. 

Before Kratom, there was always a temptation to do something; maybe drink a few beers or margaritas when I got home, and smoke cigarettes. It was just this little thought in the back of my head that stayed there.

When I found Kratom I found that it took away those thoughts completely. I've been cigarette free for over 2 and a half years and rarely drink alcohol (maybe twice a month at most). I have a healthy smoothie that I make every day when I get home from work and then spend quality time with my wife and 2 and half year old daughter. We have one more daughter coming around Nov. 4th.

When I heard that the DEA published a letter (on Aug 31st 2016) of intent to schedule Kratom (on Sept 30th 2016) I was horrified.

The company I've always used to purchase Kratom from is super professional and I really love them over there. Great customer support, great product consistency, etc. Two months ago they moved to a new warehouse in a new state to streamline things. I'm sure they had to sign a year lease on the space... What now, they just default on payments and go out of business? What about all the other small businesses just like them?

Honestly, I'm having a hard time coping with the idea that I could go to bed one night and wake up the next morning a criminal because I still have some Kratom left over from my last order... The DEA is pushing this WAY too quickly. We need a public forum for our voices to be heard. This is not a 'bath salts' situation; no matter how much they try to make it sound the same. I have taken 7 grams of dried powdered leaf 3 times a day (21 grams/day) for over 3 years. The only ill effect in the beginning was having harder stools. That passed within two weeks. Now there's NO negative at all. I take it in the morning and go about my business; just like someone might do with St. John's Wort or Chamomile Tea.

As you are probably already aware; in the U.S., Kratom has become popular among people coping with chronic pain and others trying to wean themselves off opioids or alcohol. The main chemical is mitragynine. It binds to some of the same receptors as opioids, providing some pain relief and a calming effect, but, NOT the same high. It's important that I state this: The plant and its chemicals are NOT Opioids. The chemical doesn't cause the same, sometimes deadly, side effects as opioids, such as respiratory depression.

""On August 31, the Drug Enforcement Agency published a "notice of intent" in the Federal Register
stating its plan to list the herb as a Schedule I substance, the most restrictive category, alongside
heroin and LSD, effective September 30th with no opportunity for a public comment period.""

I was very active in helping to tell the FCC that internet providers should be treated like utilities because these days the internet is a necessity. I helped sway the FCC's decision and I really hope to help sway the DEA's decision.

Heck if they wanted to ban synthetic chemicals derived from the plant; or even highly potent extracts of the leaf I'd be ok with that. BUT; the regular leaf should remain legal. And even if the ultimate decision is made to ban it; it should be done in a year after open public forums and stories like mine reverberating throughout the country.

Alabama actually banned Kratom a while back and their overdose rates went up because people were going back to their "old ways".

The DEA cites about 15 poison control center calls involving Kratom; but I want to point out that all of those cases had several other drugs in their systems as well. To put it in perspective, more than 15 people died falling out of bed within the past 6 months.

documents.commentText:
ANONYMOUS, 42yr old Female, Pharmaceutical Logistics Sr. Associate (Professional)

I believe the request by the DEA to make Kratom a Schedule I controlled substance is unfair, inaccurate, and irresponsible.  I have had little to NO side effects from using Kratom.  There is much concern to what will happen to people if the DEA has their way.  I believe it should be up to the person on what works best for them in using Kratom, I have personally found NO dangers in using it. I sincerely hope that the DEA/government will decide to leave this innocent leaf alone and the people who appreciate its uses.  I hope they respect us enough to let us decide for ourselves what we need and it isnt Opioids.
In the fall of 2010, I was diagnosed with no disc between my L5-S1 and neck problems (the bones in my neck look the opposite of what a neck should look like in an x-ray).  Because of this issue, I had severe pain in my legs, radiating from my back (sciatica).  I developed issues in my feet where I could barely walk for at least an hour in the morning.  I have worn heels and flat shoes most of my life. I was sworn to wearing tennis shoes with business attire for work.  There werent many options for me because of my job.  I had headaches DAILY; all day every day.  It was getting so bad that I was having approximately 4 migraines a month for over a year.  I considered leaving my job as the breadwinner and doing something less stressful on my body and without the commitment of getting up every day at a certain time to go to work.  I was depressed and miserable.  Enough was enough for me!
In regards to my medication and lifestyle; I ONLY used pain medication when I was in pain; started in 2010 with 5 mg Hydrocodone, then 2011 moved to 7.5mg Hydrocodone, and 2014 moved up to 10mg Hydrocodone with Percocet (2-3 per week @ 5mg).  With Opioids you develop a tolerance and then you need to increase the mg/dosage in order to have the same effect in reduction of pain (pain was never eliminated).  In addition to pain medication, I used approximately 800-1600mg of ibuprofen a day.  Just to be clear, I do not have an addictive personality, nor do I drink alcohol, or take any illicit drugs or experiment with anything that is not given by a doctor or pharmacy (OTC).  I am a responsible adult, who has her own home, cars, and a job that Ive had for over 12 years.  The job before that I had for over 7 years.  I am what you call a steady Eddie.  I follow the law to the letter, no misdemeanors or felonies, no problems with the law&.Ive gotten only 2 traffic tickets in my whole life. I am married with 2 stepsons and 2 dogs.  I only eat out 1-2x a week; I typically eat salads, fruits, veggies, and low fat meat, some healthy carbs. 
Over a year and a half ago, I began looking into trying Kratom.  This started because I had been tossed around for 4 years between a back doctor, 3 pain management doctors,  2 other specialists/doctors, a chiropractor, 2.5 years of physical therapy (2-3x a week), 3 steroid injections in my back, change in different types of pharmaceuticals, changing DEA laws, and the changing pharmacy issues.  I, again, had had enough!  I had heard it could help with pain reduction and increase quality of life.  I was not yet a believer until I tried it.  I use it as a tea and add nothing to it except Stevia (because it is quite bitter).  For over a year now, I make 2-3 Kratom teas a day, using approximately a teaspoon at a time.  I sip on those and within 15 minutes, my pain is reduced.  I have not used pain medication since the DAY I tried the Kratom tea.  I still have my pain medication sitting in my medicine cabinet that I stopped that day.  I had tried stopping before, cold turkey, and could not do it; because of pain AND body addiction.  I had no cravings after my 2nd Kratom tea.  My feet quit hurting literally, within hours of drinking the tea, they have NEVER hurt like they did before.  The best I can explain is that it feels like it blocks the craving for an opioid and then reduces pain; A sense of warmth in my back and feet and neck.  I rarely have to take any ibuprofen, usually because I have a headache here and there (about once a week).  I have only had 2 migraines in over a year.  Im not sure what caused what and when, but I can tell you that I am a TON better off without Opioids and with Kratom.  I have had no side effects from the Kratom tea.  I went from missing time at work, to back to my old self of never missing work.  I enjoy my life now, more appreciative of what I have, because I was so miserable for so long.  My husband knows the difference because he lives with me.  He is also very thankful for Kratom.  It has made a world of difference in not only my life, but in my relationships with others.  I can be myself again.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA

Below is a testimony written by my colleague who wishes to remain anonymous. He is a father, husband and sole bread-winner of the family. This is in response to the DEA's intention to make Kratom a Schedule I substance. It includes a great amount of information on what Kratom is and the what will happen if the DEA goes through with the emergency scheduling.

Thanks,

Faye

Dear DEA,
 
Please remove Mitragynine & 7-hydroxymitragynine which is in Kratom from becoming a Schedule I substance.
 
I am 29 and suffer from a herniated disc, chronic neck pain, TMJ, arthritis in my neck. I support a family of four on a single income as a Help Desk Tech. I have been to many doctors with little success for treatment. I have found that Kratom improves my quality of life after a hard days work. It isnt comparable to any drugs, marijuana, alcohol or other stimulants.  Kratom helps to improve my quality of life that I suffer with chronic pain. Please dont make this herb illegal. Cervical injections, botox injections, chiropractic care, physical therapy, acupuncture, massage therapy, yoga exercises have not helped with my pain.
 
Kratom is a well-known, well-researched herbal substance drawn from the leaves of trees within the coffee family. The number of cases of documented harm from kratom use is remarkably low, both as an absolute matter and when considered against the extensive history of use of kratom, both inside and outside the United States
 
Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine are two of the primary alkaloids of this plant. These two compounds are not synthetic and should not be lumped together with  "bath salts" or "spice".
 
Kratom has been used as a medicine by many people for thousands of years. It is a potent remedy for physical pain, anxiety and depression, and could be used to aid with opiate withdrawal by those who would like to quit using illicit drugs such as heroin. Kratom is NOT a hallucinogen and should not be classified as such. Adding mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as a Schedule I substance is rash and unjustified prohibition, resulting in a foreseeable increase in street drug-related crime, as well as a punishment to those who are currently using it responsibly to treat various ailments.

The reason that there are no deaths solely attributed to Kratom is because Kratom does not affect your respiratory capacity. It does not slow down your central nervous system. It's potential to do harm is virtually impossible.

Kratom has very limited recreational capacity.  The White House petition has over 100,000 signatures for the "Please do not make Kratom a Schedule I Substance." 

The federal government has invested significant resources to develop alternative pain management strategies. This includes a study funded by the National Institutes of Health in partnership with the University of Massachusetts and the University of Mississippi to investigate the use of Kratom as a remedy for opioid withdrawal. This study led the researchers to apply for a patent identifying the Kratom extract, mitragyinine, as a useful treatment for other addictive drugs besides opiate derivatives. The DEAs decision to place Kratom as a Schedule I substance will put a halt on federally funded research and innovation surrounding the treatment of individuals suffering from opioid and other addictionsa significant public health threat. Remember the DDear Colleague Letters of Senator Hatch and Congressman Mark Pocan.
 
We hope you realize the threat this scheduling causes the people seeking legitimate use of this special plant to improve our quality of life. Attached are testimonies and facts about Kratom along with other facts listed below. 

Sincerely,
 
Anonymous

documents.commentText:
In 2005 I was in a car crash that involved my 18 year old baby brother and my twins girls that were 2 years old.  A truck hit my car and it killed my brother instantly, the next day at the hospital one of my twins, Kirsten died and both my other twin, Kelsie and I were hospitalized.  Our major injuries included Kelsie having a lacerated liver and I had a broken back.  My father gave up on life and died 2 years later.  Over half of my family was gone.  While in the hospital I was given opioid pain pills, benzodiazepines and soma muscle relaxers.  When I left the hospital my doctor continued to prescribe me these medications.  Not long after, I found myself addicted to these drugs, especially the opioids.  My husband was in the Army but was granted a discharge due to the severity of the accident and our family situation.  He also became addicted to these drugs.  I found myself putting myself at risk by going to the streets to get more of the pain pills.  What was left of my family quickly started to fall apart.  My husband and I were in and out of rehabs and had many relapses.  We found kratom and all we know is that this plant has helped us.  I struggle with anxiety, depression, pain and addiction issues and he struggles with anxiety and addiction issues.  We found that when we would take kratom we did not crave other drugs, especially opiates or synthetic opioids.  It also gave us a sense of well-being, energy and helped me with pain.  Today we are responsible adults that no longer seek drugs.  My husband finally was able to obtain his BA in Business Management and I finally was able to obtain my BS in Psychology and I am currently working on my MS in Professional Counseling.  We use kratom responsibly and we are productive citizens.  I do not ever want to go back to all the different pharmaceutical medications I was on because I was not a productive member of society.  I took from society.  Now both my husband and I give back to society.  We are great spouses, parents and productive American citizens!  I think that kratom should have an age restriction similar to those for alcohol or cigarettes.  I also think an organization should monitor kratom so that irresponsible people cannot mix dangerous substances with it.  To me alcohol is more of a health crisis than kratom.  We see more alcohol related deaths.  I do not think that it should have to be dispensed by a doctor so they and the pharmaceutical companies can make more profit.  They are rich enough.  Alcohol is very addictive and a doctor does not have to dispense it.  Taking kratom does not make you "high" like opiates or other dangerous drugs.  It is more like drinking a good cup of coffee that gives you a sense of well-being with the bonus of helping to ease pain.  It is wonderful for this country, especially with the opiate crisis we have here in the U.S..  Kratom helps people to stop taking dangerous substances such as, heroin, suboxone, synthetic opioids and even alcohol.  I ask you to please not schedule kratom at all.  It has helped way more people than it has hurt and the same cannot be said of legal substances, such as alcohol and cigarettes.

Sincerely,


Regina Caminita Gabilondo

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

Kratom, Mitragynine, and 7-Hydroxymitraginine MUST REMAIN LEGAL and in good standing with society and government, for multiple reasons. 

1.) Kratom is NOT a drug, it is a plant. The Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitraginine compounds in question by the DEA are naturally occurring chemicals, just like caffeine, ethanol, acetic acid, or lactose. Govenment has no authority to declare God's creation evil and withhold it from the People. A ban on Kratom is a violation of natural law and religious freedom. Furthermore, government has no authority to declare nature unnatural, or ban and withhold naturally occurring substances from the people. Government did not create nature and has no authority to take it away. A ban on Kratom, Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitraginine is just as absurd as a ban on milk, apples, or pepper.

2.) Kratom, Mitragynine, and 7-Hydroxymitraginine are NOT dangerous or addictive. Rather, it is incredibly safe, especially in comparison to alcohol, tobacco, tylenol, ibuprofen, etc. Kratom is closely related to coffee and tea, and exhibits similar effects. If one attempted to overdose on Kratom to illicit negative effects, one would have to ingest copious, repulsive amounts and actively resist reflexive vomiting. It is just as ridiculous to expect one to eat a pound of coffee in one sitting as to eat an pound of kratom. It just does not happen. Do some people people become agitated or experience a slightly elevated heart rate when they drink too much coffee? Yes. The same harmless physiologic effects apply to kratom and are dealt with by common sense and cultural education about the plant's properties.

3.) Kratom, Mitragynine, and 7-Hydroxymitraginine HELP thousands of people with a variety of physical and emotional ailments, including opiate addiction, chronic fatigue, obesity, and depression to name a few. Most significantly, Kratom has the potential to help curb the tragic opioid epidemic afflicting our nation. It is well known that heroin and prescription opioids are killing tens of thousands every year and rising. How many thousands of lives have already been saved by this not-well-known plant is unknown. But what is certain is that an unconstitutional, illogical, authoritarian, arbitrary ban placed by a small group of uninformed individuals in government will certainly result in the deaths of millions over the long term. 

For these reasons and thousands more, the People of the United States of America implore DEA and government agencies to get informed about the reality of Kratom, Mitragynine, and 7-Hydroxymitraginine. It is NOT a drug, but a plant. It is NOT harmful, dangerous, or addictive. It IS BENEFICIAL for a myriad of reasons. Just try it out and talk to users, and you will understand and agree with aforementioned.

In God we trust and pray for your wisdom and right action.

Most sincerely,
Jackson B. Brown, family, friends, and citizens of the United States of America

documents.commentText:
Hello, my name is  Shaunna and I am a marketing director for an engineering company in the Portland Metro. I have been supplementing with kratom tea for a year now. It has replaced Sam-E and my nerve medication, providing me with a more holistic alternative for helping my nerve damage, chronic pain, and emotional mood swings since my mother past away recently. It's like a multi-vitamin that helps me get through my busy days. I am able to have a clear head while I travel on business, speak at conferences, being a mom and a wife to a military veteran. I rely on this plant as much as I rely on my coffee every morning. It would be horrible if this supplement was taken away and banned. It's a plant, a herb that organic seeking people turn to in order to help manage some normal day to day physical hardships that happen to the best of us. Please do not ban this herb. I did a lot of search on the plant before adding it to my daily supplement regimen. 

I'm a professional woman, with a clean record, no substance abuse background, so this is absurd that DEA/FDA would even consider taking this away. It's like taking away Ginko Biloba! You walk into Whole Foods, half the stuff on the shelves are foreign and alternative...Just because kratom is one of those things most have not heard of, doesn't mean it's dangerous. 

Have you seen the possible side effects to Sam-E? If you don't know, the famous SamE is known to TREAT depression, anxiety, heart disease, fibromyalgia, abdominal pain, osteoarthritis, bursitis, tendonitis, chronic lower back pain, dementia, Alzheimer's disease, slowing the aging process, chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS), improving mental performance, liver disease, and Parkinson's disease. It is also used for attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, seizures, migraine headache, lead poisoning, to break down a chemical in the body called bilirubin, or to help with disorders related to the buildup of a chemical called porphyrin or its precursors. Side effects? Sometimes cause gas, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, dry mouth, headache, mild insomnia, anorexia, sweating, dizziness, and nervousness, especially at higher doses. It can also make some people with depression feel anxious..... Sounds a bit dodgy to me.... 

Point is, it's a plant...that's been extremely misunderstood and mischaracterized. Additional research should continue without the need of a ban. There has been more deaths from laundry detergent balls than kratom....and laundry balls are still legal too..... (http://www.today.com/health/never-seen-anything-more-children-harmed-ingesting-laundry-pods-t88036).

It would be foolish to take away a plant that has had nearly to no reputable studies done and a massively small percentage of reported issues--that are questionable, to say the least. Im implore you, the DEA, the FDA, to see and hear the masses that are benefiting from this supplement and not be too hasty to take away a leaf that's from the coffee family...... Thank you for taking time out to read my comment in defense of a supplement I value right along with my Ginko Biloba.... Now excuse me as I drink my Monster Energy Drink that I have been addicted to since age 18 (You might want to research this drink BTW...I can swear it's a drug). THANKS! 

Professionally yours,

Shaunna K

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

My improved state of being is literally, and can be proven to be directly caused by my ability to use Kratom as an herbal supplement.  

How can I convey the benefits this simple plant has given me and so many others?  Pain is inherent to the human physiological condition as we age, this is a given, but for some of us there is a level at which the pain can no longer be toleratednor should it be when a simple and safe solution is available.  #IamKratom.  I am also a productive member of society dedicated to the well-being of all.  

Dear DEA, please hear our stories please protect health and freedomplease do not take away or schedule the one thing, namely Kratom, that has given so many of us hope for healthy and thereby meaningful lives.

Sincerely,
LH

I'm 5'4" and looked sickly), tension headaches and constipation. But above ALL of those side effects were my horrendous mood swings and detoxification. I felt mentally UNSTABLE while on pain medication. And if I was unable to get/take my prescriptions for some reason (usually the pharmacy would run out do to OVERWRITING of meds!) I would begin to detox after about 24hours. Detoxing is physical AND psychological torture. My body would spasm and ache worse than EVER before. I would vomit and have diarrhea. It was simply TORTURE. You begin to think irrationally. You feel everyone is against you and you will do almost ANYTHING to end the detox. 
The mood swings from euphoria to manic was a daily occurrence, not just during detoxification. My children feared me and my husband loathed me. They didn't know which Mommy they were going to get and THAT is what forced me to explore alternatives. Since starting Kratom I have NO (NONE.ZIP.ZILCH.) side effects and my pain is managed beautifully! It truly saved my life...and my marriage. It should be my right to choose NATURAL remedies. Please reconsider this ban. These PLANTS are stopping opioid addiction and making is possible for addicts to get clean. The detox from meds is torture and these LEAVES capped ALL of the effects, for me. We need to make this plant MORE accessible! More people die from pharms than ANYTHING else! KRATOM needs to be utilized in rehabs across the globe NOT banned! Please hear our cries! Addicts deserve a second chance and THIS IS IT! I choose plants or pills!

documents.commentText:
I suffer from permanent spinal cord damage, the result of a staph infection which I contracted over 8 years ago. I must rely on oycodone to manage severe, chronic pain, for which I receive a prescription from my doctor. I have tried many different sorts of interventions including spinal injections, all with no results. However recently I tried the herb called Kratom, which has mitragyne and 7-hydroxymitragynine in it. To my surprise, Kratom has allowed me to reduce my opioid use dramatically. This herb is useful and safe. It does not provide any sort of "high," except a slight increase in alertness. 

As you are aware, there are very few actual analgesics for chronic pain, and all have potentially severe side effects. Kratom is one of the few positive alternatives available to those of us who have no life-time strategy for pain management except opioids, and of course the body develops both dependency and tolerance for opioids over time, which causes them to lose effectiveness. 

I urge the DEA to keep Kratom legal. Please do not restrict this. It is safe, helpful, and far less harmful than tobacco or alcohol, both of which are legal.

documents.commentText:
Luckily, I have never been in an accident or had an illness or disability that required me to go on a regular dosage of pain killers. One of my close friends in college did, however. He was a football player in high school and injured his back in a game. The doctors put him on hydrocodone and there began his addiction to opiate pain medication, which then expanded to all forms of pills from antidepressants, to antipsychotics, uppers, downers, and everything in between. At 17 he was prescribed opiate pain medication. 17! My brother is 17 and I could never imagine exposing him to opiates, I don't understand how doctors can feel okay prescribing these medications to children. 

Thankfully my friend was able to beat his addiction with the help of his friends and family. My friends and I had to have multiple interventions with him, and I know his family did as well. This is how powerful these drugs are, and we give them this hall pass because they are prescribed by physicians. If my friend had been given kratom in high school he most likely never would have known his propensity for such drugs, and even if he had been exposed to them, he would not have had a prescription that he could used to get scripts filled online. 

I think kratom has its greatest potential with our nation's youth, especially those that play contact sports and are more prone to injury. The more kids we keep from getting prescribed opiates, the less exposed our nation's youth are to the drugs as a whole. All it takes is one kid's prescription to expose all of his or her friends to these drugs. Why are we making it so easy?

documents.commentText:
To whom this may concern:


I suffer from fibromyalgia, a long term condition that causes me to be in pain all day everyday, I also suffer from terrible anxiety and panic attack brought on by my pain condition. Due to these medical conditions I am required to take multiple pain and anxiety medications (likely for the rest of my life) just to get out of bed and function like a "normal" human being. The pain medications I am required to take cause unpleasant side effects and no doubt are harming my internal organs, Mitragyna Speciosa, A.K.A Kratom has been a miracle plant to me, reducing my pain and anxiety tremendously without the unpleasant side effects of Benzodiazepines and Opiod medications. With kratom I can greatly reduce and maybe one day even eliminate my need for these medications. I plead that the DEA and FDA give this miracle plant a chance, i strongly believe this plant can help millions of Americans suffering from chronic pain like my self, and help millions of other opiate dependent people. Here is some information on kratom: 

It is known to be a natural analgesic, muscle relaxer, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant (http://www.vice.com/read/why-banning-the-controversial-painkiller-kratom-could-be-bad-news-for-americas-heroin-addicts). I currently three medications that address these issues.

According to Kratom Science (https://www.kratomscience.com/strains-effects-and-dosage): An important distinction is that unlike other administered drugs like oxycodone and morphine, kratom exhibits less dependency and addiction potential on the user. Over the last 4 years of using Tramadol, I have needed to increase the dose 3 times from 50mg 3 times a day to 5 times a day as my body had adjusted the prior dose and I was not finding relief . I am very cautious of not becoming too dependent on any one substance and believe that diversification with kratom can be beneficial to my pain management plan.

Vice News reports that it is used to wean addicts off of heroin (http://www.vice.com/read/why-banning-the-controversial-painkiller-kratom-could-be-bad-news-for-americas-heroin-addicts).
Those with multiple sclerosis, back pain, chronic fatigue syndrome and Lyme disease have reported relief when using kratom.

There have been a limited number of deaths attributed solely to kratom. Only 15 reported in the last 10 years. The majority of overdoses where kratom is present, other drugs and alcohol were all contributing factors.  Unlike opioids, kratom does not suppress the breathing function, which is an element of overdosing.
These findings led me to try kratom. After trying different strains and dosing, I can say that my pain level decreases. I have not found any medication that completely takes away my pain. Kratom definitely knocks my pain down much more than my doctor prescribed medications and gives me about 4-5 hours of relief. I found that it gives me a little boost, allowing me to be more productive and get back to work. I have been pleased with the results and love that kratom is less toxic than opioids.

Over 100,000 Americans signed a petition (including myself) to halt the DEAs two-year ban on kratom. During the temporary ban, the DEA would conduct studies on this natural supplement. To me, it makes more sense to conduct studies and then come to a conclusion on whether or not to ban kratom. It clearly helps at least 100,000 manage their pain in an era where taking any type of opioid is completely taboo. People with pain matter. Completely blocking access to kratom will have a direct impact on those who responsibly take pain medications to deal with a chronic medical issue.

In conclusion, I urge the DEA to halt the ban until further studies can be performed. I believe that I represent the majority of patients with chronic pain who use opioids. We are responsible and educated. Yes, there is an opioid epidemic in this country. However, taking away a natural supplement that could replace an opioid as pain management doesnt make any sense.

Thanks for your time, 

Evanni Dominguez

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

My name is Zachary Temple, I am a 24-year-old male who works in the IT field and I oppose the upcoming ban on kratom. I have been using kratom 1-3 times a week as a dietary supplement for roughly 2 years now.

Here is my story...

All of my life I have suffered from severe social anxiety. I always had problems talking to people, and even walking down the street making eye contact with people would cause me to experience extreme anxiety. Kratom is the only thing that I have found that effectively helps with my social anxiety. Once I began occasionally taking kratom before work, my entire demeanor changed. I went from the quiet guy in the corner, to an outgoing friendly person.
My managers soon noticed that I was completing my work in a timely manner with quality and helping others when I could. I have since been promoted and now manage a group of people. Without kratom I do not believe I would have been promoted to a management position. To hear the DEA claim that kratom is a risk to public health almost seems absurd. It really disheartens me that they would do something like that, the DEA is supposed to be a government agency for public safety, but if this scheduling proceeds as planned, more harm than good will be done. 
I am far more concerned with people who use kratom for their chronic pain management than I am concerned about myself. When kratom gets banned, many who used kratom to ween off of pharmaceutical prescription opiate painkillers may be forced to return back to them, or even worse, be forced to turn to the street to buy illegal opiates (heroin or other painkillers). This is an important issue to me as I grew up in a small town that was overrun with heroin and painkiller abuse, which has affected me immensely. One of my close friends has passed away from this epidemic, and I lost contact with a couple of other friends who stole from me or other friends to support their drug habit. 
I do not always take kratom 1-3 times during the week and often have a couple of weeks where I do not take kratom at all because I know using any supplement as a crutch will not help with an anxiety order in the long term.
I have never experienced any form of withdrawal symptoms on the days or weeks that I do not take kratom.
I believe kratom is on the same level as kava, valerian root, or St. John's wort and that it should remain a dietary supplement along with the mentions supplements.

Please consider the effect that a ban of kratom will have upon Americans.

Thank you for your time,
                                              Zachary Temple

documents.commentText:
Good Afternoon,

I began using Kratom 7 years ago to help with lower back pain, anxiety, and depression. At the time I was lost, my life was off track and I felt I had dug myself deep down in a dark hole. My brother was battling cancer, and was prescribed Oxycontin for pain management. When he was in remission, he was still going through a lot and found himself depending on his prescription to get him through the day, regardless of there being any pain or not. The last thing he needed was anymore adversity on his plate, so he looked into alternatives which is how he found Kratom. The weight lifted off his shoulders was visibly noticeable once he realized there was a way out of addiction. I began researching Kratom because I was concerned my brother was ingesting something that could cause him more harm. I found out that Kratom could also help me with my life, so I began taking it in moderation to see if it was right for me. It has helped me immensely in the last seven years. I have severe anxiety and mild depression, and nagging pain from a herniated disc in my lower back. I have never been opposed to people treating these conditions with pharmaceuticals, unfortunately for me they did more harm than good as far as my quality of life. Kratom is a great alternative for people like me, and it would truly be heartbreaking to ban this plant. I fear so many good people will be lost again and back in a dark hole they worked so hard to dig themselves out of. So many of us are responsible people, contributing members of society, and overall good people who don't deserve to have the right to consume this plant taken away from them. Kratom is doing way more good than bad, which is more than we can say about other legal things available to treat ailments, or to get a recreational "buzz" from. Please make the right decision, and know that you'll be helping so many people by doing that.

documents.commentText:
While I understand research about Kratom is still in the beginning stages, everything I have encountered about this plant, both in person and online, leads me to believe it is relatively harmless. Understanding that I am no expert in this matter, what is more compelling are observations of the plant's overwhelmingly positive affects on those suffering with opiate addiction. This makes me feel very strongly that this is not only a plant that should continue to be legal, but with proper research, can change countless lives for the better. I think the true tragedy of the plant would be its banning by the DEA before science and medical communities can fully extrapolate its pros and cons. Serving a society looking towards the future, and as an organization concerned with the well being of the general public, I think the most responsible decision the DEA can make is to allow Kraton to remain legal. 

Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:
My name is Jonathan Meeker and I'm a 35 yr old male that is employed at one of the top orange juice production and bottling companies in the US as a facilities manager. I have a B.S. in Anatomy, Physiology, and Kinesiology from the University of Florida. I have known of the medicinal and hollistic benefits of kratom since 2012. At the time my usage was very rare and I used it for headaches and pain, to avoid prescription drugs. Last New Years Eve I was in a very bad head-on collision accident on the way to work. I was airlifted to the closest trauma unit, in Ocala Florida. I suffered from 2 broken ribs, both bones broken in my right arm, my hip broken in three places, both bones broken in my right leg, and my ankle was broken into pieces. I was in the hospital for almost a month and had multiple surgeries. While in the hospital, the doctors gave me many pain medications, which I really like to avoid taking, as mentioned earlier, but the pain was severe. As soon as I was released and during my one year recovery period, I've used kratom. I've not needed to fill the prescriptions my 4 doctors where giving me every few weeks. Now, nearly a year later, I am left using a cane, with a severely deformed hip and arm. Some days my pain is worse then others, as you can probably understand. Kratom is so important to me and my use of it helps me everday. Please do not schedule this plant. It has kept me off pain medication and allowed me to function, on a daily basis, while improving my quality of life greatly. Thank you for taking the time to read my comments.

documents.commentText:
It is unbelievable to me, that such a wonderful, miracle plant such as mitragyna speciosa, aka kratom, could be SCHEDULED!  All over the news, every single day, we hear about the gigantic opioid epidemic in this country and wonder what can be done... THIS IS IT!  This plant is the only thing that allowed me to get my life back after falling into heroin and prescription pain pill addiction.  I couldn't afford rehab and the time off of work that rehab requires, I had a family to support.  I felt trapped in the addiction with no viable way out.  I couldn't take a week or 2 off of work to try a home detox either.  I was "zombie mommy" just trying to keep life together for my child.  After many desperate hours of research I luckily stumbled across kratom, and a week later I was free!!  No rehab, no therapy, no missed work... just a week of kratom saved my life.  It saddens and frustrates me that there are others out there with situations like mine and much worse who could also get their lives, their families, and themselves back with this miracle, but may not get the opportunity.  There is no dangerous aspect of this plant, it's IMPOSSIBLE to overdose, only vomit or fall asleep, so therefore there is NO viable reason under the sun that it should be scheduled.  You fail those in need of help by banning this wonderful plant and it's God given alkaloids.  Not to mention those in chronic life long pain, as the pain relieving properties FAR exceed that of ANY pharmaceutical substance anywhere.

In short, I know that there is no need to "battle the opioid epidemic" as long as kratom is available, well known, and easily accessible because it is the answer to the problem.  You create more problems, and do a dis-service to those in need by taking away their best hope for recovery and freedom.

Thank you, 
A concerned recovered addict.

documents.commentText:
Mitragyna speciosa has for almost two years now provided me long lasting pain relief, as well as the energy and focus to do my work and do it well - be it a tough physical job or challenging college course work, it has noticeably improved my chronic back pain and occasional lapses of attention span. I can't even grasp the idea of blacklisting it as a dangerous drug, because I would never have described it with either of those words - it does not create some downward spiral or anything that could reasonably called a "high", and anyone that claims otherwise is either imagining things or is taking something else in conjunction (or is intentionally smearing the plant with ulterior personal motives, but I won't start on that).  

My standard for consciousness is being able to read something and remember it, and anything that would diminish my ability to do so is off the table for me these days. I like kratom because it provides moderate improvements in difficult areas of my life without the equally noticeable downsides associated with analogous pharmaceuticals (regarding both internal and mental health). In its native regions, it is popular with laborers for the reasons I've described. Shouldn't America's workers have the same access to such a helpful herb? If it needs more proper labeling, that is understandable - but to ban it outright would be absolutely asinine and counterproductive in a nation always seeking safer ways of improving living standards.

documents.commentText:
Hello, my name is Jarod and i believe kratom has many health benefits, if made illegal it would prevent others from helping themselves. 
I personally struggled with heroin addiction for five years, starting when i was sixteen. I saw no way out of my addiction and didnt think i was going to live to see my twenty first birthday. After getting in trouble with the law because of my addiction i knew i had to get off heroin, if i couldn't i would surley die or be in and out of jail my whole life. After doing a little research, i kept reading how kratom is a highly recommended herb to help ease opiate withdrawal. I had my doubts but to my surprise it worked. Not only did kratom ease my withdrawals, i was able to sleep, eat, relax, and not vomit at all. This was 20 months ago, since then i havent used any drugs or alcohol. It also helps with my social anxiety in a immense way. Im now living a normal life with a good job, great friends and a loving family. If it wasnt for kratom i would not be here today, a productive member of society that has a bright future ahead of him. Kratom has also help my father get off presciption pain killers. After rupturing two dics in his back he was destined to take pain killers the rest of his life. His pain was so bad he told me, "If i didnt have two boys that depend on me i would have ate a bullet years ago". After 13 years of him taking multiple prescription pain killers and two surgerys i suggested kratom to him. That day changed his life, he was amazed a simple herb can take away pain that made a grown man want to kill himself. He now takes two, four gram doses a day and hasnt taken a single pain killer for 13 months. Kratom is a miracle herb that has many health benfits and has helped thousands of people a year. It is the greatest alternative to pain killers and many other presciption drugs Please dont schedule Kratom, it would only escalate things such as illegal and presciption drug abuse. 
Thank you for taking the time to read this, JRB

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern: 

Last week, I walked in to the place where I buy my kratom most of the time.  At the register, they had a pile of leaflets directing me here to leave a comment, and some guiding information about where they stand on the issue.  It was all very sound until I got to the middle section where they stated emphatically that "Kratom is not addictive".  This is the only grey area I encounter when it comes to this plant.  I've been using it on and off for 2 years, you see, in "stints" that ranged from 3 weeks to 3 months--always daily--and each time I chose to stop, I experienced withdrawal.  It was classic addiction.  Mind you, the withdrawal was not intolerable.  It always averaged out to just a little under 3 days during which I mainly lay in bed watching TV.  I know this isn't the same for everyone.  

I have a friend in Idaho I introduced to kratom for his back pain (I use it for medicine resistant depression) and he has been using it as often as he pleases with zero discernible withdrawal whenever he stops.  As he's gone through half a kilo on his own already, I am incredulous that he seems immune to Kratom addiction.  (He used to smoke cigarettes for years, and was also a chronic drinker before Kratom stopped his drinking altogether, so he is not immune to addiction itself).  

I just stopped Kratom after a month of daily use, and this is the beginning of 4 days clean. Do I miss it?  Yes.  Even though the easy detox period is over, I miss the stimulation of Kratom and just how much it allows me to accomplish (with a fairly clear head, I might add, save some short term memory issues while I'm on it.  I generally keep a list in my pocket to keep track of responsibilities).  What's the longest I've been off it since I began this Kratom adventure?  About 
4 months.  

Downsides:   Constipation (I manage it fine with stool softeners)
                      The memory thing I already mentioned
                      The lack of appetite that is par for the course on Kratom
                      The inability to achieve orgasm without pausing in my usage for about 16 hours.
                      A cigarette smoker may see his smoking increase by twice their normal amount.


Conclusion:  When I heard Kratom was to be banned at the end of September, I had very mixed feelings.  At first, I only selfishly thought of me.  I was both happy that I would be forced to find another alternative for untreatable depression that might not inhibit my digestion or sex drive, and I was outraged I would have to find an alternative for untreatable depression....
In twenty years, I've been on virtually every antidepressant under the sun.  

When I considered Kratom's usefulness for others, that's when I really did my homework.  In short, if Kratom is listed on a Schedule that prevents research that will ultimately keep this substance from the hands of hardcore opiate addicts--you know:  the kind one can actually overdose on, unlike Kratom--then America will continue to lose its children for lack of a solution to heroin/painkiller epidemic that actually works.  The testimonials are out there.  Kratom saves lives. 

Thank you for your time.  


R. Trevor Mills

documents.commentText:
Hello. I am a 20 year old male. I have haemochromatosis, a genetic disorder, which causes me to absorb too much iron and causes painful tendon problems, skeletal pain, migraines, and problems with my organs (due to iron being stored in them). On top of this, I have issues with my P450 enzyme system in my liver. I am an under-methylator which means my body doesn't break down nutrients properly. I unfortunately was born with bad genes in this regard. I have tried pharmaceuticals to help with depressive symptoms and physical pain, all of which only made my symptoms worse. Even over the counter pain medications either do nothing for my pain or make it worse. I did find some relief from gabapentin (Neurontin) but it made me too tired to go about my day. I also developed a tolerance to it and it gave me very unpleasant withdrawal symptoms, to the point where I felt mentally unstable just hours after taking a dose. I found out about kratom after I heard it was being scheduled. I decided to try some while it was still legal just to see if it helped. I was hoping it would help my physical pain, but it has done much more that just to help manage pain. It gives me clean energy that I haven't ever felt before. I don't really have anything else to take to give me energy. Coffee/caffeine gives me migraines and visual disturbances. It makes me physically sick and it doesn't actually give me energy. It just makes me unable to sleep and causes me to feel extremely stressed out. I don't know if the iron overloaded from haemochromatosis causes this, or if my other genetic issues are to blame. It probably is a mixture of the two. I do know my liver and thyroid functioning is compromised to some degree, and not reacting well to "normal" substances- especially MSG (glutamate) and caffeine, has been a huge problem of mine starting around the time I hit puberty. 

Since taking kratom, I have had energy and my pain levels are down. I don't feel depressive brain fog that used to plague my day to day life. What still amazes me to this day is, kratom gives me no "crash" that other stimulants do. I take some in the morning and evening usually. I end up getting a great night's rest and wake up feeling refreshed. I was actually able to come completely off gabapentin with the help of kratom and I no longer have been taking gabapentin. My quality of life is the best it has been since I was a very young child. I am able to go on long runs without experiencing tendon pain in my ankles and legs, for example. Furthermore, I can say that using kratom responsibly has yielded less withdrawal symptoms- less addictive potential than the gabapentin had, and I was taking that as prescribed by my doctor. I have read the science behind kratom addiction. It takes a very large amount of kratom powder to stimulate the mu-opioid receptors in the brain (which are the ones involved in addiction to mitragynine, the main psychoactive alkaloid in kratom) and the amounts I am using simply isn't causing me the type of addiction I experienced on gabapentin.

If kratom is scheduled I do not know what I will do. What I do know is that my quality of life will decline; I will be in significant physical pain, and I ultimately will be faced with the decision to go back on pharmaceuticals that are either more addictive or are not metabolized by my liver correctly.

There are thousands of farmers around the world who rely on preparing kratom leaves and exporting them for work. Scheduling kratom would simply not be fair to them or to me, nor would it be fair to those on opioid narcotic pain medications much stronger than gabapentin, whose quality of life has been improved since taking kratom. 

In reality, kratom is just a tea leaf. It can be taken as tea or taken as a supplement, just like many teas are. It isn't anywhere near as dangerous as the few people in positions of power seem to believe. If kratom is dangerous and needs to be scheduled, please also consider scheduling sugar, MSG, caffeine, alcohol, and NSAIDs such as Tylenol. They are all more dangerous than the kratom leaf.
