documents.commentText:
I am a 41 year old male pursuing my Social Sciences degree. I graduated my HiSet w/Honors, and am a straight A-B student. 

I have advanced degenerative osteoarthritis in my knees (bilateral), and arthritis in my neck as well. I've been prescribed Mobic/Meloxicam twice a day, and it helped with all but the most serious pain. However, noticing some side-effects I wasn't comfortable with, I self-discontinued and the pain became so bad that I Googled alternative pain relief measures and Kratom came up almost immediately.

However, not wanting to do anything risky, I began studying it. I have yet to take any, even though my first batch came in the  mail several weeks ago. I am still collecting information, and hope you will do so as well before making it a Shedule I controlled substance.

But I can tell you that some form of regulation needs to occur, so that incidents like the Sweden fatalities, as well as other incidents occurring as the result of (usually) tainted Kratom do not occur again.

Here is some of what my research has yielded:

Kratom is highly individualistic in how it interacts with the human body. Some people get sick of a gram, while some can consume over fifteen grams daily without incident (reportedly--this information comes from self-reports.) 

It is an opioid agonist, and can help with opiate withdraw issues. It is not been known (read: directly observed) to affect the CNS' respiratory functions in a negative way, as does opioids. However, if taken with an opioid, it may magnify the opiate's response to the CNS and depress breathing moreso than the opiate would alone.

It has caused seizures in a small (reportedly) percentage of the population of daily users. It has been remarked that it may have withdraw symptoms similar to those experienced by heroin users. Other side effects are those found with most opioids, and a far shorter list than those associated with Meloxicam, I might add. Some ephedrine/heroin/caffeine side effects are also reported in a small percentage of users. The extent of potent hepatoxicity is undetermined, but from self-reports I've seen, I believe it is higher than many would claim. Further studies need done on this, for this is perhaps one of the most serious health risks Kratom may pose, should it exist to that extent.

Further studies also need to be done on the potential spectrum of drug interactions in the human body when taking Kratom and other prescribed substances. Most of the studies on this reference many drugs that conflict (fatally so) with standard opiates, In the majority of deaths associated with Kratom, Tramadol was a significant factor. Kratom does not play well with other stimulants, depressants, SSRI's, Psychedelics, or MAOI's. But beyond that, we know little else about what it might interact negatively with. 

The safest way to consume Kratom is by steeping it as a tea. It can also be taken as a pill, but for many that aggravates the stomach lining, especially if taken on an empty stomach. It should never, ever be injected or smoked. A common method among many users is the 'toss-n'wash,' where a certain amount of Kratom is put into the mouth, then chased by a liquid and swallowed. This may complicate pre-existing lung issues, or may cause these issues to occur where they might not have before. Think cinnamon challenge, and that's basically what you have. Research needs to be carried out to determine a safe maximum daily dosage, though this is hard with Kratom's unique effects on varying individuals. There has been no determined fatality limit associated with Kratom, as the body's defensive reactions to it seem exceedingly similar to those of the neuro-toxin capciasin. In other words, it appears that in severe overdose cases, the body will do everything in its power to incapacitate the recipient before death is a possibility.

While I think Schedule I is a bit much, I do agree with certain regulation protocols to protect the people from unsavory sellers and con-men. I also believe that nearly any pharmaceutical and OTC medicine carries much higher rates of dangerous side-effects than is possible with Kratom.

documents.commentText:
Thank you for reconsidering your decision to schedule kratom without public comment. I have read through a number of comments. While aren't many studies that confirm the anecdotal evidence in these comments, I hope that the 1000s of people who have shared their story give regulators pause when considering scheduling kratom. 

I have never used kratom, but my wife used it successfully to treat chronic pain. We're a young family. I'm 33, my wife 32, and our daughter 2. With the exception of this year, my wife had slowly deteriorated physically and mentally from chronic pain for the last number of years. She saw her primary care doctor countless times along with regular visits to the rheumatologist and other specialists.

Under the care of her doctors, she slowly but surely was prescribed a larger and larger batter of pharmaceutical medications. Sometimes, the pain would temporarily subside but mostly it stayed the same or progressed. Her mental condition was the most difficult for her and to see. Towards the end of using Lyrica, Abilify, Xanax, and a handful of other medications that I can't remember, she became agoraphobic. Her condition was wrongly thought to be progressing and was told to see a neurologist and get an EMG. 

In truth, she was experiencing side effects from medications and then put on additional medications to address the side effects. It was a vicious circle that increased her anxiety substantially and, looking back, likely caused a psychosomatic increase in pain. 

I kept looking for answers because I was losing my wife and was drowning in the pressure of being a caregiver to my baby, my wife, and as the sole breadwinner. Occasionally, my wife would be open to trying alternative treatments. One of them was kratom. We were thoughtful about her approach to using kratom including it's dose, what strains to use and when, and so on. Kratom is most effective in small amounts and kratom has a natural way of preventing you from taking it in large amounts, nausea and taste!

Are there people misusing kratom, surely. The people who are misusing kratom are mixing with it opioids and other drugs. Just as surely as people are misusing kratom, they aren't dying from it. They are dying from fentanyl, heroin, etc. and happen to have kratom in their system at the time. 

Do people who use kratom often continue to use it for potentially indefinite periods of time, yes. There are counter examples though. My wife used kratom for a short period and the relief allowed her to the opportunity to get off all of her prescriptions medications. Kratom gave me my wife back. Her pain levels reduced substantially from her improved mental state and with some subsequent dietary changes her pain has subsided.

As to the people who depend upon kratom. It's important to point out something that you already know, that dependence and addiction are two different things. You and I are dependent upon water. We don't, however, exhibit the kind of behaviors of substance use disorder such as physically risky behaviors, isolating ourselves from important relationships, etc. Just as some people are on SSRIs indefinitely, some kratom users are too because they need the results that it produces.

Users of this herbal supplement can keep their tolerance low by changing the strains that they use regularly, an occasional off day, and other methods. 

In short, kratom doesn't meet the definition of a schedule 1 drug. It has medicinal value and it's addiction potential is low. 

My wife's experience with kratom and my own with chiropractic care, has led me to believe that regulatory agencies should to take an extremely conservative approach in regulating alternative health. This is my body and I'm responsible for what I put it in it with some notable exceptions that endanger public health, eg. heroin, cocaine, etc. Kratom is a natural substance and with care can be a helpful supplement to many. 

I'm sure that there are people using all kinds of herbs irresponsibly thought not necessarily recreationally. I read a story about someone who slathered neem, used to clean teeth in some forms among other uses, all over his teeth and gums leaving it there for 20 minutes. At that point, he was desperately posting on an alternative health forum because the skin on his gums was peeling. I'm sure he ended up fine, and hopefully he learned that he is responsible for his health and it's a sacred responsibility that should be pursued with thought and care.

I ask that you not schedule kratom since it does not meet the criteria for a schedule one drug and that, generally speaking, you allow people to take responsibility for their own health as they see fit.

I am opposed to the scheduling of Kratom as a controlled substance. I am a 56 year old male. I have two children, am a licensed attorney in the state of Michigan, and am currently employed in the oil and gas industry as a landman. I currently use Kratom on a daily basis for therapeutic reasons. Throughout the years I have suffered from and been diagnosed with clinical depression. I have tried numerous medications in the past that have either been ineffective or have resulted in unpleasant side effects. A friend recommended that I give Kratom a try. 

I researched the scientific literature and discovered several studies that suggest that Kratom has an antidepressant effect without impairing one's abilities to function. It has also been discovered that Kratom has an anti inflammatory effect. Some research has found that depression may be a result of inflammation in the body, which alters mood. Having taken Kratom for over 3 years now, I can personally state that my mood has improved and stabilized. I am able to parent and work without impairment of any kind. It has allowed me to be a more productive person. 

The effect I experience when using Kratom has been an increase in energy and a mild uplift in mood, not unlike drinking several cups of coffee, but without the jitters and without the inevitable crash. (Interestingly, Kratom is a plant in the coffee family). In the 3 years I have used Kratom I have experienced no ill effects or unpleasant side effects like I have in the past with prescribed medications. I have not personally experienced any effects of addiction, and I use the same amount daily without any increase in tolerance. I also have not experienced any effects which I would consider similar to narcotic medications. I have found Kratom to be similar to St. John's Wort, which is marketed as an OTC herbal remedy for depression, but I have found it to be much more effective. 

I would be devastated if this natural herbal substance were to be made illegal (and me a criminal), especially when I have found it to be effective in treating my symptoms of depressions and when further scientific research into Kratom is sorely needed.

documents.commentText:
To All That Will Actually Pause A Momental To Read My Comment!!

First, I would like to thank you for opening this up for public comment. Honestly, I want to clarify a few things about my experience with kratom.

Several years ago, I became chronically ill  to the point I was bedridden...in my late forties. My wonderful husband had to do everything up to and including shampooing my hair and shaving my legs for me. Daily, I crawled to the bathroom because the neuropathy was excruciating.  Being a person that has always worked 2 or 3 jobs, this was extremely  difficult. Not just physically but mentally. 

I had raised my children and this was supposed to be the years to travel, take up hobbies and enjoy life. It was a nightmare of a life! Each morning I wondered WHY? Why on Earth did I wake up again? The pills were making me sicker. I needed two more pills to cover the side effects of the pill prescribed last month. 

Finally, enough was enough! I searched the Internet for natural alternatives.  Lo and behold, I discovered kratom. I researched it for 6 months before trying it. Now, let me be clear, it didn't cure or heal me, what it did do is allowed my symptoms to be more manageable.  I got ip out of bed, started a business, have traveled and been able to pursue some hobbies. There is no "high", there is no drowsiness...in fact, quite the opposite. I feel energetic, mood elevation, mental clarity and overall "feel like I did in my twenties".  

To take this plant from me, would be like putting the final nails in my coffin. We are law abiding citizens, a veteran family with my son active duty, a grandmother to 8 and they sure love spending "fun" time with Granny. In conclusion,  I ask that you keep kratom legal and know that wouldn't just effect me but my entire family as well as millions of others. Thank you for your time!

My name is Kristen I am 41. I have worked in the Medical and Perscription drug field for 14 years.  Kratom should not be further considered to be a potential Schedule 1 controlled substance.  Our society has largely become addicts of many of the drugs that the FDA has approved and pushed into our homes. Our drug dependence issues in this country are not because of a naturally occuring plant that has been avilable for decades. Addiction has been cause by the very drugs that the  DEA and FDA have approved and " Scheduled" for our " Safety" . 
People seeking to abuse a substance are not going looking for Kratom. Kratom is not a street drug.  They are breaking into pharmacies and homes or buying it from friends who have perscriptions for real " Schedule 1 " medications.  
I have a chronic pain condition at 41. That means in a years time I went from feeling like a 39 year  old , to feeling like I was over the age of 80 and in failing health.   I am not a person that will accept pain as the winner  and allow it to take over my life.  I attempted many of the approved medications to assist with the pain. Changed my diet, did Physical therapy anything to help learn how to adjust to a different way of life. The medications had so many side affects that although it took the edge off the pain at times it left me barely able to function at work or keep my concentration to drive.  I was becoming a person consumed by my illness and the medications to treat it . I could lose my job, my home I have two children I support on only my income. I began a quest for alternative options to my care.  Kratom has been a part of the new path to wellness for me. I don't need it every day. I have no side effects.  I have a 1/4 of a teaspoon in the morning if I am having a difficult day.  I sometimes use at night to help me sleep. 
Kratom has given me a big portion of my functionality back so I can at least manage my life on a better level.  If you have never taken a drug like Cymbalta you will never know what you have to give up just to get a tiny bit back. With Kratom I give up nothing and the benefits are large. 
The percentage of people who use this to better their lives far exceeds the few who may have abused it. As is the case with anything as simple as food, cold mdicine etc.  Look at the real drug issues in this country, not ones that don't exist.

documents.commentText:
There are many reasons not to go forward with banning kratom:

1.  Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
2.  If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
3.  Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
4.  Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
5.  Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
6.  Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Instead of banning this drug maybe it's uses as a substitute for addictive drugs like opiods particularly since it has minimal side effects and witdrawal issues should be welcomed.

Sincerely,

Kay M. Randall  Moorhead MN

documents.commentText:
I stumbled upon Kratom around 8 months ago by happenstance while researching natural alternatives to pain killers for coping with chronic pain. My main concern was the long-term use of opiates and acetaminophen on my body. I came across a few articles discussing individual experiences with kratom and decided to do more research. In my research, I found that kratom was more than just a plant, but also a community.

I ordered a small amount to try for myself, initially quite skeptical. I was surprised to see how much of an improvement it made almost immediately. The best part? No major side effects. 

Over time, I have found that the kratom community is made up of people from all walks of life: military veterans, teachers, accountants, retirees, lawyers, students, IT specialists, factory workers, among others.

I won't delve much deeper than that, but I strongly believe this plant needs to remain unscheduled and widely available. I would NOT have a problem with regulations being put in place to make sure what is imported is free of other materials and to make sure nefarious actors don't falsely sell it offering it as a "natural high" or try to sell it to minors. More studies need to be funded and keeping it unscheduled would facilitate that. There is already an immense amount of anecdotal evidence that this plant is safe, effective, and improved the lives of many people.

The majority of people that actually gather, ship, import, sell, and use kratom are GOOD, ordinary citizens, with full-time jobs and families. To schedule or ban this plant would hurt people, plain and simple. Please do the right thing. Please do the research. Please keep this plant legal and available.

I started using kratom 7 years ago to combat my opioid addiction.  It worked great -- reduces the aches, controls the cravings (along with a bit of will), and not harmful or addictive like most medicine that just treats individual symptoms.  Around that time I also quit smoking, which I like to think kratom played a part in that too.

Its now 7 years later, still utilizing the powers of kratom without any ill effects.  I work a just that requires manual labour -- kratom helps ease the back and muscle pain at the end of the day.  If going out to a social event -- kratom helps ease my social anxiety.  This plant is wonderful and eases a number of different ailments for so many people. To make a natural plant illegal that has no real adverse effects documented is ridiculous and unnecessary.

Why take multiple pills each to only mask certain symptoms, when we have a plant that works to manage a whole host of things with little to no side effects? 

If this plant becomes illegal with no real replacement, you will be signing a death warrant for countless recovering opioid addicts -- as they will surely go back to other things not being able to manage withdrawal symptoms. documents.commentText:
I am commenting because I do not agree with the DEAs intent to regulate or ban the plant Kratom.  My name is Nathan Nacey and I have been a kratom user for over a year now.  I came to try kratom in hopes that it would help with my chronic back pain. 5 years ago I began to have an onset of continual pain in my lower back.  I eventually found out that I had two torn discs in my back as well as degenerative disc disease and dysfunction of the sacrum.  Surgery was an option but no doctor would perform it on someone so young.  My full time job suffered as I was unable to sit for extended periods of time and I had to be put on Family Medical leave.  One of the worst parts of being in chronic pain is that it never goes away.  Not only did it interrupt my day to day life but it caused me not to be able to sleep or exercise or do much of anything.  My pain doctor tried multiple things including injections into my spine, chiropractic care, physical therapy, decompression therapy etc.  He tried to keep the pain at bay by prescribing opiods yet these did not work and he was hesitant to prescribe because he feared I would be addicted.  Truth was , I WAS addicted.  There is nothing you can do when you live in chronic pain and people have no way to heal you.  He in fact told me that the best he could do was to keep me comfortable but even this was a lie as the pain meds just werent working and I was taking them only to avoid further withdrawal .   When I tried kratom I got sick to my stomach a bit the first time.  I didnt throw up but after reading so many positive stories I decided to stick with it.  The second time I tried it I took a little less and found that my pain in fact was reduced more than when I would take pain killers.    It was a very easy decision after seeing how effective it was in helping my pain; I stopped going to the doctor who couldnt do anything other than prescribe me more meds.  I went back to work and now take it daily when I feel the onset of pain.  I can function on it while at my desk at work and it actually even gives me a bit of energy and focus (similar to coffee).  I have taken it for over a year now and have no ill effects.  My wife and family are happy that I take it and have found relief.  I can tell you with certainty that if the plant is not accessible to me in the future I will have no choice but to go directly to the pain doctor and start taking opiates again.  My pain condition does not go away ever.  It is underlying and always there, but at a minimum I seem to find relief more with this plant than anything else.  In addition to this benefit  I was able to quit opiates all together with what seemed like minimal withdrawal.  Such a clear choice; take synthetic drugs or get help from an all natural plant.  
Sincerely,
Nathan Nacey

At most, it might cause a little nausea if too much is taken at once.This is a natural plant that only helps people, and I find it ridiculous that it has even gone this far, that the DEA is considering scheduling it. Please reconsider. Thank You.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,
I am contacting you in regards to classification of Kratom to a schedule 1 drug.  I am opposed to this because I believe Kratom can be used as a viable resource in the fight of opiate addiction.  Being a teacher since 2001, I have witnessed the loss of a generation due to opiate addiction.  I believe Kratom can be used to both treat those in pain and help those in their fight against addiction.  Please give it a chance and provide hope to those that are lost.

Sincerely,

Scott Land, PES
